webTitle: Todd in line as Swindon sack Quinn

fields.headline: Todd in line as Swindon sack Quinn
fields.trailText: Jimmy Quinn was sacked by relegated Swindon Town last night, paving the way for Colin Todd to return to management eight months after he resigned from Bolton Wanderers.
fields.body:
Jimmy Quinn was sacked by relegated Swindon last night, paving the way for Colin Todd to return to management eight months after he resigned from Bolton.

Todd's appointment should be confirmed in the next week if, as expected, the millionaire printer Terry Brady completes his £3m takeover of the club.

Todd is likely to ask Brian Kidd, the former Blackburn manager who coached at Swindon in the 80s, to work as his assistant. He will be given £2m by Brady, the father of Birmingham's managing director Karren, to try to haul the club out of the Second Division at the first attempt.

"I felt the club needed someone with a little more experience [than Quinn] to take it forward," Brady said, "and if my deal is agreed I want to bring in Colin Todd as manager. We are very good friends and he thinks we can work well together."

Quinn took over in 1998 after Steve McMahon resigned, but he ended up selling 15 players as debts rose. Relegation was confirmed last month with the club in administration and losing £25,000 a week. His No2 Alan McDonald is in temporary charge.

 Police used teargas, causing the Croatian Cup final first leg to be abandoned four minutes from time in Split last night when Dinamo Zagreb and Hajduk Split fans were about to invade the pitch and clash. Hajduk were leading 2-0.

fields.headline: Hammers steam into hot water
fields.trailText: Arsenal 2 - 1 West Ham
fields.body:
West Ham will almost certainly face the wrath of the Football Association after letting anger overcome better judgment last night.

A disputed Arsenal winner in the third minute of injury-time was the cue for disgraceful scenes reminiscent of the game between these two sides at Upton Park this season, when Marc-Vivien Foe and Patrick Vieira were sent off. Now Foe may be in more trouble after appearing to push the referee Paul Durkin at the final whistle.

Foe was one of several West Ham players who surrounded the official, protesting about Emmanuel Petit's injury-time winner which deprived their makeshift team of a point and raised Arsenal's hopes of finishing second in the Premiership.

Paolo di Canio and Trevor Sinclair were booked for their protests and minutes later Sinclair was sent off after bringing down Ray Parlour.

In all Durkin issued nine yellow cards - but only two to Arsenal - and the red. It was a tetchy game in which the home side played below their best against a West Ham side missing no fewer than 13 players for various reasons.

So the fact that Harry Redknapp's patched-up side had a draw snatched from them in such controversial circumstances - Petit's shot also benefited from a huge deflection off West Ham's Igor Stimac - was difficult to stomach. But it was no excuse for haranguing the referee in such an aggressive manner, and in the current climate the FA will no doubt consider individual and collective disciplinary charges.

Redknapp courted further trouble afterwards with his scathing comment about Durkin. "They ought to find reasons to clamp down on poor referees who are not doing their job properly," he said.

"Some of my players are in tears in the dressing room. They feel they've been cheated by the referee. They feel the referee has robbed them of a result by a bad decision."

Arsène Wenger was understandably happier. "The ball rebounded against Petit's hand," he said, arguing that it was not deliberate and therefore within the rules.

It was hard on West Ham, who were so short of personnel they were forced to name their 42-year-old goalkeeping coach Les Sealey as a substitute. But by combining bags of spirit with their trademark passing they more than held their own.

Arsenal just about created the better early chances. Parlour fired a shot wide, Gilles Grimandi headed straight at the goalkeeper and Tony Adams saw his effort diverted over. But five minutes before the interval the home side, without the injured Thierry Henry and Martin Keown, were punished for their lacklustre performance. Sinclair unleashed a shot which David Seaman could only parry and Di Canio tucked away the rebound.

Dennis Bergkamp twice went close, then Paulo Wanchope skewed a shot wide at the other end. But then the Uefa Cup finalists brought on Petit, who had started on the bench because of an injury doubt, and immediately looked more threatening. The equaliser came when Marc Overmars twisted past Foe and cleverly scored just inside the post.

The Dutchman twice went close to scoring again before controversy arrived. The ball touched Petit's hand after a throw-in but he turned and unleashed a 30-yard shot which deflected off Stimac to wrong-foot young Stephen Bywater.

webTitle: Festa has final word in Tyne-Tees drama

fields.headline: Festa has final word in Tyne-Tees drama
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 2 - 2 Newcastle
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
Derby games don't come any better than this domestic dispute between two of the north-east's Robson clan. Just ask Gianluca Festa and Alessandro Pistone for confirmation.

The two Italians have played in Milan derbies for Inter, but it is unlikely they have been involved in a more absorbing or entertaining affair. It was truly a match to remember.

Festa, the Middlesbrough defender, and Newcastle's full-back Pistone contributed two of the goals, and the others came from a Brazilian and a Welshman. Alan Shearer, a rare local lad, waited in vain for the 300th of his career.

In the context of the Premiership, of course, this was an inconsequential match between two mid-table teams who have again failed to fulfil their potential. The north-east viewed it differently. The two Robsons - Bryan and Bobby - are managers born in the region and both stressed to their players the importance of not finishing below their two Premiership neighbours. Fans in this part of the world are grateful for any reason to gloat during the summer, however insignificant, so Sunderland will relish the fact they will finish as top dogs in the north- east.

The tone of a match of passion, commitment and incident was set by a goal for Middlesbrough after only five minutes. The scorer was Juninho, eager to prove to Bryan Robson that he is worth keeping when his loan from Atletico Madrid ends in the summer. The Brazilian's close-range header from Colin Cooper's excellent cross helped his case, but the fact that it was only his fourth goal of the season indicates why he may be heading back to Spain.

Newcastle's response was irresistible. In the 10th minute Kieron Dyer's cross was met first time by Gary Speed's supposedly weaker right foot from 16 yards for his 11th goal of the season.

Eight minute later Newcastle were ahead when Shearer nudged on Nolberto Solano's corner and Pistone drove in his first goal in nearly three seasons at the club.

Three goals in 13 minutes and there could have been at least five more in a remarkable first half, with most of the opportunities falling to Middlesbrough.

After the interval Festa squandered a glorious chance from Christian Ziege's free-kick before he finally equalised 12 minutes from time. The Italian dived in to head the substitute Robbie Stockdale's cross past Shay Given to ensure the only appropriate result, even if it left Bobby Robson dismayed.

The Newcastle manager confronted the referee Mike Riley, apparently angry about a foul in the build-up to the goal, and said later: "No comment. I might say something I regret."

fields.headline: Asaba treble sinks Cardiff
fields.trailText: Gillingham 4 - 1 Cardiff
fields.body:
At the finish the players shook hands and went their different ways, Gillingham seemingly up into the First Division and Cardiff, for sure, down into the Third, which ensures Oxford's safety. Carl Asaba's hat-trick had major significance for both ends of the table.

With immaculate timing the Gills moved up to second place, the highest they have been all season, and a win at Wrexham on Saturday will see them promoted to the second tier for the first time.

"It's in our hands but we are not expecting any favours from Wrexham," said Gillingham's manager Peter Taylor, who has shrugged off the disappointment of losing his job in the England set-up to inspire a club denied promotion in last May's dramatic play-off final.

Despite Taylor's caution it will be surprising if they do slip up. They are admired by all their rivals for an unstinting work rate and resolute character, and they needed to dig deep last night after Cardiff took a second-minute lead and would have added another if Kevin Nugent had been able to finish in the style that Jason Bowen had produced 60 seconds earlier.

Gillingham owed their equaliser to Cardiff's Andy Legg, who muffed a back-pass; Asaba slipped the ball home. Their second came from a free-kick which followed a shirt-tugging contest between Legg and Asaba, who clearly pulled first; Legg should not have been shown the red card and when Nicky Southall converted the kick it added injury to insult.

Asaba, who has missed most of the season with injury, then took advantage of another defensive lapse to make it three.

Cardiff kept pushing forward after half-time and forced Vince Bartram into making two fine saves. But it left them in peril when they lost the ball and Asaba's third goal, superbly swept home, duly followed.

fields.headline: A balance of skills
fields.standfirst:
Bobby Watson
Ronnie Scott's, London
****
fields.trailText:
Bobby Watson
Ronnie Scott's, London
****
fields.body:
With his torrential mane, lean frame and passionately quivering limbs, the Kansas-born altoist Bobby Watson looks like a thoroughbred steeplechaser. Appropriately, his mix of Charlie Parker's headlong lyricism, Johnny Hodges' beseeching romantic blandishments and Stevie Wonder's funkiness is all about leaping the obstacles of life.

Watson has been coming here since the late 70s, when he was musical director of a forceful line-up of Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers. He may be more grizzled and less mercurially quick than he was when his remarkable fluency first struck the jazz world, but his sound is magnificent. An R&B player's stomping drive consistently underpins the intricacies of his improvisations.

For his week in London, Watson is also in very congenial company. Bassist Curtis Lundy and drummer Victor Lewis are long-time partners, and in John Hicks Watson has a pianist of much the same alacrity of thought and execution as himself.

Watson attractively spliced the abstract and the inviting from the start. The initially Coltrane-inspired River Jordan, an intense lament over a two-chord piano vamp, turned out to have something close to a fusion groove as its middle section.

Lundy's seamlessly murmuring bassline and Lewis's bumpy-road drumming lifted Watson into spaces he filled with double-time soliloquies and bluesy phrasing. The unaccompanied circular-breathing display that then followed showcased all the saxophonist's formidable technique.

Watson has an explosive stockpile of pyrotechnical effects always close to ignition, but he is also a master of texture. He will impart a rich variety of tone colours to a single repeated warbling sound, or recycle a shapely phrase with barely perceptible shifts of nuance. On Curtis Lundy's ballad Nobody Needs to Know, his swoony Johnny Hodges-style sigh seemed to fill the whole room.

The band was as attentively reflective on this piece as it had been unwaveringly fearless on its demanding predecessors. Here were individual and collective skills in a fine balance.

Bobby Watson's group is playing at Ronnie Scott's until Saturday. Box office: 020-7439 0747.

fields.headline: Exploring extremes
fields.standfirst:
Unknown, Forgotten and Remembered: A Day of Russian Music
Purcell Room, London
***
fields.trailText:
Unknown, Forgotten and Remembered: A Day of Russian Music
Purcell Room, London
***
fields.body:
Although the Centre for Russian Music's day of concerts claimed to be a celebration of the "Unknown, Forgotten and Remembered", the most striking feature of much of the music was the exploitation of extremes.

In Elena Firsova's Sonata for solo clarinet, a wailing, glissando-inflected melody was magnified and distended through Colin Lawson's carefully sculpted playing into ever-wilder contrasts and conflicts. From the same generation of fortysomething Russian composers, Alexander Raskatov's Kyrie Eleison for solo cello required Alexander Ivashkin to tap, stroke and batter his instrument. However, these apparent gimmicks brought expressive dividends.

The "Unknown" was represented by world premieres of works by Alfred Schnittke, Dmitri Smirnov and Edison Denisov. Schnittke's Variations for string quartet is one of the composer's last pieces, written during his final years of severe physical debilitation. It is possible to hear the Variations' unalloyed diatonicism as an attempt to create a serene musical perfection. But the work treads close to saccharine banality - this is no Heiliger Dankgesang-like catharsis.

Dmitri Smirnov's Postlude in Memoriam Alfred Schnittke is a lamenting melody for solo violin, whose sincere sentiments suffered under Oleh Krysa's oppressively bright tone. The most interesting of the world premieres was Denisov's Hymn for eight cellos, which had all the energy and melancholy of a Shostakovich scherzo, its slow movement compressed into a single, six-minute blaze.

Sofia Gubaidulina's Quaternion for four cellos, new to this country, was an intense exploration of the enormous range of this most sonorous of instrumental line-ups: from the tiny, breathy sounds made from bowing the outside of the instruments, to a catatonic, chromatic polyphony. Another British premier, of Vladimir Tarnopolsky's trio, Echoes of a Passed Day, allowed the musicians to show off their theatrical skills in a chaotic combination of gestures, speech and impassioned playing.

Notable among other novelties was Boris Berman's performance of a luxuriously abundant piano sonata by a 19-year-old Boris Pasternak - written before he dropped music to become a poet and author. But the real star was Alexander Ivashkin who, in addition to appearing in the other concerts, gave a fascinating recital of Alexander Tcherepnin's music for piano and cello. Despite Geoffrey Tozer's galumphing accompaniments, Ivashkin revealed the forward-thinking imagination of this lesser-known contemporary of Prokofiev.

fields.headline: George rebuffs exporters
fields.standfirst:
Governor refuses to cap rates despite slide towards recession

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, yesterday dismissed calls for Threadneedle Street to cap sterling's rise against the euro as a new survey showed the strength of the pound has sent manufacturing almost into recession.
fields.body:
The governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, yesterday dismissed calls for Threadneedle Street to cap sterling's rise against the euro as a new survey showed the strength of the pound has sent manufacturing almost into recession.

Manufacturers are rapidly losing orders in foreign markets, according to the latest snapshot. While industrial output continued to expand in April, the overall activity index stood at 50.6, a whisker above the 50 point which marks the boundary between output expanding and shrinking.

The new export orders index from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply fell from 52.1 in March to 47 last month, suggesting that export orders are shrinking. Firms blame the strong pound, according to the CIPS survey, while uncertainty in the car industry about Rover was reported by a number of firms to have led to weaker growth in domestic orders.

Despite the pain industry is feeling, a survey of City economists by Reuters showed that 25 out of 28 expect the Bank of England to raise interest rates by a further quarter-point when it announces the outcome of its monthly rate setting meeting tomorrow.

In evidence to a House of Lords committee, Mr George brushed aside suggestions that interest rates had been raised to damp down an overheated housing market in the southeast and without reference to the plight of manufacturing industry.

While the housing market was one of a number of indicators that the Bank's monetary policy committee monitored, it was "not anything like at the top of the list".

If anything, house prices were showing signs of stabilising, Mr George said.

The MPC did take account of the disinflationary effect of sterling's strength when setting rates but any action to rescue industry from the ravages of the strong pound would put the whole economy, including manufacturing, at risk of accelerating inflation.

"The price of attempting to deliver a lower level of sterling would be that we could not accept the mandate in relation to the control of inflation which I have to say, harsh though it may sound... is more fundamentally important to the performance of the economy."

While official figures showed last week that the economy slowed sharply in the first quarter of the year, the Bank is thought to be sufficiently worried about inflationary pressures in the labour and housing markets to risk the backlash from one further rise.

webTitle: Britons take to surf in a big way

fields.headline: Britons take to surf in a big way
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The number of people in Britain using the internet has grown by almost a fifth in the past 12 months and people are spending more time online than ever before, according to figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
The number of people in Britain using the internet has grown by almost a fifth in the past 12 months and people are spending more time online than ever before, according to figures released yesterday.

Britain's internet population increased from 7.8m in October to 9.2m in March, web tracking group MMXI Europe said. The average time spent online increased from 257 to 276 minutes a month, though that number could expect to rise sharply when the unmetered access deals now being offered start to feature in the figures.

The research also details the most popular websites in Britain, led by Yahoo.com which had 3.15m unique visitors in March, followed by MSN.com with 3.05m and Freeserve with 2.96m visits.

BBC.co.uk is ranked eighth with 1.69m unique users during the month.

webTitle: Thomson Travel plays hard to get

fields.headline: Thomson Travel plays hard to get
fields.trailText: German holiday operator C&N Touristic will decide this week whether to raise its offer for Thomson Travel, with all the signs suggesting that it will need to bid at least £1.55bn to capture the company.
fields.body:
German holiday operator C&N Touristic will decide this week whether to raise its offer for Thomson Travel, with all the signs suggesting that it will need to bid at least £1.55bn to capture the company.

C&N's indicative offer of 145p a share, worth £1.45bn, has been firmly rejected by Thomson, and a source close to the British company said yesterday: "If an offer were to be made at 150p, it would still be wide of the mark and it would not bring the company to the negotiating table."

It is understood that this hardline stance has the support of the Thomson family, who own more than 20% of the shares. C&N is thought unlikely to attempt a hostile bid.

Dubbed "the battle of the beach towels", the tussle between the two companies has been going on for nearly a month, without any formal offer on the table.

Formal negotiations have been restricted to three telephone conversations between Thomson's chief executive, Charles Gurassa, and his counterpart at C&N, Stefan Pichler. These were described by advisers as "short but amiable".

A combination of the two would create Europe's largest holiday company. Thomson's businesses include Britannia Airways and Lunn Poly travel agents.

Thomson has asked the takeover panel to impose a deadline on C&N, forcing the bidder to either "put up or shut up". The panel has stopped short of issuing an ultimatum, but has asked C&N to clarify its position as soon as possible.

A C&N source said a decision was likely within days, adding: "We are not in a hurry but we recognise a resolution is in everybody's interests."

It is understood that other European players, including the German group Preussag, have also expressed interest in Thomson.

webTitle: Market merger is good news for small investors

fields.headline: Market merger is good news for small investors
fields.standfirst:
The union of British and German stock exchanges will reduce many of the costs of trading shares in different countries, writes Money Unlimited editor Marianne Curphey

London and Frankfurt stock exchanges to merge
fields.trailText: What does the merger of the London Stock Exchange and the Deutsche Börse in Frankfurt mean to the private investor? In the short term, the small investor will not notice much difference. In the long term, there could be an opportunity to trade a variety of shares in a number of different countries without many of the barriers that exist at present.
fields.body:
What does the merger of the London Stock Exchange and the Deutsche Börse in Frankfurt mean to the private investor? In the short term, the small investor will not notice much difference. In the long term, there could be an opportunity to trade a variety of shares in a number of different countries without many of the barriers that exist at present.

The small investor needs simple, low-cost dealing. Dealing costs are still relatively high in the UK and private investors must pay stamp duty on share purchases. For UK investors, trading and holding stocks overseas is even more expensive.

Yet private share dealing has boomed within the last year. Much of this enthusiasm for stocks has been fuelled by the growth in the popularity of internet and technology stocks. Many private investors now hold shares in tech stocks whose prices are quoted on the New York-based Nasdaq exchange.

The merger between Germany and London is also likely to include a link with the Nasdaq. This would enable the small investor to trade shares across Europe and the United States via one settlement process, and possibly even using one currency.

But there are still question marks about how the new exchange will operate. The first challenge is to combine the different technologies used on the German and British markets to create an efficient trading system.

Secondly, there has been no decision made yet about whether a UK resident would be able to buy a Nasdaq stock using sterling or euros, or whether investors would still have to make their transactions in dollars and bear the risk of currency fluctuations.

There are political issues too. If a London-Frankfurt-Nasdaq link-up is successful, stock markets in countries like France, Holland and Belgium may decide to join too. Negotiations between markets and governments would take time and energy.

The good news for private investors is that today's merger may allow them to buy shares in companies outside the UK, but without the prohibitive costs involved at present. It will still be difficult for investors to research foreign companies, however, although the growth of websites providing specialist investment information is making this process easier.

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: This week I have been co-responding. This is not as racy as it may sound. Once upon a time, co-respondents were the third parties in divorce proceedings - I visualise the men in trenchcoats and trilbies and the women in those sculpted 40s hairdos and dark lipstick.
fields.body:
This week I have been co-responding. This is not as racy as it may sound. Once upon a time, co-respondents were the third parties in divorce proceedings - I visualise the men in trenchcoats and trilbies and the women in those sculpted 40s hairdos and dark lipstick.

In the tribunal you co-respond when, for example, an applicant sues both the employer and a named individual for discrimination. If the employer doesn't want to throw in its lot with the individual, they get separate representation. You and your client are then co-responding with the company and its counsel.

In this instance I am for Mr Alleged Harasser. The company is being represented by someone I suspect of being an ex-member of the Famous Five, probably Julian.

Julian is very jolly: "We won't have too much trouble with this one." Me: "You think not?" Julian: "Well, it certainly sounds like she encouraged the chaps to take a few liberties with her all that banter, showing her brassiere and so forth."

It strikes me that it is not only Julian's suit which belongs to the opening years of the recently departed century. I have already advised Mr Alleged Harasser that it is unlikely that the tribunal will accept that the applicant welcomed him putting his hand down her trousers to see if she was wearing French knickers.

Since Julian is so gung-ho about the whole thing, however, he readily agrees to cross-examine first. This means I avoid having to put most of the "You liked it really, didn't you Mrs?" questions.

And it all goes rapidly wrong for him. The applicant's counsel turns out to be a large American woman. Julian launches in: "Now, Miss Applicant, it would be right to say that you could be a bit frisky with the lads in the workplace?"

"Aaaabjection!" We are all a bit startled by this, which turns out to be applicant's counsel standard form of objection to a line of questioning.

The tribunal chair makes no move to stop these interjections, so every few minutes Julian finds his increasingly spluttery questions penetrated by a sort of nasal yowl.

The hearing doesn't finish in the day allotted to it so my client won't have to give his evidence until a resumed hearing in some months time. He's happy. I'm pleasantly relaxed. Julian is looking a bit bruised and bitter. He tells me that most of his work is construction and defamation. Maybe the chaps are more civilised in the high court.

webTitle: Is it cos I is bald?

fields.headline: Is it cos I is bald?
fields.standfirst: Why losing your hair could damage your career
fields.trailText: Forget training courses. Throw out your self-help manuals. If you want to get ahead, get a full head of hair.That's the advice from a group of German researchers, who have found that men with thinning hair are considerably less likely to get a job than their colleagues with thick, shiny thatches.
fields.body:
Forget training courses. Throw out your self-help manuals. If you want to get ahead, get a full head of hair. That's the advice from a group of German researchers, who have found that men with thinning hair are considerably less likely to get a job than their colleagues with thick, shiny thatches. If you spend more time than you would like polishing your pate, they say, there's not much point polishing up your CV. You need a trichologist, and fast.

Britain's 7.5m baldies can hardly have needed another survey to tell them that there was prejudice out there against people with thinning hair. But the extent of the disadvantage discovered by the German study is depressing for those who can't remember what it's like to peer through one's fringe. Fictitious CVs were sent to 98 personnel bosses at large companies, some bearing photos of men with hair, others with the same picture digitally altered so the man looked bald. While 41% of those with hair were invited back for interview, only 27% of those with long-since receded hairlines got the call. Slapheads may like to think they have the sex appeal of Sean Connery, but employers, it would seem, are more likely to credit them with the professionalism of Homer Simpson.

It doesn't require much scratching of the scalp to figure out what is going on. Men lose their hair as they get older, ergo men without hair are less energetic, less vigorous - and who wants to hire someone who looks old and a bit dull? "First impressions make a big difference to how people react," says Nottingham-based occupational psychologist Tony Gleadell. "It's often in the first 10 seconds or so when people make up their minds about someone."

New Labour knew it, which is one of the reasons they dumped poor Neil Kinnock. And while William Hague may have defied anti-baldie prejudice to be elected leader of the Conservative party (observant voters will have noted his rapid adoption of a skinhead to make a stab at Grant Mitchell-esque sex appeal), he must surely be a little more nervous now that the voluptuously coiffed Michael Portillo is back on the benches. Never mind the policies: get yourself a fringe.

The cheap gags may come easily, but Elizabeth Steel, founder of the Hairline support group for people with hair loss says she has contact with individuals who experience acute embarrassment and shame over their lack of hair, so she's not surprised they get a rough deal in the workplace. Hairline found that 82% of people with hair loss said they felt they had lost out professionally and personally because of their baldness. "For many people it wrecks their life at a stroke."

But chartered psychologist Ben Williams, who proudly admits to being "bald as a coot", is adamant that the important thing is one's attitude to baldness. Employers are not prejudiced so much against bald people, he argues, but against people who are reserved or embarrassed because of their baldness. "Look around at some of the people who are in the charts, and particularly some of the people who are doing very nicely in business, and think about it. It's not so much about whether a man is bald or not but how they wear it. Arthur Scargill or Jean-Luc Picard: who would you rather work with?"

Celebrity coiffeur Nicky Clarke agrees. He is frustrated by the hair hierarchy that sees balding men at the bottom of the pile. "Thinning hair is a fact of life, and there's not much you can do about it," he says. "It only becomes an issue when men look like they are trying to hide it, and let's face it, it's a pretty difficult thing to hide. In most cases it just means you cut your hair really short, and once you do that people don't seem to notice it any more." Mr Hague will hope that he is right.

webTitle: Longbridge can't bank on Britain or Byers

fields.headline: Longbridge can't bank on Britain or Byers
fields.standfirst:
Towers lacks true friends
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was said to be on the phone last week to his German oppo, Chancellor Schröder, trying to talk through an upbeat final instalment of that dismal industrial soap opera called Longbridge.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was said to be on the phone last week to his German oppo, Chancellor Schröder, trying to talk through an upbeat final instalment of that dismal industrial soap opera called Longbridge.

But it is clear now he was calling the wrong man. He should have tried Matt Barrett at Barclays or any of the other high street lenders in need of a PR pick-me-up, because it is their intransigence that now threatens to send Britain's car industry to the wall.

Despite personal appeals from Mr Blair's trade secretary, Stephen Byers, Britain's banks do not want John Towers' Phoenix consortium as a customer. They reckon the proposal, involving a £200m overdraft facility, is just too risky. So Mr Towers and his team have had to go to where the risk-takers reside, North America.

It is easy to speculate on why our banks are so leery. They, like the rest of us, have the received wisdom that Longbridge can only be viable in the long term if the management team leading the rescue does so in partnership with one of the world's fast diminishing band of motor manufacturing majors. Without this, the money and expertise to research and develop the Rover models of the future will be lacking.

The banks, it can be assumed, also suspect that the government only wants a political fix for Longbridge, one that will see it through the next election. Any sane lender will see the danger of "doing a BMW" - being the bogeyman who closes down half of the Midlands in three years' time.

But such thinking comes across as two-dimensional, especially at a time when the banking industry as a whole is being bashed for the rigidity of its approach to customers and for its failure to understand that it has social responsibilities as well as those that involve shareholders and executive incentive schemes.

Even on a purely business-driven view, the damage to the banks' profit streams caused by the abrupt and total closure of Longbridge (mortgage arrears, the cutting up of credit cards, receiverships) would seem to far outweigh the "worst case" risk scenario associated with a £200m facility for the Phoenix consortium.

In short, the high street lenders look to have turned their noses up at an extremely cost-effective public relations coup - buying favour in Whitehall and building public trust into the bargain. Goodness knows, there might even have been a gong in it for someone in the industry.

We should not really support backroom, favour-driven deals, but it would be naive to pretend either that they do not exist or do not, in certain circumstances, work for the common good. What remains unclear, however, is how our trade and industry secretary could possibly fail to sell any of this to the banks.

Mr Byers' approach to Longbridge in general and the Towers bid in particular has been puzzling - denying any knowledge of or involvement with Phoenix for several weeks when he was clearly giving it strong behind-scenes encouragement, and then privately casting doubt on its success when publicly he has come out in support of the attempted rescue.

It is assumed now that Mr Byers will lose his job at the next reshuffle. Maybe that reshuffle should come this week.

High and dry

Heard the one about the senior executives who mount a bid for a leading company only to discover the financing is not in place?

Yes, of course you have: it is par for the course in the motor car industry. But wait, the trend seems to be spreading.

The utilities sector had a bout of it yesterday when Western Power Distribution of the US announced plans for a possible offer for the Welsh water and electricity provider, Hyder.

In the morning the yet-to-be-tabled bid was to have the support of Barclays Capital. By the afternoon (just after the stock market had closed, of course) WPD had lost Barclays. What happened? If you believe some, poor old Barclays was nobbled by Nomura Securities, anxious to keep its own agreed £2.3bn bid for Hyder in contention.

Mysteriously, Barclays claims it is not working for either side and never has been. All it has been doing since Christmas has been trying to help Hyder come up with different options to help solve its crippling debt problems.

One of those solutions was to hive off its water arm by setting up a non-profit making vehicle. It was this idea that WPD used when it went public on its plans yesterday morning.

So why did Barclays originally allow its name to be used if it was not intending to participate? Better not ask. After retail branch closures and executive salaries, Barclays is finding it a little difficult communicating with the outside world.

webTitle: London and Frankfurt to unveil merger

fields.headline: London and Frankfurt to unveil merger
fields.standfirst: Link will create Europe's biggest market
fields.trailText: The London and Frankfurt stock exchanges are widely expected to announce the terms of a merger this morning in a move which would mark the crucial move in the restructuring of European share dealing.
fields.body:
The London and Frankfurt stock exchanges are widely expected to announce the terms of a merger this morning in a move which would mark the crucial move in the restructuring of European share dealing.

Members of the LSE board met yesterday evening to discuss details of the deal though, according to some sources, the main outlines of the merger have been agreed.

"It is little more than a question of dotting the is and crossing the ts," said one source.

The Deutsche Börse's board is said to have accepted the terms of the deal at the end of last week, but even if the London exchange's board has finally given its blessing, the two exchanges will have to sell the idea to their memberships.

London is in the process of demutualisation while the Frankfurt exchange was expected to take a further step towards broadening its share base tomorrow .

If the merger goes ahead as expected it will create Europe's biggest exchange, leaving Euronext - the alliance of the French, Dutch and Belgian exchanges - trailing behind.

It would increase the pressure on other exchange's to seek to join the Anglo-German grouping or risk being marginalised.

The merger terms are ex pected to involve the creation of a 50/50 joint venture to avoid criticisms that one exchange is effectively taking over the other. British and German blue chip stocks will be traded in London while growth stocks and futures will be located in Frankfurt.

Werner Seifert, the chief executive of the Frankfurt exchange will become the chief executive of the merged grouping while Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London exchange, will take on the same role in the merged entity.

The US exchange Nasdaq, which has announced its own plans for a pan-European trading platform is expected to a play a role in the new exchange's plans.

If the two European exchange's can complete their merger and bring the US exchange on board it would create a formidable player in Europe and the US as well as provide a bridgehead in the Far East where Nasdaq has recently signed a cooperation agreement with the Osaka securities exchange.

German stock market officials and senior executives from Nasdaq, including Frank Zarb, the chairman of Nasdaq's parent, the National Association of Securities Dealers, were in London for talks with the LSE yesterday.

All the traditional European exchanges are under pressure to put together alliances which would provide the framework which would allow big institutional investors to trade across borders cheaply and efficiently.

A combination of technological changes and the emergence of new exchanges has increased the pressure.

London and Frankfurt announced plans for an alliance in 1998 and six other exchanges later agreed to join.

But an eight-way deal has proved elusive, and earlier this year the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels exchanges announced their alliance -though they made it clear they would like to see others join, especially London.

Yesterday Milan and Madrid were reported to be keen to join the Anglo-German alliance while Zurich - the eighth exchange in the original cooperation programme, will also want to ensure it does not become isolated.

One crucial area will be clearing and settlement of trades. The London-Frankfurt merger is expected to exclude the German exchange's share in clearing and settlement provider Clearstream. That could prove a problem.

Big institutional players are likely to push their business towards exchanges which offer the prospect of "netting" deals off against each other - rather than having to settle each one individually - in order to cut costs.

fields.headline: Colonial sells UK life unit
fields.standfirst: Howells steps up pressure to curb social exclusion
fields.trailText: The pace of restructuring in the British life industry quickened yesterday as Australian insurer Colonial sold its UK operations for £332m to Winterthur, and Axa paid £2.4bn to take full control of Sun Life and Provincial Holdings.
fields.body:
The pace of restructuring in the British life industry quickened yesterday as Australian insurer Colonial sold its UK operations for £332m to Winterthur, and Axa paid £2.4bn to take full control of Sun Life and Provincial Holdings.

Colonial, which is the subject of a A$9.4bn (£3.5bn) takeover by Australia's second largest bank, CBA, blamed the emergence of huge insurers such as Axa and CGU for its decision to quit Britain after 120 years. It has only £4.5bn in life and pension assets in the UK, managed by 600 staff at offices in Chatham, Kent.

"There's a lot of convergence and consolidation going on in the UK and scale is essential. We didn't have that in the UK," said a Colonial spokesman. Instead, Colonial's British focus will be on its fund management business, Colonial Stewart Ivory.

Winterthur, part of the Credit Suisse group, owns motor insurer Churchill and sells mortgages and related products through its 1,000-strong chain of independently branded estate agents. The acquisition of Colonial will more than double its existing UK life and pensions business, until now centred on specialist pensions for high earners.

Colonial demutualised in Australia in 1997, creating 300,000 small shareholders among policyholders in Britain. Two-thirds have sold their shares, which have leapt in value from the initial listing price of A$2.70 to A$8.86 yesterday.

Axa, took full control of Sun Life and Provincial Holdings, paying £2.4bn to buy out minority shareholders who own 43.7% of the company. SLPH's businesses include Axa Sun Life, Axa Insurance, Axa Investment Managers and PPP Healthcare, which had total premium income last year of £5.5bn.

Axa said the takeover would enable it to exploit fully the Axa brand in Britain but admitted that its UK pensions sales fell by 16% in the first quarter of 2000. The company says it expects the market to remain tough for the rest of the year.

fields.headline: House prices rise £50 a day
fields.standfirst:
Lending figures gainsay claims that property market has peaked

More about house prices
fields.trailText: New figures showing a surge in mortgage lending and another strong rise in house prices yesterday provided further evidence of continued buoyancy in the property market, confounding those who declared it was coming off the boil.
fields.body:
New figures showing a surge in mortgage lending and another strong rise in house prices yesterday provided further evidence of continued buoyancy in the property market, confounding those who declared it was coming off the boil.

Gross mortgage lending by British banks hit £6.5bn in March, 30% up on February and the highest figure since late last autumn, said the British Bankers' Association.

The cost of the average home rose by £1,500 last month - £50 a day - to reach £80,893, according to the latest data from the Nationwide building society.

Some observers said that be neath these headline figures could be detected signs that the housing market might be starting to slow. While clearly a substantial rise, the March surge in mortgage lending was not as strong as that notched up during the corresponding period in 1999, when the increase was 38%. Last month's 1.6% increase in house prices was down slightly on February and March, when the figures were 2.2% and 2.3% respectively.

The BBA said the number of new mortgage loans approved climbed to 149,779 in March from 123,955 in February. This figure included 75,772 loans for house purchase - almost double the 39,062 achieved in January this year, and sug gesting that the spring house-buying season got off to a strong start. Remortgages and loans for home improvements and equity release made up the rest of the total.

The new mortgage figures may strengthen the argument for an increase in interest rates when the Bank of England monetary policy committee meets this week.

Nationwide said last month's 1.6% rise in house prices means the average home is now worth 17.5% more than a year ago. This annual inflation figure has risen sharply in recent months - 12 months ago the figure was 7.1%, while in December it was 13.3%. A year ago the average home cost £68,856.

The society said the market's strong run was likely to continue for another few months, fuelled by the expected con tinued strength of the economy.

"However, by late summer, as some of the momentum in the south-east reduces, price rises are unlikely to stay at current levels," said spokesman David Parry. "We would therefore expect to see a gradual slowdown in house price inflation to around 14% by the end of the year."

The current double-digit rates of price inflation are simply not sustainable given earnings growth of around 6% and general price inflation of 2.5%, according to the Nationwide.

After concern from some quarters that some lenders have been offering homebuyers too much money, the society called on homebuyers to take a "relatively cautious view" in their borrowing and said that lenders should continue to take a prudent approach and must make sure borrowers did not overstretch themselves.

The Nationwide figures came 48 hours ahead of house price data from the Halifax, which has lately been taking a much less bullish view of the market than its rival. According to the Halifax, house prices fell 0.9% in February and 0.4% in March.

The Nationwide signalled that even if the monetary policy committee did raise interest rates this week, this would do little to take the heat out of the market, and said that there is little to prevent continued house price rises.

fields.headline: Rebel without a brain
fields.standfirst:
Eminem
Brixton Academy, London
**
fields.trailText:
Eminem
Brixton Academy, London
**
fields.body:
Musicians love an audience to bring different things to and take different things away from their art: it gives them an inflated sense of their own diversity. But Eminem's two distinct types of fans have so little in common, it's hard to believe that at least one set hasn't got completely the wrong end of the Uzi. Intimidated liberals hold him up as a subversive, thought provoking, in-your-face indictment of modern America. Street kids simply buzz off his sheer nihilism.

Eminem is the ultimate symbol for the post-PC era. Were this 1990, would he have got away with inventing such a homophobic, sexist and violent persona as Slim Shady, his murderous alter ego, then repeatedly failing to argue a good case for its existence during interviews? Surely not. Today, he gets a few extra record sales from the endorsements of upper middle class, bank holiday b-boy journalists. But he'd be massive anyway, in an era when hip hop is little more than a race to be the baddest, the crudest, the most disrespectful.

Witnessing an Eminem gig is possibly the only way to recreate the danger you felt as a teenager at your first gig. It must feel like a nice little ghetto daytrip for music biz trendies, until they observe - as I did - a burly adolescent dragging his girlfriend towards the back of the venue by the scruff of her Tommy Hilfiger top, or three bouncers piling towards the moshpit with GBH in their eyes. But can you still rank it as real artistic danger when there is so little imagination involved?

Eminem is more mirror than spotlight. He's very good at reflecting the violent, apathetic mindset of America's deprived young and weaving a catchy rhyme around it, but not so good at analysing it or making waves to improve it. Yet, because he swears a lot and throws in a few up-to-the-minute, easy-to-grasp pop culture references, he probably hasn't once been compared to Vanilla Ice.

In the end, out-rapped by his on-stage sparring partner Dr Dre, his ghetto runt presence is incongruous next to the hype. If he is the subversive icon he's been held up to be, his sound and fury is somewhat counterproductive: it signifies nothing. On the few occasions when you can pick out the words, it's Slim Shady who's getting the loudest cheers.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
Moving offices
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Jason Jones, 25 managing director
fields.body:
Jason Jones, 25 managing director

I moved our company offices from London to Windsor and most of the clerical and administrative staff resigned. We had to work out a way in which the move would cause the least disruption possible. The key was in the pre-planning. We were going to make a killing out of the old property so we decided to pour money into the solution. We put all our new staff on the payroll for a month before the move and paid their travel expenses to London so they could sit with their opposite numbers and learn about the job. We also paid loyalty bonuses to our London staff so that they wouldn't jump ship before the move.

Sarah Helmore, 26 publishing assistant

If your company decides to move offices at a busy time for you, make sure the powers that be know about it and try to get the date changed. At least you have some recompense if your work suffers. I had to be quite strategic because I knew that in the general chaos I couldn't leave anything until the last minute. There was a mad scramble for boxes towards the end of the move and I saw grown men and women almost coming to blows over the last few. I managed to avoid the scrum. I did a trial run of what I could fit into a box, so rather than going to get one box at a time I picked up the 12 I needed in one go.

Tara Buckland, 31 office manager

About three years ago we moved our offices from one side of the street to the other. On Monday morning we couldn't find the IT manager's store cupboard, and eventually it turned up in the ladies' loos of our old building. Next time I'm going to keep a close eye on the the removal company. I set up a "move squad" six months before we left, where the heads of each department got together and discussed the way forward. It meant a small group were making decisions rather than having a staff free-for-all which could descend into chaos. Any squabbling over office space was done departmentally and there was a three-week cut-off point where no one could change their minds about their new space.

Richard Hunter, 32 sales director

It's worth using the disruption of an office move to think about restructuring things. When we relocated, I re-examined where people sat and reorganised the desks so that people are now grouped according to their gifts and abilities. For example, techies are now next to sales people and can work together without phoning through to another department. There were things we didn't take into consideration though, such as the size of the men's loos - which were far too small. Moving to new offices is like moving house: you've got to watch out for the estate agent speak. We were partly sold on an "air cooling system" which is nothing like air conditioning at all.

Alison May, 39 chief executive

Always over-estimate the amount of storage space you'll need when you move because it's always more than you think. I've learned through bitter experience that you should personally take all the files you're working on at the time and all your personal stuff with you when you move. I lost a box of important files I was working on for two days when I last moved offices because the removal people had put it in the wrong room. And set aside two days to move: one to clear everything out, the other to set it all up in your new space, otherwise you will spend months trying to find things and in the long term waste more time.

fields.headline: No more manic Mondays
fields.standfirst:
We have just had three bank holidays in a row - and yet the world has not ground to a halt. Matthew Taylor has a modest proposal: it is time to bring in the four-day week
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: We have just had three bank holidays in a row - and yet the world has not ground to a halt. Matthew Taylor has a modest proposal: it is time to bring in the four-day week
fields.body:
For the last three weeks we have had a tantalising glimpse of a better life. A life where balancing a demanding job and bringing up children feels not just manageable but pleasurable. Where there is time to do the odd jobs round the house, even to ask the old lady next door if she needs help mowing the lawn. The combination of a very late Easter and the May bank holiday has meant we have enjoyed three consecutive four-day weeks. The world didn't come to a standstill - far from it. Four days on, three days off simply felt much better balanced than five on, two off. Could now be the time to make the four-day week the norm?

Despite the rise in part-time work, "portfolio work" and other "non-standard" forms of employment, the five-days-a-week, eight-hours-a-day job is still the dominant model for full-time employment. In fact, average hours worked in Britain have risen over the last decade - a reversal of a 150-year trend of gradually falling working hours.

Thanks to two decades of mass unemployment, public policy has tended to focus on the availability of work. Attempts to improve the content or conditions of work have tended to be seen as jeopardising jobs. It is this that lies behind the government's grudging implementation of the Working Time Directive. But UK social democrats are out of step with their European colleagues in their lack of enthusiasm for measures to reduce hours.

Despite expectations, the implementation of the French 35-hour week has been largely successful; indeed, many French employees are moving to a week of four long days. In Holland, all workers have the opportunity to renegotiate full-time jobs on a part-time basis, and the Belgian health minister, Frank Vandenbroucke, recently spoke of "the argument for a generalised voluntary access to a four-day week", a measure that has now been inserted in public employment agreements.

While the priority for Brown and Blair is for the UK to "catch up" with the US economy, they may find many voters would rather pursue the quality of life enjoyed by the Germans, the Dutch and the Danes. The question is not whether the government will have to address the call for better work but whether it takes the lead or drags its heels.

Stephen Byers is currently chairing a cross-departmental team to examine improving the work/life balance. Byers and company need to be ambitious. Assuming the current period of economic growth continues, we can expect to see average incomes rise by 30% over the next 10 years. This gives us the opportunity to combine rising affluence with better work. It will mean a major cultural shift in the UK. Opinion polls have found that faced with the choice between more money and fewer hours, UK employees will tend to go for the money. Yet initiatives by employers committed to a better work/life balance have borne fruit. Lloyds TSB's policy of giving branch managers the opportunity to move to four long days, for example, is working for both the company and the staff. If collectively and individually we were prevailed upon to choose greater leisure over growing pay packets, the benefits across society would be immense.

Firstly, lower working hours for those in full-time work would bring more people into the labour market - some of the estimated 3m unemployed, for example, or some of the older workers currently clamouring to come back into the labour market. Ultimately, as we live longer, healthier lives, more people will want to continue in employment well beyond the official retirement age.

Secondly, families would benefit. Anyone working full time knows it is simply impossible to give enough time and energy to your children. The government recognises the contribution that parents can make to education, whether through helping young children to read or making sure older kids are going to school. But for many parents, while the spirit of good parenting is strong, the exhausted flesh is weak.

The same goes for those with other family responsibilities. How many of us would visit elderly relatives more often if only we had the time?

Thirdly, communities would be strengthened. For all its talk of communitarianism, the government has failed to go beyond anti-social behaviour orders to articulate a positive policy agenda for making communities stronger. As US sociologist Robert Putnam has shown, we are continuing to lead more isolated and private lives. Yet most people say they would like to put more back into local community life. Lack of time and general exhaustion is the most commonly heard excuse for not standing for the local school governors or attending the residents' association.

So what should be done? First, every full-time employee in a firm with over 20 staff should be given the right to have their current job on a four-day-a-week, four-fifths of salary basis, and all new full-time jobs should be advertised on these terms. Of course, the CBI and other employers' organisations will undoubtedly complain that such a move threatens capitalist civilisation as we know it. When they do they should be told, first, that similar measures are being successfully implemented in some companies in the UK and more widely in Europe with no apparent problems. Secondly, employers will get higher productivity out of workers who get three days a week to rest, recuperate and develop other forms of fulfilment and personal development.

My second proposal aims to ensure that society as a whole and not just individuals and their families benefit from a reduction in working time. The government should encourage those with more time on their hands to use it to put something back into the community. These measures could range from tax breaks, to underlining the importance of voluntary work as a relevant employment qualification. By definition you cannot force people to be active citizens, but we could certainly remove barriers and create incentives.

Perhaps the biggest weakness of my proposal is that as long as the move from five to four days is voluntary, the take up will be low. It is not only an issue of money, it is also that we live in a society in which working hard is seen as a virtue regardless of whether it makes sense. To achieve the shift to a four-day week and all the benefits that will flow from it will require opinion formers to make the case for more balanced ways of living, and more rounded ways of seeing ourselves and the contribution we make. That's why I will be asking the next meeting of the trustees of IPPR to introduce a voluntary four-day week to the Institute and why, if they say yes, I will be one of the first take up the offer.
fields.bodyText: For the last three weeks we have had a tantalising glimpse of a better life. A life where balancing a demanding job and bringing up children feels not just manageable but pleasurable. Where there is time to do the odd jobs round the house, even to ask the old lady next door if she needs help mowing the lawn. The combination of a very late Easter and the May bank holiday has meant we have enjoyed three consecutive four-day weeks. The world didn't come to a standstill - far from it. Four days on, three days off simply felt much better balanced than five on, two off. Could now be the time to make the four-day week the norm? Despite the rise in part-time work, "portfolio work" and other "non-standard" forms of employment, the five-days-a-week, eight-hours-a-day job is still the dominant model for full-time employment. In fact, average hours worked in Britain have risen over the last decade - a reversal of a 150-year trend of gradually falling working hours. Thanks to two decades of mass unemployment, public policy has tended to focus on the availability of work. Attempts to improve the content or conditions of work have tended to be seen as jeopardising jobs. It is this that lies behind the government's grudging implementation of the Working Time Directive. But UK social democrats are out of step with their European colleagues in their lack of enthusiasm for measures to reduce hours. Despite expectations, the implementation of the French 35-hour week has been largely successful; indeed, many French employees are moving to a week of four long days. In Holland, all workers have the opportunity to renegotiate full-time jobs on a part-time basis, and the Belgian health minister, Frank Vandenbroucke, recently spoke of "the argument for a generalised voluntary access to a four-day week", a measure that has now been inserted in public employment agreements. While the priority for Brown and Blair is for the UK to "catch up" with the US economy, they may find many voters would rather pursue the quality of life enjoyed by the Germans, the Dutch and the Danes. The question is not whether the government will have to address the call for better work but whether it takes the lead or drags its heels. Stephen Byers is currently chairing a cross-departmental team to examine improving the work/life balance. Byers and company need to be ambitious. Assuming the current period of economic growth continues, we can expect to see average incomes rise by 30% over the next 10 years. This gives us the opportunity to combine rising affluence with better work. It will mean a major cultural shift in the UK. Opinion polls have found that faced with the choice between more money and fewer hours, UK employees will tend to go for the money. Yet initiatives by employers committed to a better work/life balance have borne fruit. Lloyds TSB's policy of giving branch managers the opportunity to move to four long days, for example, is working for both the company and the staff. If collectively and individually we were prevailed upon to choose greater leisure over growing pay packets, the benefits across society would be immense. Firstly, lower working hours for those in full-time work would bring more people into the labour market - some of the estimated 3m unemployed, for example, or some of the older workers currently clamouring to come back into the labour market. Ultimately, as we live longer, healthier lives, more people will want to continue in employment well beyond the official retirement age. Secondly, families would benefit. Anyone working full time knows it is simply impossible to give enough time and energy to your children. The government recognises the contribution that parents can make to education, whether through helping young children to read or making sure older kids are going to school. But for many parents, while the spirit of good parenting is strong, the exhausted flesh is weak. The same goes for those with other family responsibilities. How many of us would visit elderly relatives more often if only we had the time? Thirdly, communities would be strengthened. For all its talk of communitarianism, the government has failed to go beyond anti-social behaviour orders to articulate a positive policy agenda for making communities stronger. As US sociologist Robert Putnam has shown, we are continuing to lead more isolated and private lives. Yet most people say they would like to put more back into local community life. Lack of time and general exhaustion is the most commonly heard excuse for not standing for the local school governors or attending the residents' association. So what should be done? First, every full-time employee in a firm with over 20 staff should be given the right to have their current job on a four-day-a-week, four-fifths of salary basis, and all new full-time jobs should be advertised on these terms. Of course, the CBI and other employers' organisations will undoubtedly complain that such a move threatens capitalist civilisation as we know it. When they do they should be told, first, that similar measures are being successfully implemented in some companies in the UK and more widely in Europe with no apparent problems. Secondly, employers will get higher productivity out of workers who get three days a week to rest, recuperate and develop other forms of fulfilment and personal development. My second proposal aims to ensure that society as a whole and not just individuals and their families benefit from a reduction in working time. The government should encourage those with more time on their hands to use it to put something back into the community. These measures could range from tax breaks, to underlining the importance of voluntary work as a relevant employment qualification. By definition you cannot force people to be active citizens, but we could certainly remove barriers and create incentives. Perhaps the biggest weakness of my proposal is that as long as the move from five to four days is voluntary, the take up will be low. It is not only an issue of money, it is also that we live in a society in which working hard is seen as a virtue regardless of whether it makes sense. To achieve the shift to a four-day week and all the benefits that will flow from it will require opinion formers to make the case for more balanced ways of living, and more rounded ways of seeing ourselves and the contribution we make. fields.headline: How the scandal has unfolded around the world
fields.standfirst:
Matthew Engel
MacLaurin backs amnesty
The salvage operation starts here
The ICC's points of order
fields.trailText: A country-by-country account of the accused and the accusers
fields.body:
Australia

The accused
Mark Waugh and Shane Warne accepted what they calculate as a joint sum of about £8,000 for "supplying information" to an Indian bookmaker only known as "John" during a 1994 tournament in Sri Lanka. They first admitted this to the ACB that year in order to expose a a subsequent bribe attempt from Salim Malik on Australia's tour of Pakistan. The ACB told the ICC, but requested confidentiality. After media exposes, the Australians came clean, and Waugh and Warne gave evidence as the Qayyum enquiry decamped to Melbourne. Warne and Waugh admitted they had been "naive and stupid". Few seriously suspected them of match-rigging.

The accusers
David Hookes,the former Australian batsman who exposed Australia's Indian-bookmaker links on a Melbourne radio station in 1998.

Dean Jones,the former Australian batsman who volunteered that he had been offered £50,000 by Indian bookmakers in Sri Lanka in 1992. He wonders: "What I don't understand is why my information was worth £50,000 and everyone else's supposedly around £10,000?"

A four-year cover-up after Warne and Mark Waugh admitted they had taken money from an Indian bookmaker left the Australian Cricket Board's reputation in tatters. They have since regained esteem by pressing for players found guilty of match-rigging to be banned for life, and calling for the suspension of inconsequential TV tournaments.

England

The accused
Only a purblind commitment to secrecy prevents the ECB from entering the ICC meeting boasting an entirely unblemished record. The mishandling of the Chris Lewis affair, when the ECB was more concerned with its own reputation than with protecting a potential informer, has been a disgrace. Far too long elapsed before Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the ECB, praised Lewis' "guts'' and underlined that there was no reason for him to face disciplinary action.

The accusers
Chris Lewis informed the ECB of a meeting with Ashim Kheterpal, a sports promoter, who allegedly asked him to be the middle-man in a £1m sting during last summer's Test series against New Zealand. Kheterpal named three England players who had allegedly taken bungs. The names have not been released and no evidence has been forthcoming.

Stephen Fleming, the Kiwi captain, reported a similar approach in the same series.

Lord MacLaurin successfully lobbied for an the emergency ICC meeting last month in the wake of the Cronje affair. Now he must force the issue home even if he risks strife within the ICC.

England players Adam Hollioake and Dougie Brown both reported approaches by a bookie in the team hotel during England's first appearance in Sharjah, in 1997-98.

India

The accused
Illegal Indian bookmakers and gamblers - regarded as the prime source of a decade of corruption. Bets range from match results to how many wides are bowled.

Jagmohan Dalmiya, president of ICC, who has encouraged the proliferation of televised one-day tournaments, blamed as ideal vehicles for the spread of corruption. Dalmiya has threatened to sue over allegations of irregularities in sale of TV rights.

Indian Outlook magazine made allegations against four Indian players, past and present - Mohammad Azharuddin, Aday Jadeja, Nayan Mongia and Kapil Dev. None have sued.

Jaywant Lele, Dalmiya supporter, and secretary of Indian board. Claims it is "impossible'' to fix matches.

The accusers
The Delhi police: their covert operation has already forced the sacking of South African captain, Hansie Cronje. Among several other arrest warrants issued is one for former Indian star, Ajay Sharma, currently playing near Burnley.

Inderjit Singh Bindra, ousted by Dalmiya as president of the Indian board. Accuses Dalmiya of being "in the grip of the mafia and sharks". Pressing for right to give evidence to today's ICC meeting.

Manoj Prabhakar, former Indian all-rounder, whose allegations of corruption within Indian team were described as "imaginary and unrealistic" by a retired Indian chief justice, after a cricket board investigation between 1994 and 1997. Prabhakar has now promised to assist a new Government probe by naming the team-mate who allegedly offered him £40,000 to fix a match between India and Pakistan in Colombo in 1994. The match was rained off.

Pakistan

The accused
Salim Malik - nicknamed "The Rat" - has put up no legal defence against accusations by three Australian players - Shane Warne, Tim May and Mark Waugh - that he offered them £120,000 to throw matches on their Pakistan tour of 1994. This was the start of match-rigging inquiries.

Pakistan's players were forced to swear innocence of match-fixing on the Koran after Zimbabwe's victory in the Harare Test in 1995.

Suspicions of foul play during the 1999 World Cup in England focus primarily upon Pakistan's 62-run defeat against "no-hopers" Bangladesh. Pakistan had already qualified for the final stages and none of their top five batsmen made double figures.

The accusers
Justice Mohammad Qayyum's report into match-fixing will be available in June. The findings have been widely leaked. He allegedly proposed life bans and swingeing fines for Salim Malik and Mushtaq Ahmed and suggested that Wasim Akram should be fined and stripped of the captaincy. The players have strongly denied any wrongdoing.

Sarfraz Nawaz - the former Pakistan and Northamptonshire star and political advisor, has made repeated allegations. He has demanded no mercy for those found guilty, even suggesting in his wildest moment that they should be stoned to death.

South Africa

The accused
Hansie Cronje, previously upheld as the essence of cricketing virtue, was charged by Delhi police with match-fixing last month - and world cricket could no longer ignore its deepening crisis. Cronje, after initial denials, was sacked as South African captain after conceding he had taken around £8,000 from corrupt bookmakers as a down-payment "for information'' earlier this year. Delhi police tapes concern Cronje's dealings during five one-day internationals in South Africa's one-day series in India earlier this year. Cronje's behaviour during the Centurion Test against England this year has also been questioned. He successfully persuaded England's captain, Nasser Hussain, to accept a double-forfeit of innings, and a run-chase of 240 in 72 overs, so reviving a rain-hit match seemingly consigned to a draw. England won.

The accusers
Dr Ali Bacher, chief executive of the United Cricket Board, pronounced that "the UCB and the government have been deceived". Bacher then voiced suspicions that matches in last summer's World Cup in England had been fixed. Recognises that South Africa's honour can only be satisfied by a no-holds-barred independent enquiry.

Team-mates have questioned the validity of Cronje's Centurion Test declaration. "Out of character,'' according to Brian McMillan. "Unbelievable,'' said Allan Donald. Another player has spoken of Cronje ruling in "a culture of fear".

Cronje's bizarre new-ball attack of Derek Crookes and Henry Williams in a one-day international in Nagpur is the result, according to Delhi police, of bookmaker dealings. Crookes has said he was "amazed". And South Africa's physio revealed that Williams had a torn shoulder, but played anyway; he broke down after one over.

Sri Lanka

The accused
Australia's captain Allan Border called it "the greatest heist since the Great Train Robbery". Sri Lanka, with a first innings lead of 291 and standing at 127 for two in their second innings, with only 181 required for victory, lost the first Test in Colombo in 1992 by 16 runs after collapsing in dramatic fashion. (This is the same tour where the Australian Dean Jones was offered £50,000 in a biscuit tin.) Crucially, it is known that an illegal bookmaker approached at least three Sri Lankan players around that time at the Great Chinese Wall restaurant in Colombo.

Following Sri Lanka's 1996 World Cup win, a Sri Lankan player was allegedly offered £320,000 by a bookmaker in Sharjah. He refused.

The accusers
Sidath Wettimuny, Sri Lanka's representative at the ICC meeting, now a match referee, has confirmed reports that Roshan Mahanama informed him that he had refused bookmakers' blandishments. Two other players - Asanka Gurunsinha and Sanath Jayasuriya - refused to co-operate. All pleaded for police protection. Tyronne Fernando, then the Board's president, said: "Such things were new to us then. We should have taken it more seriously".

webTitle: Time to tackle the game's points of disorder

fields.headline: Time to tackle the game's points of disorder
fields.standfirst:
The salvage operation starts here
MacLaurin backs amnesty
The anatomy of a scandal
Matthew Engel
fields.trailText: The International Cricket Council is due finally to act on match-rigging at its meeting today. These are the issues it should be tackling...
fields.body:
The International Cricket Council is due finally to act on match-rigging at its meeting today. These are the issues it should be tackling...

Betting
Should players be allowed to bet on matches in which they are participating? A ban would be hard to police but the initiative has to be taken.

Qayyum Report
Last autumn Justice Malik Qayyum, a leading Pakistani legal expert, completed his two-year inves- tigation into alleged match-rigging involving the Pakistan team. It is believed to incriminate leading players, most of whom are still playing, but has yet to be released.

Life bans
It seems astounding that anyone should consider that those convicted of match-rigging or bribery should be allowed either to continue playing or suffer only short-term penalties. Punishment here should be unequivocal. The Australians are believed to be in the vanguard pushing for life bans, although after the Warne-Waugh cover-up and paltry fines handed out they do not hold the high moral ground.

Cronjegate
The allegations against the former South Africa captain are believed to be the tip of this particular iceberg. The Delhi police, whose investigations led to his exposure, have yet to release the hours of tape recordings they insist they have of conversations involving Cronje and Indian bookmakers. They are fundamental to any ICC action.

Corruption
A proper investigation would take in not just match-rigging but the staging of tournaments, their sanctioning, the sale of television rights and sponsorship, and should include players, umpires, administrators at all levels and anyone else in a position to influence matters.

Specific matches
England's match at Centurion last winter will come under scrutiny as will South Africa's recent matches in India which brought this into the open, Zimbabwe's Test wins against Pakistan and the World Cup.

India
This country is at the centre of the illegal betting operations, has the richest of all the cricket boards and for the past three years has held the power base of world cricket. The former captain Mohammad Azharuddin is under fire for alleged match-rigging and was recently questioned by police in connection with the death of an acquaintance. Yet the topic is not on the agenda today.

Jagmohan Dalmiya
Allegations of corruption against the ICC president emerged this week, with suggestions, denied vigorously, that he was involved in hiving off money from television deals. Dalmiya is chairing the meeting, so the chances of heavy questioning are slight.

Amnesty
It has been suggested there should be an amnesty for corrupt cricketers. It is an interesting idea, but surely optimistic. Only those who suspect they are about to be unmasked are likely to come forward and, if they are already known, there is no need for an amnesty.

Tournaments
One-day tournaments are the bookmakers' lifeblood - and there are just too many of them. Restrictions have to be considered, particularly in Sharjah. This will meet with resistance, not least from Dalmiya, who has made the Indian board rich on the back of them.
