fields.headline: The salvage operation starts here
fields.standfirst:
An emergency meeting opens at Lord's today in the wake of match-rigging allegations
MacLaurin backs amnesty
The anatomy of a scandal
Matthew Engel
The ICC's points of order
fields.trailText: An emergency meeting opens at Lord's today in the wake of match-rigging allegations.
fields.body:
Lord MacLaurin is not a person to be deflected by unfavourable odds. He once persuaded his Tesco employer Lord Cohen to abandon Green Shield Stamps and the policy of piling it high and selling it cheap. But even he, as chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, must be wondering what positive outcomes can emanate from the emergency meeting of the International Cricket Council at Lord's over the next two days.

The meeting has been called at MacLaurin's behest in the wake of the allegations of corruption which have dominated cricket in the few weeks since the former South Africa captain Hansie Cronje was exposed as someone who had taken payments from Asian bookmakers in exchange for match information.

Over the years the ICC has gained a reputation as a purveyor of junkets and inaction, but this, MacLaurin said, was one issue which must be addressed without delay. The council, the governing body of international cricket, had not only to act but be seen to do so. Already, though, MacLaurin's idea has been compromised.

It was proposed to Jagmohan Dalmiya, the ICC president, that the meeting should comprise not only board presidents or chairmen but their chief executives or secretaries as well, who oversee what MacLaurin called "the day-to-day running of the ship". This has not been adopted.

The meeting will be attended by the ICC president and the president-elect, the Australian Malcolm Gray, who takes over from Dalmiya in July, chairmen from the nine test-playing countries, three representatives of the associate members, the heads of the three main ICC committees, including South Africa's Ali Bacher who can be expected to be at the forefront of discussion, and the ICC chief executive David Richards.

"It is important to address the issue of confidence in the sport," said Richards. "What we must do is assure all those people who support and love our sport that they know they can have complete confidence that every game is played in a truly competitive fashion. There can be no contrived results nor any misdemeanours perpetrated by any players."

These are grand words but the chances of any confidence emerging from the next few days are slim. The president himself has come under fire this week, with allegations from an Indian finance expert, called in by the national television station to investigate the distribution of television rights, that he abused his position to line his pockets. Dal-miya has instigated litigation.

He is certain to receive questioning on this but first the meeting has to go through an agenda, set by the president, which includes his own address, a discussion paper from Richards and then a concentration on countries other than the president's own, India, despite the belief that the power base of corruption lies there.

Cronje will be discussed at length, as no doubt will Chris Lewis, Shane Warne and Mark Waugh. The claims of Stephen Fleming, the New Zealand captain, will come up. But this is trying to treat spots with Clearasil when the patient has measles. And, as with Sherlock Holmes's dog that did not bark, it is the things that are missing which are of most significance.

Where, for instance, is Justice Qayyum's report into match-fixing in Pakistan, a painstaking document that took two years to research and is believed to contain specific allegations and recommendations for punishment against a number of cricketers - perhaps as many as seven - all but one of whom are still playing. Much to the annoyance of the judge and the cricket world at large, this has been gathering dust since its completion last autumn.

According to the Pakistan representative Yawar Saeed he cannot supply the report now because he has been asked to bring it to the full ICC meeting in July and cannot change the plan. And has Dalmiya, a man of considerable influence in his homeland, been able to obtain further details of the investigations by the Delhi police that sparked the chain of events in the first place? Has he even tried? No two pieces of evidence are more crucial to a credible meeting than these. As to what should be discussed, Cronjegate and its peripherals come first. Cronje has admitted only to that with which he has been confronted, and Bacher will be pressed to expand, not least on why there is no judge in place yet to front the promised judicial inquiry in South Africa. Sharjah, the place that many believe holds the key to much of the illicit betting and other scams, should be looked at closely, as indeed should be other venues off the beaten cricket track. Dalmiya has promoted one-day cricket vigorously, using it, he says, as an evangelical tool.

There is much in that argument. But there is too much indifferent and irrelevant one-day cricket receiving ICC sanction. On the back of official approval come sponsorship, television deals and the bookies. Where can the line be drawn?

The Australians, who kept their heads below the parapet for two years after Warne and Waugh were found out, are going to press strongly for life bans for players who are found to be involved with bookmakers in an illegal fashion.

That this should be a matter for discussion is beyond belief; it should be a matter of course. "The worst thing that could happen is that nothing comes out of the meeting. It must not be a talking shop; it must be an action shop. Whatever we decide has to be all-embracing."

It also has to be now. Next year is too late. Does the ICC have the appetite? Does it, indeed, have the teeth?

webTitle: MacLaurin backs amnesty on match-rigging evidence

fields.headline: MacLaurin backs amnesty on match-rigging evidence
fields.standfirst:
The anatomy of a scandal
Matthew Engel
The salvage operation starts here
The ICC's points of order
fields.trailText: Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, yesterday endorsed the proposed amnesty for cricketers offering information about match-rigging.
fields.body:
Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, yesterday endorsed the proposed amnesty for cricketers offering information about match-rigging.

The proposal is likely to feature high on the agenda today when the International Cricket Council holds a crucial meeting at Lord's to discuss the scandal engulfing the game.

"I've thought a lot about this and I think it is the way to go," MacLaurin said. "It's the best way to get to the root of the problem and persuade people to come forward with hard evidence and information."

MacLaurin's stance is expected to receive widespread support among ICC members and echoes demands for an amnesty made by the ICC chief executive Dave Richards, who said it might be the only way to get players to come forward.

MacLaurin added: "I'd like to say to everybody - from the president to officials like me right down to the players - that they should come forward so we can determine exactly what is going on."

Today's meeting was called at MacLaurin's request and pressure is increasing on the ICC president Jagmohan Dalmiya, who will chair the meeting, to assert the ICC's authority and take a firm stance against match-rigging.

The organisation has been accused in the past of not taking the problem seriously and not doing enough to eradicate it, despite claims from several players over the years that it is common practice.

ICC delegates are likely to discuss the drawing up of guidelines for players if approached as well as penalties against those who do become involved in match-rigging. An amnesty would represent a chance to clean the slate before such penalties come in.

webTitle: Bumbling leaders fanning the flames of crisis

fields.headline: Bumbling leaders fanning the flames of crisis
fields.standfirst:
The anatomy of a scandal
MacLaurin backs amnesty
The salvage operation starts here
The ICC's points of order
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel explains how the ICC has singularly failed to address rising crisis and offers some solutions for a cleaner game - and not for the first time.
fields.body:
For as long as anyone can remember, the International Cricket Council (ICC) has had a reputation within the game for supine uselessness. Until 1993 it was run as an adjunct of MCC, administered by the secretary in moments left free from worrying about the seats in the Warner Stand, and generally organised more casually than a well ordered village club.

When it was finally set free from the Great White Mother the ICC had two huge rows. One was over the venue of the 1996 World Cup, originally promised to England but filched by the subcontinent in a lightning coup; the other was over Jagmohan Dalmiya's right to be head of the organisation. Both ended in shifts of power away from the old dominions towards the subcontinent.

But still the reputation persisted. Two years ago the media descended on Lord's for a press conference widely trailed as the announcement of a test-match world championship. Dalmiya, by then the president, solemnly proclaimed the venue of the next Under-19 tournament and (as I recall) some minor alterations to the regulations governing no-balls. The world championship? Oh, um, yes: under consideration, a working party, very important, tell you soon...

Now there is a danger that the ICC's reputation may be changing - but not for the better. The flames of crisis are starting to singe the organisation itself. Within the past two days the focus has shifted from match-fixing to alleged kickbacks for television rights; and long-standing rumours have now been published. Dalmiya has denied wrongdoing, and issued writs. But inevitably his authority - and that of his chief executive David Richards - is damaged at the very moment when the game most needs leadership.

It is now more than five years since it became public that three Australians - Shane Warne, Tim May and Mark Waugh - alleged that they had been offered a bribe by the Pakistan captain Salim Malik to throw a test match in 1994. The fire has leapt around since then: dying down, then flaring up somewhere else (at one point almost consuming Warne and Waugh). There has been one constant: at every point the response of cricket's administrators has been to minimise the problems of gambling-related bribes: always the bucket of water, never the fire engine.

The ICC has had to take some care. It has only nine full members, all of them strong-minded and reluctant to cede any power to a central authority. The game lives in perpetual terror of m'learned friends. But the suspicion has been - and remains - that Dalmiya, Richards and others knew a great deal more than they were letting on (I should hope they did; they can't be that daft) and were refusing to level with the public. In this they were abetted by those cricket writers who wouldn't take the problem seriously. Only last week one journalist called it "a storm in a teacup". Some teacup.

In 1998 Richards promised action. The result was a grand-sounding international commission of lawyers, but empowered merely to invigilate national investigations, not to do anything. Result: more supine uselessness.

The ICC now has little more than 24 hours to start saving itself and cricket. Still it gets everything wrong. Richards has been floating the possibility of an amnesty for past miscreants. How stupid. Amnesty may well be a legitimate tactic to be used as part of a genuine attempt to uncover the truth, but first the wrongdoers have to be scared of the consequences of lying. Cricket now has more lies than leg byes.

There has to be a proper, genuine international inquiry. There has to be a proper strategy to distance the game from the gamblers. There has to be reform of the fixture list to end the dependence on worthless one-day internationals, with poor prize money and no wider resonance, designed primarily for TV and Asian bookmakers. These are the breeding grounds of corruption. I suggest instead a biennial World Cup and/or an ongoing one-day championship in which losing matches will actually matter. There has - at last - to be candour.

I'm sorry if you've heard me bang on like this over the past five years. But no one seems to have been listening.

fields.headline: Waugh earns a rise
fields.trailText: Australia's captain Steve Waugh was given a £36,000 rise yesterday to take his basic wage to £118,000 a year.
fields.body:
Australia's captain Steve Waugh was given a £36,000 rise yesterday to take his basic wage to £118,000 a year.

If he plays a full test and one-day programme next season, Waugh could earn up to £226,000. The England captain Nasser Hussain, by contrast, receives a relatively paltry £70,000 a year.

The Australians' lowest-paid centrally contracted player is believed to be the Western Australia opener Michael Hussey, who has received a £30,500 retainer. England's lowest-paid players, such as Chris Schofield, will earn a basic £20,000.

Australia have removed the veteran all-rounder Tom Moody, Brendon Julian, Adam Dale, Essex's Stuart Law and the retired Ian Healy from their list of 25 contracted players.

Nine players on the list are appearing in county cricket this season.

Australia's contracted players: Michael Bevan, Greg Blewett, Matthew Elliott, Damien Fleming, Adam Gilchrist, Jason Gillespie, Ian Harvey, Matthew Hayden, Michael Hussey, Michael Kasprowicz, Simon Katich, Justin Langer, Brett Lee, Shane Lee, Darren Lehmann, Damien Martyn, Stuart MacGill, Glenn McGrath, Colin Miller, Ricky Ponting, Michael Slater, Andrew Symonds, Shane Warne, Mark Waugh, Steve Waugh.

fields.headline: Bevan swaggers in new tie
fields.trailText:
Leicestershire v Sussex
Leicestershire 164-8
Sussex 164-9
fields.body:
Sussex have clearly decided to put all their eggs in Michael Bevan's capacious basket this season. It is a risky strategy.

The best batsman in one-day cricket has already carried his side to the quarter-finals of the Benson & Hedges Cup but he clearly needs a helping hand in the National League.

Despite another fifty from the Australian as his side pursued a modest target of 165 Sussex only managed to tie this match, with last pair Mark Robinson and James Kirtley scrambling a bye from the final delivery.

While Bevan was at the wicket Sussex were winning comfortably. They had been 133 for three and even when the Australian was fifth out at 138, with 27 required from five overs, they should have won with a swagger.

But for the second time in two days their middle and late order faltered as they approached the winning line. They needed 21 from three, 17 from two and then 10 from the last over, bowled by someone called Chris Lewis.

Lewis dismissed Nick Wilton and Umer Rashid with his second and fifth deliveries, to claim four wickets in all, and two runs were needed for victory from the last ball.

Until yesterday Bevan had not been dismissed in one-day cricket this season. He has scored 157 not out against Essex, 65 not out against Hampshire and an undefeated 52 against Gloucestershire.

But in that innings, on Sunday, Sussex lost six wickets for 10 runs to lose a match they looked certain of winning and yesterday they lost six for 30.

On a difficult pitch, on which the ball frequently stopped and where positive strokes had to be checked, most of the Leicestershire batsmen hit the ball up in the air and gave Sussex some gentle fielding practice. This was a very poor surface for this form of the game

Even the increasingly impressive Darren Stevens, their most fluent striker yesterday, chipped tamely to midwicket after hitting four fours in his 42-ball 32. His third wicket partnership of 51 with Ben Smith (19) was the highest of the innings.

After that the only belligerence came from Darren Maddy, who hit three fours in his 24 before he too hit the ball up in the air in the manner of a coach engaged in a fielding warm-up.

A more composed 39 not out from Aftab Habib gave the Leicestershire bowlers something to work with. Robinson, with four for 23, equalled his best bowling figures in this competition. But Bevan is not getting quality support.

 The South African fast bowler Allan Donald was carried off on a stretcher with a suspected broken rib after a freak accident in an English National League match yesterday. Donald, playing for Warwickshire against Hampshire at Southampton, successfully caught a skied on-drive from Australian Shane Warne but fell backwards on to the top of a wooden advertising board on the boundary as he did so.

He collapsed in agony, clutching the right side of his lower back.

1972: Retires from playing

1973 First coaching appointment with Lyn Oslo. Takes them from Third Division to First Division

1990: November - Takes over as Norway coach after two years in charge of the Olympic team

1994: Norway concede only four goals in 10 games to qualify for USA 94, their first World Cup since 1938. Their 1-1 draw at Wembley and 2-0 win in Oslo against England mean Graham Taylor's side fails to qualify. Norway eliminated after the first phase on goal difference

Joins Oslo First Division side Valerenga. Saves them from relegation with a run of just one defeat in nine games and guides them to quarter-finals of Cup Winners' Cup, losing to Chelsea. 1999: June - takes over as Wimbledon manager

2000 After a 3-0 defeat at Bradford - Wimbledon's eighth successive defeat - plunges Wimbledon into the relegation zone, Olsen is sacked by the club

webTitle: Hunt keeps Croydon on double track

fields.headline: Hunt keeps Croydon on double track
fields.standfirst: Exley 37 | C Walker 23, Hunt 65
fields.trailText: It might have been Bramall Lane rather than Wembley but the women's FA Cup final proved as contentious as any men's final of recent years.
fields.body:
It might have been Bramall Lane rather than Wembley but the women's FA Cup final proved as contentious as any men's final of recent years.

The Premier League leaders Croydon moved nearer to their second double in five years after a controversy-laden second half which saw the 18-year-old midfielder Gemma Hunt score a disputed winning goal and the player of the year Karen Walker miss a penalty for Doncaster.

Hunt, who was later carried off after falling awkwardly, saw her 65th-minute shot ricochet off both posts before Leanne Hall got a hand to it. The lineswoman Gillian Armstrong said the ball had crossed the line and, despite Doncaster protests, the goal stood.

Only a few minutes earlier Croydon's goalkeeper Pauline Cope made a fine save from Walker's well struck penalty.

"I have no problem with the goal," said Croydon's player-coach Debbie Bampton. "The referee said it was a goal. I felt we'd played the better football anyway, at least in the second half."

Doncaster flattered to deceive, their attractive passing frequently petering out in the final third. By contrast, Croydon's direct football and spirit would have been good enough to impress the manager whose teams they have most often been compared to, Tottenham's George Graham.

"I do feel we are seen as not being as attractive as other sides or perhaps simply not as fashionable," Bampton said. "But for much of the second half Doncaster did little more than hoof the ball in the air towards the strikers."

After an indifferent start by both sides Doncaster gained the upper hand. With Gill Coultard anchoring the midfield the Belles stroked the ball around, their build-ups spoiled only by their failure to exploit numerous chances. All too frequently Vicky Exley and Coultard sliced open the Croydon defence and then saw Walker and Mel Garside fire wide.

So it was a shock when Croydon went ahead. Bampton swung in a cross and Carmaine Walker rose high above the Belles defence to head firmly home. Scoring with their first shot on target galvanised Croy don and they started to show why they have dominated the league this season.

Yet Doncaster equalised 14 minutes later when a cross from Karen Walker found Exley, who headed home.

With parity re-established the game opened up. Doncaster started the second half playing the better football but, after Walker's missed penalty and Hunt's controversial goal, they became short of ideas.

"Of course I'm disappointed," Coultard said. "But the important thing is a few years ago we used to win every game four or five-nil. Now there are several teams of the same standard as us and that means women's football is becoming a more exciting and enjoyable game."

Doncaster Belles: Hall; Gomersal, Embleton, Lowe, Utley, Jackson, Thomas (Borman, 68min), Coultard, K Walker, Garside (Abrahams, 82), Exley.

Croydon: Cope, Barber, Fletcher, Hunt (Mapes, 82), Wilie, Loizou, Arnold, Bampton, C Walker, Broadhurst, Proctor.

Referee: J Frampton. (Dorset).

webTitle: Wenger hints at return to Japan

fields.headline: Wenger hints at return to Japan
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger has revealed his desire to return to Japan to manage, but not before his Arsenal contract ends in June 2002.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger has revealed his desire to return to Japan to manage, but not before his Arsenal contract ends in June 2002.

Wenger has been pursued by the Japanese Football Association to replace Phillipe Troussier as national coach when Troussier's contract runs out in the summer. Yesterday Wenger, who coached Grampus Eight in Nagoya between 1994 and 1996, made his first overtures in the opposite direction.

"I love the country and especially the people," Wenger said. "I really enjoyed my two years there as a club manager and I have already had offers to take over the national team, but I'm not ready yet. At the moment my way is clear: I'm here until 2002 and that's it. After that I don't know, but I've signed a contract at this club and I respect it."

Wenger won two national cups and the manager of the year title during his stint in charge at Grampus, and has been targeted to lead Japan's build-up to the 2002 World Cup, which they are co-hosting with South Korea.

"I'm always in touch with Japan because I kept a strong link," Wenger added. "I loved it there and I love life in England, especially with Arsenal, but you can find some qualities in Japan which you maybe have missed in England. There is 100% dedication, a respect by people for one another and a strong feeling of security."

Of more immediate concern to Wenger is his side's match against West Ham at Highbury tonight, when an 11th consecutive win will guarantee Arsenal's place in Europe next season.

Arsenal will be without the French striker Thierry Henry, while Harry Redknapp's injury woes deepened yesterday when Rio Ferdinand, Neil Ruddock and Frank Lampard joined a lengthy list of casualties.

"It is quicker to say who isn't injured," West Ham's manager said. "Rio is struggling with an ankle problem and Frank has ligament damage, so it will be a miracle if he plays again this season. Neil has a foot problem and I'm just trying to find 11 players and fit them into positions as best I can."

West Ham's hopes of signing Frédéric Kanoute were set back yesterday when Lyon, who loaned the French striker to Upton Park until the end of the season, quoted a price of £6.25m. Redknapp had been expecting to pay about £4m.

The Sheffield Wednesday defender Des Walker is expected to join West Ham at the end of the season.

fields.headline: Olsen lashes players after sacking
fields.standfirst:
Olsen factfile
Olsen's record
Bradford 3 - 0 Wimbledon
fields.trailText: A furious Egil Olsen turned on his players and predecessor yesterday after being sacked by Wimbledon after only 11 months. As his disastrous reign was brought to an end, the Norwegian branded his team "disloyal" and virulenty castigated Joe Kinnear.
fields.body:
A furious Egil Olsen turned on his players and predecessor yesterday after being sacked by Wimbledon after only 11 months. As his disastrous reign was brought to an end, the Norwegian branded his team "disloyal" and virulenty castigated Joe Kinnear.

Olsen's tactics, personality and managerial style have been criticised almost from day one, not least internally. After an eighth straight defeat at Bradford on Sunday John Hartson called for a change of manager. Beforehand Kinnear had delivered a withering attack. As Olsen headed for the exit with the club in the relegation zone, he bit back.

"I thought I would see out the season," he said, "but there has been disloyalty from players. The comments from Joe Kinnear didn't help my case. I would never do what he did and criticise a manager before a crucial game. It is bad timing but that's the culture of English football."

It was the unique culture of Wimbledon - with its brashness and anarchy - that the quiet, regimented Olsen struggled to come to terms with. He looks a victim of player power and in a desperate attempt to stay up the club have turned to one of the old-style Crazy Gang. Terry Burton, with 12 years' service as coach and technical director, steps in for the last games at home to Aston Villa and at Southampton.

He will enjoy the bond and respect Olsen never seemed to manage. The former Norway manager's long-ball style was supposed to be tailor-made for Wimbledon but the intricacies of his rigid 4-5-1 system, with its zonal marking, left a queue of disillusioned squad members. Many of his imports failed to integrate, Hartson said. Spirit appeared to drain.

Carl Cort complained that he was deployed in a wide role which did not maximise his strengths. Michael Hughes, arguably the squad's most inventive talent, found his lack of height and perceived defensive weakness counted against him. Those two, and others, are expected to leave .

"The one thing I blame myself for is that I never managed to impose my style on the team," Olsen said. "I have been criticised for my way of playing football but I never managed to implement that ... I would have felt really depressed if I had managed to implement what I believed in and still failed but I don't feel as bad as that now."

It is tempting to heap some blame for that on the players. Having struggled to master the system at first, it appeared a few decided it was not to their liking and lost heart. Olsen never enjoyed the faith which helped him at home.

"Egil's skill has always been his system of playing," said Wimbledon's chairman Bjorn Rune Gjelsten. "The great difference is that in Norway there has been a natural respect for Egil through the results he created. Out here it is a different ball game."

The captain Kenny Cunningham was flattering in his assessment of Olsen, though the club's decision to ban all other players from talking hinted at different obituaries. "We have to look at ourselves," Cunningham said, "before we point accusing fingers."

Gjelsten insisted the media had put Olsen under great pressure. But he accepted he and his business partner Kjell-Inge Rokke should have bought out Sam Hammam on day one, rather than taking 80%. "There has been a lack of focus and clarity," he said. "Had we been closer to the club we might have done a few things differently."

Olsen, their appointment, was removed after a late-night meeting on Sunday. Burton, 47, was coaching at Arsenal at 22, spent 5 years as Kinnear's assistant and was most recently academy director. He will be assisted by Mick Harford and Stewart Robson.

Yesterday Burton made all the right noises. The last two games would be won, he said, and the spirit was excellent. His role will be reassessed in the summer but already the former Wimbledon players Hans Segers and John Fashanu have expressed interest.

Kinnear has also been mentioned, though a return would surely depend on the club staying up. For Olsen it seems management is over. "It looks now that I don't think I will manage a team again," he said. "I'm somewhere between maybe and no, with the emphasis on no."

 John Hartson allegedly instigated a fight with Bradford's Stuart McCall in the tunnel before Sunday's game. Hartson, later sent off for foul and abusive language, "started to fight" and was acting "pretty wild," according to Bradford's Gunnar Halle. It is thought McCall was kneed in the stomach. The referee Jeff Winter broke up the fight and if it is included in his report Hartson is likely to be charged by the FA.

fields.headline: Turks tempt Zola with £3m
fields.trailText: Gianfranco Zola may leave Chelsea in the summer after receiving a staggering £3m tax-free offer to play in Turkey.
fields.body:
Gianfranco Zola may leave Chelsea in the summer after receiving a staggering £3m tax-free offer to play in Turkey.

Although the little striker is playing well enough for Gianluca Vialli to want to keep him at Stamford Bridge for the two years left on his contract, the manager may decide not to stand in the way of his 33-year-old compatriot receiving one last huge payday and include him in his planned summer shake-up of playing personnel.

The staggering two-year offer to Zola has come from Fenerbahce of Istanbul. According to reports in Italy, Zola is giving the offer serious thought.

webTitle: Wembley redevelopment on brink of collapse

fields.headline: Wembley redevelopment on brink of collapse
fields.trailText: Brent Council have admitted that the Wembley Stadium development - the cornerstone of the 2006 World Cup bid - is once again on the brink of collapse.
fields.body:
Brent Council have admitted that the Wembley Stadium development - the cornerstone of the 2006 World Cup bid - is once again on the brink of collapse.

A report into the Wembley planning application will be released by the council next Tuesday, with a final decision on its acceptability due to be made on May 15.

It is already widely known that officers have recommended that the application is rejected because adequate funds have not been put in place to ensure the local transport network is capable of carrying the increased number of people using the complex.

A meeting between all interested parties last month held open the possibility that the problems could be resolved, so Brent agreed to defer the report's release to give time for formal financial assurances to be made.

However, council leader Paul Daisley tonight confirmed that none of the parties - including Wembley - had been in touch and unless there was any movement in the next week, the application is doomed to failure.

Daisley has advised his officers to write to the relevant bodies and treat the matter with absolute urgency.

"Once the report is released, it would be very difficult to go against the officers recommendations without good reason," said Daisley. "We have a legal duty to respond to the planning application and we can't hold it up forever.

"At the very least we need something substantial enough to allow the final decision to be put back from May 15. As it stands, the report is very clear and the application will be rejected."

It is believed that Brent have adopted their hard-line stance because of work they were promised on the Wembley Park tube station for Euro 96 which wasn't carried out as they had hoped.

But, while they are anxious not to be seen as the bad guys in the whole saga, they reject the notion that they are involved in game of brinkmanship just to secure extra funding.

"The idea that we are the awkward squad is dispelled if you look at the facts," said Daisley. "You are talking about a stadium which is in operation, on average once a week. I don't think anyone would particularly like 50 coaches driving past their front window and I don't think it is too much to ask that this volume of traffic be directed away from residential areas.

"The complex as it is proposed reduces the number of car-parking places available, despite increasing the capacity of the stadium, so we need to have a public transport mechanism capable of coping with the extra volume."

Wembley are confident that they can supply a written acknowledgement of their side of the bargain but what both sides are agreed on is that ditching the whole proposal and touching up the present stadium will not be considered.

"It is not an issue," said Wembley spokesman Chris Palmer. "Wembley would then become the third biggest stadium in the country, which would under the circumstances would not be appropriate.

"As far as we are concerned, a deal was struck on April 20 between ourselves and the government which has put the infrastructure problem back in its box. We expect that deal to be honoured."

Brent have acknowledged that Wembley have shifted their position significantly from the early stages of their application.

However, if there is no end to the impasse, which appears to centre around the amount of cash central government are willing to put into the scheme, there is little doubt the planning committee will go along with their officers' recommendation and reject the application. That would immediately mean a one-year delay in the project as Wembley have already stated that they would appeal against the decision. And, coming less than two months before FIFA decide which country will host the 2006 event, it could hardly be timed worse.

"When you talk to people who have visited Wembley, they enthuse about the experience of visiting the stadium but complain that it has taken them three hours to get there and three hours to get out again," said Daisley.

"There is no point building a world class stadium and finding that you have a 1920s transport system. We must ensure that the road, rail and tube links meet the requirements not only of people visiting Wembley but also of those who have to live here."

fields.headline: McCall speaks up for Hartson
fields.trailText: Bradford captain Stuart McCall today cleared Wimbledon striker John Hartson of any physical violence during an alleged tunnel bust-up at Valley Parade on Sunday.
fields.body:
Bradford captain Stuart McCall today cleared Wimbledon striker John Hartson of any physical violence during an alleged tunnel bust-up at Valley Parade on Sunday.

Hartson was believed to have attacked McCall as the two teams lined up in the tunnel before City's vital 3-0 victory over their relegation rivals - and in full view of referee Jeff Winter.

The Football Association were today awaiting the Stockton official's report, although it is believed the Welsh international will still face disciplinary action.

But McCall's comments could ultimately now help Hartson - later dismissed during the game for abusing linesman Alan Sheffield - escape serious sanctions.

"John Hartson was trying to wind up his own team, and I think he got carried away a little bit," said McCall.

"He was obviously psyching himself up for the match and trying to get the old Wimbledon 'Crazy Gang' spirit going.

"It must have been frustrating for him to see the club where they are near the bottom of the table, especially because he had been out injured for four months.

"It was mainly him trying to get the team going, but we have experience in our side not to be intimidated by that sort of thing.

"I admit the dressing-room corridor at Valley Parade is so narrow that the players are bound to be close to each other as they line up before they go on to the pitch.

"But there was no physical contact between the players, just a lot of shouting - and the referee wanted him to be quiet. I think he Winter just wanted to get the players out on to the field as quickly as possible."

Two hotly disputed Peter Beagrie goals - the second of which was immediately followed by Hartson's red card - helped Bradford on their way to a crunch win which was rounded off by Dean Windass' 10th of the season.

It also sparked Egil Olsen's sacking less than 24 hours later, but Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond has revealed Wimbledon's crisis will not distract his club from their "life-and-death battle" for Premiership survival.

The Bantams' fate is now in their hands, although Olsen's departure could prove the tonic the nosediving Dons need going into their last two games of the season following a harrowing run of eight straight defeats.

With Wimbledon now in the bottom three for the first time this season, it has prompted a number of old boys - Vinnie Jones, John Fashanu and Lawrie Sanchez - to offer their help to save the club from the drop.

Wimbledon are at home to Aston Villa on Saturday and then face Southampton at The Dell on the final day of the season, while Bradford travel to Leicester before hosting Liverpool.

Richmond said: "It's now become a two-game season - just nine days in May. But we will not be distracted by matters we cannot control. What happened at Wimbledon is an internal matter and of no concern to us.

"For the first time our situation is now in our hands, and if we win both games then it doesn't matter what anybody else does.

"There is this belief that we can do it - no matter what people say - because we have always been positive at all times. What is happening has grabbed people's imagination. It's become a classic life-and-death battle - it's what we are in the game for."

City boss Paul Jewell, meanwhile, will again take his team away in the build-up to the game at Filbert Street as they look to avoid all the attention and hype surrounding the match.

Jewell will tomorrow head to the same secret retreat Bradford visited last week in the hope it proves an omen as they look for the win which could preserve their top-flight status.

fields.headline: Swindon boss Quinn sacked
fields.trailText: Former Northern Ireland striker Jimmy Quinn has paid the price for taking the Robins into the Second Division in his first full season in charge.
fields.body:
Jimmy Quinn has been sacked as boss of Division One basement club Swindon.

The former Northern Ireland striker has paid the price for taking the Robins into the Second Division in his first full season in charge.

In his time as boss, Swindon managed just eight wins in 45 games and the club, who have been propping up the First Division for much of the season, were relegated after defeat at Stockport on Easter Monday.

Assistant manager Alan MacDonald takes temporary charge of the club for their final game of the season against Sheffield United on Sunday.

fields.headline: Augenzeuge
fields.standfirst: Eva Finger took her four-legged friends to Turkey and Taiwan to save earthquake victims
fields.trailText: Eva Finger took her four-legged friends to Turkey and Taiwan to save earthquake victims
fields.body:
Seit 1991 bin ich Mitglied der Rettungshundestaffel. Ich habe vorher schon viel mit Hunden gearbeitet. Doch dann wollten mein Mann und ich mehr mit den Tieren machen, als nur Sport. So kamen wir zur Einsatzgruppe. 1999, innerhalb eines knappen halben Jahres war ich mit meiner Hündin Yuppi" zweimal in der Türkei und einmal in Taiwan um nach dem Erdbeben die Suche nach Verschütteten zu unterstützen. Um schnell an den Einsatzort zu kommen, hat mir das Innenministerium einmal sogar einen Hubschrauber geschickt.

fields.headline: Lord, Loud and Lucky
fields.trailText: VIN IT TO WIN IT
fields.body:
VIN IT TO WIN IT

"I'm here. And I can save you." Not the words of the son of God, but Vinnie Jones who wants to return after 40 days in the wilderness (well QPR and Hollywood) to lead Wimbledon to the promised land of Premiership survival. According to Vinnie, "Terry Burton is a nice bloke, and has a good soccer brain, but he is a natural number two, not the type you need to lead at this stage." So who, pray, is the right man for the job? Why it's Vinnie (although Roy Kinnear and Fash can help out if they want).

The Fiver, like the other 172 Dons fans around the world, is ready to believe him, but we need evidence of miracles before we commit our souls. Vinnie decides to talk tactics. "I would recall Neil Ardley," he says pointing the finger menacingly in a Presbyterian minister-like way. "Surely not the same Neil Ardley who played on Sunday?" wonders the Fiver, cowering in the corner. "And I would get Michael Hughes, Carl Cort and Jason Euell in the side." But didn't they all play on Sunday as well, oh holy one? "And I would put Marcus Gayle centre-half to combat Dion Dublin against Aston Villa." Err praise be to God, we are convinced!!!

Remembering that it is easier for a camel to pass through an eye of a needle than a rich man to enter the kingdom of heaven, Vinnie has even offered to take a pay cut: "I'd take £200,000 as thanks." Furthermore, he seems to have the support of the players: "John Hartson phoned me and said the players would love it," he reveals. But a dour-faced club spokesman has poured cold water on the whole idea. "Vinnie Jones has already named his price for coming as manager. In contrast Terry Burton never mentioned money once when he was offered the job. Vinnie would be better served concentrating on his showbiz career rather than exploiting the situation at the club he claims still to care about." Vinnie, the man needs more convincing. Work those miracles!

SPURRED INTO ACTION

Les Ferdinand could be forgiven for needing a sit down after all the activity at White Hart Lane today. The permanently crocked Spurs striker would not have been chuffed to have limped down to the newsagents this morning and found that "£10m Rebrov says yes to Spurs". But barely had the technically questionable forward had chance to digest the imminent arrival of one of Europe's top strikers before David Pleat came out and to reveal that "Nothing has been finalised yet." So what, Les may have muttered as he scuffled back to his flat, is going on?

It seems that the most plausible way of looking at events is this. Spurs, again without manager George Graham, produce a poor performance at home. Their fans decide to complain, for once in their lives, and hang around the ground demanding Alan Sugar goes back to Chigwell (he was in Miami at the time). At the same time crucial contract negotiations with club captain Sol Campbell and top scorer Steffen Iversen are approaching. 48 hours later and one of the hottest properties in Europe is on his way to a club that won't be in Europe next season.

So either Alan Sugar has pulled off the transfer coup of the summer, or somebody's making something up. Who knows which is true (apart from Internazionale, AC Milan, Arsenal and Real Madrid, all of whom are in the chase for Rebrov)? But let's face it, it's about time Sugar got a break. As spokesman Pleat said today: "It is not true that we are reluctant spenders." Indeed. "We do want to invest in quality players but our problem in the transfer market has been selling. We have struggled to move on some of the moderate ability that was brought to the club a few years ago." Shame on you, Sir Les.

BOO TO A GUUS

After weeks of speculation it looks like the Bonny Bowler-hatted Bhoys of Celtic could have landed their dream managerial candidate. Yes, former Real Madrid and Dutch national coach Guus Hiddink is now available to take over the reins of Parkhead. Because he's been sacked by Spanish relegation candidates Real Betis.

In a move that brought joy to every hooped-sweater-wearer in Glasgow (apart from the city's burglars, who may or may not care less), Betis gave Hiddink the boot today after a two-month spell at the club. In this time the Dutchman promised European qualification and effectively achieved the opposite - winning only one match in 13 league games. Betis have yet to announce Hiddink's replacement, presumably feeling that anyone, or indeed no one, is as good as Guus.

Hiddink has been the long time favourite for the manager's (whipping) post at Celtic. He is thought to have the qualities that will enable the Bhoys to compete with Dick Advocaat's Rangers: ie an in-depth knowledge of Dutch players who can be bought on the cheap. After today's developments it appears that the only thing hindering Hiddink's move to Glasgow is his reportedly sizeable contract demands. But why let that stand in the way?

Newcastle are set to revive their interest in Velez Sarsfield midfielder Christian Bassedas. The deal for the South American star was aborted earlier this year when Robson was unable to raise the £3.6m transfer fee.

Gianluca Vialli says he will buy British from now on. Chelsea are thought to be interested in Jamie Redknapp, Robbie Fowler, Frank Lampard and Trevor Sinclair, Andy Cole and Richard Wright.

Des Walker will leave Sheffield Wednesday at the end of the season. West Ham are likely to repeat their £1.5m offer from earlier this season and Charlton, Manchester City and Coventry are also interested.

NEWS IN BRIEF

John Hartson could be charged with misconduct by the FA after he was allegedly involved in a scuffle with Bradford midfielder Stuart McCall in the tunnel before Wimbledon's 3-0 defeat at Valley Parade on Sunday.

Liverpool and Reebok have signed the biggest kit sponsorship deal in the Premiership, worth £21m over the next three seasons.

David Ginola has denied claiming that he has wasted the best years of his career by playing in English football. "I've never said that I was wasting my time playing in the English Premiership. I am very grateful that I play in one of the strongest leagues in the world. I loved the time I played at Newcastle and I love it at Tottenham."

Joe Royle has been named Nationwide manager of the month for April. Burnley's Stan Ternent won the Division Two award, while Kevin Wilson of Northampton was named the top Division Three manager.

Nicholas Anelka will start for Real Madrid in their Champions League semi-final against Bayern Munich tomorrow, because Fernando Morientes is injured.

webTitle: Hague's outbursts could pay off - in the short term

fields.headline: Hague's outbursts could pay off - in the short term
fields.trailText: William Hague has succeeded, with two carefully timed speeches, to dominate the entire political landscape over the past two weeks.
fields.body:
William Hague has succeeded, with two carefully timed speeches, to dominate the entire political landscape over the past two weeks.

Tory spinners are delighted with the blanket coverage they have won for their leader's provocative interventions on asylum seekers and on the farmer Tony Martin so soon before the spring elections.

His outbursts are likely to pay dividends when the Tories regain the safe seat of Romsey in Thursday's by-election and when they notch up local election successes around the country.

Tory shadow ministers will pop up on Friday morning to claim they have recovered from the trauma of 1997 and they are now on course for a strong performance in the general election.

However, Tories will privately know that any victories this week will show that the party is merely consolidating its core vote and is a long way from reaching out to the broader electorate who will decide the next election. The Tories should win Romsey with no effort because it is one of the party's safest seats, while Conservatives are bound to do well in the council election because Labour and the Liberal Democrats are defending seats they won at the height of the Tories' unpopularity in the mid 1990s.

It is against this background that Mr Hague has spoken out in the past few weeks as he panders to his party's core supporters with threats to lock up all asylum seekers and rally to the defence of the likes of the farmer Tony Martin.

The Tory leader denied today that he was lurching to the right, declaring that he was appealing to the "common sense" values of ordinary voters.

"These are not right-wing themes," he told Radio 4's Today programme as he prepared to travel down to Romsey. "Labour voters, people who voted Liberal in the past are saying to me these are the sort of things which we should be raising. We must not be browbeaten out of raising this subject because other people want to distort the way we raise it."

However, the Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy used a campaign speech in Romsey last night to round on Mr Hague for his opportunism in recent weeks. "He will stand anywhere for a favourable tabloid headline," Mr Kennedy said.

His speech may not sway the voters of Romsey, but the wider electorate are more likely to identify with Mr Kennedy's criticism.

webTitle: Police hunt racist gang after black man is set on fire

fields.headline: Police hunt racist gang after black man is set on fire
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Police are hunting three white men who yesterday sprayed a 24-year-old black man with inflammable fluid and then set him on fire in a racist attack in Birmingham.
fields.body:
Police are hunting three white men who yesterday sprayed a 24-year-old black man with inflammable fluid and then set him on fire in a racist attack in Birmingham.

The victim, who has not been named, was also subjected to racist abuse in the incident.

He suffered 10% burns to his face and right arm and is in intensive care at the city's Selly Oak hospital where his condition was described yesterday as stable.

Det Chief Insp Neil James, of West Midlands police, described the attack as "sickening" and appealed for witnesses.

The three assaulted the man as he walked home at about 1am along a dual carriageway near the Royal Orthopaedic Hospital in the Northfield district south of the city centre. He managed to stagger to the home of his girlfriend and was then taken to hospital.

"There appears to be no motive for the attack apart from the fact it was racially motivated," said Mr James. "It was a particularly vicious attack aggravated by the fact that the victim was abused verbally prior to being set alight.

"He is in hospital under sedation. Unfortunately, we have not been able to interview him due to the nature of his injuries.

"It was a vicious, unprovoked attack, which quite frankly is very sickening. It would appear he was walking home after visiting a friend when he was attacked by three men. One of them sprayed a substance in his face and set it alight."

Forensic tests are being carried out to discover what liquid was used in the assault.

webTitle: Film Council aims for the reel thing

fields.headline: Film Council aims for the reel thing
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited editor Xan Brooks looks at the latest shake-up in the British movie industry
fields.trailText: Film Unlimited editor Xan Brooks looks at the latest shake-up in the British movie industry.
fields.body:
Don't look now, but there's another shake-up taking place inside that ongoing Ealing-esque comedy otherwise known as the British film industry. Today sees the launch of the Film Council, spearheaded by Alan Parker, John Woodward and Four Weddings producer Duncan Kenworthy. Its mission: to streamline our homegrown industry and make it more business savvy. Its victim: the widely reviled and discredited scheme of funding pictures via the National Lottery, which has recouped only one-tenth of the £105m it has sunk into domestic film production.

The council will command an annual budget of £22m. The bulk of that will be funnelled into pictures it regards as having definite commercial potential, with the odd million or two set aside to develop scripts and train budding screenwriters. The aim is to steer well clear of the sort of oddball, no-name, small-scale projects that traditionally go belly-up at the box office. Big budgets, big returns - this is what the council is angling for. "One of the truisms of the film business is that the more money a film costs to make, the more it is likely to make," insists Kenworthy. "No none wants to make a film that is only seen by the film-makers, their families and the crew."

Kenworthy makes a fair point, though I rather feel he is missing someone out. Spare a thought for the hapless film reviewer, who must traditionally attend and review even those pictures that nobody is likely to see. Spare a thought, in other words, for me. The Guardian today lists the lottery hall of shame as Stephen Poliakoff's Food of Love, The Secret Laughter of Women, Los Angeles Without a Map, The Last Yellow, A Kind of Hush and The Slab Boys. All were pieced together on hefty lottery funds, all bombed spectacularly, and all (with the blissful exception of the Poliakoff film) have been seen by yours truly. Yes, some of them were flat-out terrible and some merely misconceived. Needless to say, I wouldn't hurry back to revisit any of them.

And yet will the council's output really be any better? Presumably, Kenworthy et al would hold Four Weddings and Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels up as examples of the sort of British movies they are looking for, even though I found each, in its way, just as objectionable as the likes of The Last Yellow (and heaps more cynical). The suspicion in some quarters (these quarters) is that great British films do not come out of any corporate structure or prevailing ideology so much as slip the net. The award-winning Ratcatcher was funded by lottery money and East is East was not. Both, though, stand proud as the best British films of the past 12 months.

The one consolation the council offers is that the years ahead will see more money being ploughed into fewer British films; the non-commercial follies weeded out in favour of the test-marketed corporate produce. But for some reason, this isn't as comforting as it should be. The implication is that equally duff films will be spread just a little thinner on the ground. In the end, the council's scheme calls to mind that old Woody Allen joke about two Jewish women at a Catskill retreat. "The food here is absolutely terrible," says one. "Yeah," says the other. "And such tiny portions too."

Today sees the launch of the Film Council, spearheaded by Alan Parker, John Woodward and Four Weddings producer Duncan Kenworthy. Its mission: to streamline our homegrown industry and make it more business savvy. Its victim: the widely reviled and discredited scheme of funding pictures via the National Lottery, which has recouped only one-tenth of the £105m it has sunk into domestic film production. fields.headline: Big spenders par excellence
fields.standfirst: British embassy in 'expensive' Paris tops entertainment budget ahead of Washington and Tokyo with bill of £293,125
fields.trailText: The British embassy in Paris, a former palace on the exclusive Rue du Faubourg St Honoré near the Champs-Elysées, is one of the splendours of the French capital. So too is its entertainment budget.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Rob Evans  and  Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
The British embassy in Paris, a former palace on the exclusive Rue du Faubourg St Honoré near the Champs-Elysées, is one of the splendours of the French capital. So too is its entertainment budget.

The embassy spent £293,125, which buys a lot of canapes and wine, in the last financial year. It is the biggest-spending British embassy, its entertainment budget higher than Washington, Tokyo and Moscow, the centres of world political and economic power.

Opposition MPs questioned yesterday if the spending was a reflection of France's historical importance rather than a reflection of its position in the present world.

Previously unpublished Foreign Office figures obtained by the Guardian reveal that Paris topped the entertainment league table of British embassies in 1997-98 and 1998-99 followed by Tokyo, New York, Brussels and Washington. The top 15 embassies in the entertainment league spent about £2m in the last financial year.

The Foreign Office minister, Baroness Scotland, said: "All such expenditure is, of course, to promote UK interests: winning support for our policies and products from businessmen, politicians, the media and other decision-makers."

One of the diplomats at the Paris embassy, Tim Livesey, was unapologetic: Paris was expensive."You try entertaining 16,000 in Paris as opposed to doing so in Abu Dhabi."

The embassy hosted visits for ministers, provided candle-lit dinners for French politicians and opinion-formers, and held parties and receptions, mainly to help provide a showcase for British products.

Mr Livesey said: "If you are in Washington, you are looking at a political kind of market. In New York, you are looking at movers and shakers. In Los Angeles, it is the movie industry."

But in France, if you wanted to influence people, "you did it in Paris because it is a very centralised country. When you entertain, you entertain the whole of France".

Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman, said: "It seems how much they spend depends on how much they spent in the 19th century rather than its importance in the 20th century, never mind the 21st."

In the past, the Paris embassy would have concentrated on gathering political intelligence and trying to influence opinion. Mr Livesey said that had changed in favour of the commercial side.

Last year, the embassy and the residency had hosted 50 special events, including promotion of such things as British fabrics. British cheese was served on all occasions at the embassy and British wine much of the time.

After unfavourable publicity in the mid-1990s about diplomats overseas enjoying a seemingly extravagant lifestyle, the Treasury tightened up on spending.

The latest figures appear to show spending is down in Tokyo, New York, Madrid, Rome and Geneva. The Paris embassy's expenditure rose over the same period, though only marginally. More importantly, its spending was down dramatically from 1993-94 when it spent £331,000 in entertainment.

Regulars at embassy events have noticed little difference. The Foreign Office itself admitted the reduction was not as dramatic as the figures suggested, saying there were various factors at play, such as the high pound working in favour of the embassies.

A dramatic example of currency fluctuations was in Moscow, where spending on entertainment dropped from £126,243 in 1997-98 to £83,455 in 1998-99 due to the decline in the value of the rouble.

Brussels also saw a substantial drop, from £240,320 to £184,071. New Delhi, the fourth highest in 1997-98, spending £134,091, dropped out of the top 15 last year.

The Foreign Office has 223 overseas posts, and 5,635 staff, of whom 2,295 are based overseas. In addition, there are 7,841 local staff. Paris in the mid-1990s employed 89 staff, including four footmen, a butler and a gardener, as well as 142 local staff. Mr Livesey said this had been cut back to a total of about 160.

Paris's entertainment rival is Washington where the ambassador, Sir Christopher Meyer, formerly prime ministerial spokesman for John Major, has made it an important part of the Washington social scene. Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones were the star attractions as the ambassador's ball.

The embassy claims to have had 14,500 visitors in the past year, increasing the costs while keeping the numbers down. Sir Christopher thought the term entertaining was misleading: "Entertaining is not really the right word. It's also about creating networks of influence so that, when you need to, you have easy access to people whose decisions can affect British interests for better or worse. Our network at the British embassy has paid off repeatedly to Britain's benefit. That's the way Washington works."

The Foreign Office complains privately that the image of diplomats having a good time means that they have had to pare down spending and usually it is the embassy buildings that suffer, with insufficient funds for renovation.

But Mr Taylor remained unimpressed, especially with the claims that spending on entertainment had been tightened up. "It may have tightened a little but not as much as the stomachs have grown."

Top 15 Biggest spenders 1998-99

Paris £293,125

Tokyo £221,711

New York £196,446

Brussels £184,071

Washington £112,645

Hong Kong £103,573

Bonn £101,809

Geneva £100,470

Peking £100,150

Vienna £97,049

Moscow £83,455

Madrid £83,111

Rome £79,936

Seoul £71,009

Buenos Aires £68,408

fields.headline: Language learning
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor on what's out there in the world of languages
fields.body:
Considering the web's potential for language learning, it's astonishing that most year 11 pupils will be turning to costly books when they tackle GCSE revision. Wouldn't it be better to simply click on a French phrase and hear it pronounced by a native speaker?

You can do this at the Fodors website in French, Italian and Spanish, and the vocabulary is highly practical and therefore suited to KS3-4, even if it doesn't exactly match the syllabus and curriculum requirements.

The BBC's online languages revision service is closely tied to curriculum requirements and is highly impressive.

Nonetheless, the web has yet to embrace full-scale language courses - chiefly because they are expensive to produce well, and specialists such as Linguaphone show no inclination to move their profitable tuition online. BBC Worldwide does back up its Talk series for adult learners with photocopiable teachers worksheets to download but well before the internet became a mainstream medium, Call (Computer-Assisted Language Learning) dominated the agenda.

Inevitably, Call is about software - whether it is downloaded from the net or bought in disk or CD-Rom format. It seems unlikely that Call will survive very long wherever the internet is freely available. Sussex university academic Matthew Platts maintains a useful page that points to downloadable language-learning software elsewhere on the net (including Chinese and Arabic fonts). Some of it is free. Unfortunately, he only lists software for PCs; if your computer is a Mac, try Jacek Iwanski's dedicated page.

One of the major jobs of government educational agency Becta is to review software. Becta is part of the National Grid for Learning, where Teem also publish software reviews for teachers.

It's also possible to subscribe to an online service such as LINE or FELINX! which provides regular modern language worksheets for teachers. They promise to supply over 750 new items each year and charge £30 pa to each school.

fields.headline: And the brand played on...
fields.standfirst: Theodore Dalrymple  on the NHS's new £225,000 'money-saving' logo
fields.trailText: Theodore Dalrymple on the NHS's new £225,000 'money-saving' logo
fields.body:
How did doctors, nurses, porters and cleaners etc know what they were supposed to do in the days before hospitals had corporate identities, brand images, logos and mission statements? It all seems so long ago now that it is like trying to recapture what life was like before television and Subscriber Trunk Dialling.

I do remember, however, the long and sometimes acrimonious meetings to discuss the development of hospital mission statements. All over the country, grown (and highly trained) men and women sat around for hours in hospital boardrooms, thinking up snappy little slogans such as "Caring for Margate" or "Abolishing death in Durham", although "Losing Mrs Smith's notes" or "Finding new ways to make food inedible" would perhaps have been more truthful and credible. A three-hour meeting to discuss a mission statement is an NHS bureaucrat's idea of real work, by the way.

The logos for the new hospital trusts created by former health secretary Kenneth Clarke's reforms had to be designed by professionals, however, at a cost of between £2,000 and £15,000 each. Little phoenixes started to rise from the flames at the top or bottom of hospital notepaper, as did birds of various kinds (though never, of course, vultures). Flowers, torches, even horses, adorned the pages of medical letters; and one hospital trust was so enthusiastic about its logo that henceforth it omitted to put its name and address on its notepaper, so that for a time recipients of its letters had no idea where they came from.

But now all corporate-identifying, brand-imaging logos are to go, swept into the waste-paper basket of history, as it were, and all our correspondence is to be subsumed under one big NHS logo, a blue lozenge bearing the letters NHS in white, developed and implemented at a cost of only £225,000 (the whole of Pasteur's researches probably cost less). The spokesman for the NHS Confederation, however, says that the new logo will save the NHS £340,000.

Of course, saving money in the NHS has a special, technical meaning. It usually means wasting less money than might have been wasted some other way. To save money in the NHS has approxi mately the same meaning as saving money at the January sales when you buy something you don't need and probably can't use: a fish tank oxygenator, for example, at an irresistibly knock-down price, when you don't have a fish tank in the first place. You think of the money you've saved, not the money you've spent.

What does the spokesman mean, then, when he says the new universal logo will save the NHS money? Well, 500 new organisations are formed within the NHS each year, he says, and if each of them developed a new logo of their own, the expense would clearly be considerable. Now they will all just use the blue NHS lozenge. It will not only save a lot of money, but - presumably - be a tremendous weight off administrators' minds, as they shed the onerous burden of responsibility for commissioning the design of new logos.

But what of the brand image of hospitals if all logos (save one) are to go? There are cynics among us who believe that hospitals don't need brand images at all: because if you live in Slagshire, it is to the Slagshire Royal Infirmary you must go when you're ill, there being no other hospital for miles around. The Slagshire Royal Infirmary, therefore, does not have to tout for business. It already has market share: approximately 100%.

Opponents of the blue lozenge concept of the NHS think, however, that it is symptomatic of the government's desire to control and regulate everything. Henceforth, we shall all sing the same song, whether we like it or not. The blue lozenge is yet a further threat to our independence.

Personally, I don't think the new blue lozenge matters at all, and I shall certainly not be manning the barricades to defend my hospital's logo to the death. What truly appals me is the comment of one senior bureaucrat: "A single brand logo is a terrific idea."

For if that is what constitutes our rulers' idea of a terrific idea, God help us all.

 Theodore Dalrymple is a hospital doctor

fields.headline: The radish revolution
fields.standfirst:
New books raving about the miraculous healing properties
of food - be it beetroot or aloe vera - are appearing on an
almost daily basis. Angelique Chrisafis swots up on the
'alfalfa saved my life' school of literature
fields.trailText: New books raving about the miraculous healing properties of food - be it beetroot or aloe vera - are appearing on an almost daily basis. Angelique Chrisafis swots up on the 'alfalfa saved my life' school of literature
fields.body:
Dr Gillian McKeith once found an entire vitamin tablet in one of her stools. "There it was, gleaming and undigested," she says. "You see, you are not what you eat, you are what you absorb. Get your nutrients from real food." There is a pause and a whimper. "Sorry, the baby just fell off my breast."

McKeith is promoting her new book by telephone because she has just given birth. Living Food for Health: 12 Natural Superfoods to Transform Your Health is just one of this month's new books about the miracle healing properties of food. Sprouting beans, it suggests, may cure prostate cancer.

The "alfalfa saved my life" genre of health books is a growing market. Last year we learnt that lean beef and lamb cure acne, oysters relieve cold sores, dried apricots ease fluid retention, prawns cure colds and yoghurt helps you remember who you are and where you put your wallet. This spring's new releases include Food: Your Miracle Medicine; The Food Pharmacy; Eat Well, Stay Well; Super Juice; Super Herbs; Super Boosters; Detox Your Mind; Detox Your Life; Detox Your Self; Healing from the Inside; Energy Foods; H2O: The Healing Power of Water and The Power Food Cookbook.

Borders book shop in London's Oxford Street has three shelves of these titles. The Food Doctor by Ian Marbar and Vicki Edgson has had four reprints since September, and in August, Collins & Brown publish Food Doctor in the City (like Sex in the City, but with mung beans).

Recently the line between food and pharmaceuticals has been blurred. The bread and bananas that give you vitamins are no longer foods, they are "nutraceuticals". "The market for books about so-called healing foods is an extension of the market for functional foods such as Yakult and Benecol margarine - which is fortified to lower your cholesterol," says "food psychologist" Richard Shepherd, who works at Surrey University. "People want two things: information and an easy cure for illness."

All these books about healing foods carry disclaimers warning readers not to give up chemotherapy in favour of dried pears. But people, inevitably, have high expectations. "More and more people are visiting nutritionists not to cure a specific ailment but because they don't feel happy with their lives and expect spinach to solve the problem," says Sarah Stanner, a nutrition scientist at the British Nutrition Foundation.

Jackie Landman, a public health nutritionist, says a priest told her recently that food therapists were like the clergy. In a secular world, "cancer-curing" radish juice is the new religion. There is an evangelism about the language of the new healing nutrition titles: "miracle foods", "food bible", "health testament". Miracle Food Cures from the Bible by Reese Dubin (Prentice Hall, £9.49) claims that the hawthorn featured in Jesus's crown of thorns is a great cure for heart pain.

McKeith's Living Food for Health (Piatkus, £6.99) is one of the better researched books. Her London clinic has a two-year waiting list for consultations and she irrigates the colons of the royals, the Hollywood acting establishment and Olympic athletes. A former health consultant to the Joan Rivers television show, she now presents a Feel Fab Forever slot on This Morning with Richard and Judy.

McKeith tells you to give your body "a lube job" with sprouting grains such as millet, quinoa, flax seeds and barley grass. This will cure spots, warts, brain malfunction, high cholesterol and hormone trouble, she says. It may also cure cancer. But you will have to spend an awful lot of time playing around with wet beans: covering them with cheese cloth or muslin, tilting them to 45 degrees and putting them on and off the window ledge for days to make them sprout properly.

Aloe vera, it seems, is the Rolls-Royce of healing foods. It cures all manner of infections, arthritis, diabetes, hepatitis, tumours, constipation, haemorrhoids, ulcers, skin diseases, burns, wounds and liver complaints. Courgettes cleanse the organs. And - surely a miracle - lentils and kidney beans cure wind.

Flatulence features quite potently in Jean Carper's Food: Your Miracle Medicine - How Foods can Prevent and Treat over 100 Symptoms and Problems (Pocket Books, £8.99). To find your wind nemesis, keep a record of how many farts you do in a 24-hour period (one young entrepreneur did 34), and cut down on the food types you ate that day.

Carper claims that asparagus and avocados may stop the proliferation of Aids, tea and carrots prevent strokes, ginger snaps cure nausea, sugar stops anti-social behaviour, spinach and garlic sooth depression, turkey breasts give you energy and - this is a new one - pasta is a downer that makes you woolly in the head.

Super Juice: Juicing for Health and Healing by Michael Van Straten (Mitchell Beazley, £10.99) claims squeezing fruit "extends your life". "Good mouthkeeping" (carrots and radish juice) cures throat and gum problems, "healer colada" (pineapple and coconut) stops the effects of alcohol abuse and "high flyer" (spinach, beetroot and carrot) prevents sunburn damage and should be drunk before going abroad. Try a "radish revolution" to combat cancer, fresh onion and garlic to "build better blood" or the self-explanatory prune-light express.

Anna Selby's H2O: Healing Water for Mind and Body, just published by Collins & Brown at £14.99, teaches you to cure eczema, spots, headaches, stress, lack of concentration, depression and travel sickness by drinking water at certain times of the day. Try 2pm for clear thinking. Boost your immune system with H20 recipes like cabbage water, watery vegetable broth, and a glass of water with sunflower seeds floating in it.

McKeith is promoting her new book by telephone because she has just given birth. fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: Returning after a holiday is never easy, the break inevitably bringing the utter pointlessness of work into sharp focus, but this time it is physical rather than existential distress that ails me.
fields.body:
Tuesday

Returning after a holiday is never easy, the break inevitably bringing the utter pointlessness of work into sharp focus, but this time it is physical rather than existential distress that ails me. After two weeks of unbroken relaxation (albeit punctuated by disastrous runs at blackjack and roulette tables in London and Normandy), I am horribly run down and have developed a nasty ache in the lower back.

Wednesday

Awoken shortly before 7.30am by a small boy with a model InterCity 125, I am exhausted to the point of collapse. "It's not natural to be this tired," I tell Rebecca.

"And what time did you get in from the casino?"

"About 4.30."

"So how much sleep did you get in all?"

"Two and a half hours."

"I see. And why do you think you're so shattered?"

"Leukemia? You think it's leukemia, don't you?"

Thursday

While towelling off after a shower, I analyse the twinge in the lower back. It is not a hot or acute pain, more a nagging ache, like a stitch. I now wonder if the cause of my tiredness is a tumour on the kidney - a terrifying disease albeit eminently curable if caught before spreading. And yet, how could it be? How could you have a tumour on a vital organ with no more dramatic symptom than a twinge in the back? No, for once I am worrying needlessly.

Friday

In today's Sun is a long piece about the broadcaster James Whale and his surgeon Tim O'Brien. "Tim told James he had a cancer after the star went to his GP complaining about a 'twinge' in his back," it reads. "A cancerous tumour 1ft long and 5in wide had devoured his left kidney."

Saturday

During a fretful morning, I am soothed by the recollection that Kerry Packer also had a kidney removed about 12 years ago, and he's still around to give the Las Vegas casinos the occasional $15m hammering. On reflection, perhaps success at blackjack and a predisposition towards renal cancer are linked, on the old "lucky at cards, unlucky at cancer" rule of thumb. If so, with my form, I should have nothing to fear.

Sunday

I awake exhausted and traumatised after a night too short to be troubled, having returned late from the refurbished Victoria casino.

"How badly did you do them?" asks Rebecca, with a reference to my standard post-Casino remark ("I did me orchestras").

"I didn't do them at all," I reply tersely. "I won."

"You're kidding. Roulette?"

"Blackjack. I couldn't lose a hand." She looks at me with concern. "I'll call Sarah and make an appointment," she says.

Monday

Dr Sarah Jarvis listens to the details. "Rebecca mentioned you've been tired lately," she says, "especially after nights at the casino. When you play blackjack, do you sit down?"

"Sometimes. But not usually."

"And when you go to the casino, how long do you gamble for?"

"Not long. Five or six hours."

"So you're on your feet for ages in a state of tension?"

"Sorry, you've lost me."

"And the next day you have backache."

"Yes."

"So...?"

"Go home," she says.

"But a urine sample to check for blood?"

"Go home. Skip the casino for a week, and if it's still sore, come back. But now go home. Please."

I go home, mulling carefully over the doctor's advice, and prepare for another long night at the tables.
