webTitle: 'I thought I was putting on weight'

fields.headline: 'I thought I was putting on weight'
fields.standfirst: Women often fail to realise that they have an ovarian cyst, mistaking any symptoms for menstrual problems. But if the cyst grows larger than a tennis ball, major surgery may be necessary, as  Sharon Gethings, discovered
fields.trailText: Women often fail to realise that they have an ovarian cyst, mistaking any symptoms for menstrual problems. But if the cyst grows larger than a tennis ball, major surgery may be necessary, as Sharon Gethings, discovered
fields.body:
It was impossible to ignore it any longer - my belly was bulging. But, unlike excess fat, the bulge didn't disappear when I lay on my back: it just sat there solidly, menacingly, pressing down uncomfortably on my bladder. So I went to see my GP.

When a pregnancy test proved negative, as I knew it would, he looked worried. He assured me that the lump could be one of any of a number of "non-serious" growths but that we needed to make sure, and then he booked me in for an ultrasound scan.

Four weeks later, at University College Hospital in London, the scan revealed a large ovarian cyst. My first reaction was anger. I had spent most of my life eating a balanced diet and exercising regularly, and strongly believed in a preventive, holistic approach to disease. How could my body betray all these years of care and attention by producing an enormous growth in my reproductive system?

Reading up on the subject, I discovered that ovarian cysts are, in fact, extremely common but as they have few symptoms, women often discover them only when examined for another gynaecological condition. Cysts smaller than about four centimetres in diameter are simply monitored, since they may dissolve and be reabsorbed by the body without being treated. My cyst, however, had ballooned to 10cm so discreetly that I'll never know when it first appeared or exactly how quickly it grew.

There are different types of cysts, depending on their cause and make-up. The ultrasound described mine as fluid-filled, thick-walled and "unilocular" - meaning that it has a single cavity; this type is also called a simple cyst. Multichambered cysts containing solid components have more chance of being malignant. The low risk of cancer was comforting, but I was worried that surgery would reveal something other than a simple cyst.

Because the ultrasound scan showed that the cyst had expanded my right ovary to about 10cm in circumference the nurse recommended referral to a gynaecologist. She explained there was a danger that the cyst might burst. The weight of the cyst could also cause either it or my ovary to twist round, causing great pain or haemorrhaging. I became hyper-aware of any unusual pain, expecting the cyst to burst at any minute. In bed, I would struggle to get comfortable as this fluid-filled mass wobbled around inside my abdomen, pressing first on my bladder and then on my intestines.

When I saw the gynaecologist at my local hospital, he confirmed the need for swift surgery and broached the issue of fertility. A scan isn't a precise diagnostic tool, he explained, and they couldn't be sure exactly what was going on inside my abdomen until they opened me up. They might have to remove one or both ovaries. His stark confirmation of my worst fears sent a chill through me and the anxiety I had been suppressing bubbled over into tears. I went home with the date of my operation and cried all morning.

Although I had never felt a strong desire to have children, I had never doubted that, when called on to perform, my reproductive system would acquit itself admirably: I was fit, had never had gynaecological problems and had always opted for alternatives to the contraceptive pill. However, at 37, I was no spring chicken, biologically speaking, and surgery would leave its mark. Ironically, two close friends became pregnant during this period and I was surprised by the strength of my reaction to the announcement. It was a potent mixture of joy for them, jealousy and self-pity - they were carrying babies, I was about to give to give birth to a lump of useless tissue.

The operation itself didn't worry me because I trusted my consultant. A friend had worked on a television programme about the unnecessary removal of female reproductive organs during surgery and a check of his credentials allayed any fears that he would whip out my ovaries at the drop of a hat; he had an excellent reputation. The anaesthetic was a different matter. A strong believer in complementary therapies, I balk at even mild painkillers and was terrified of the effect such a strong drug would have on my system.

The operation was to take place at 9am. As I was wheeled down to the operating theatre on my hospital bed, I felt incredibly vulnerable: total strangers were going to render me unconscious, cut me open and remove part of my insides. Weird.

A friend's hand on my arm woke me from post-operative sleep back on the ward. I opened my eyes to drips, tubes and plastic bags suspended from metal poles - all attached to me.

A nurse explained that the "remote control" next to my hand would give me a shot of morphine at the touch of a button if the pain became too much. More drugs. I don't know if was a subconscious desire to purge my body of medication, or a strong constitution, but I barely touched the morphine admin istrator and asked for it to be removed next day. Doctors told me that the cyst had been about 14cm in circumference (about the size of a large grapefruit on the frequently used but curious fruit and vegetable scale of the internal growth) and was, in fact, attached to my left ovary. The ultrasound scan had recorded the results of it being squashed around the front of my lower abdomen.

Endometriosis is an often painful condition in which bits of the womb's lining, the endometrium, migrate to other areas of the body and become inflamed. Ovarian cysts and endometriosis are often spoken of in the same breath, partly because the latter condition can give rise to "chocolate" cysts, so called because they contain old, thick blood. I was surprised when my consultant told me he had also removed one of these chocolate cysts.

I had never had the pain or any other symptom connected with endometriosis, and how much room is there on one ovary anyway, for heaven's sake? It's only the size of a walnut. My surgeon painstakingly removed both cysts and then sewed the ovary back together. Another doctor, present during the operation, even stayed behind after the usual morning doctors' round to tell me the procedure had been "amazingly intricate and beautiful to watch".

After that, the influx of drugs was relentless. As well as the daily painful injection into my thigh of a blood-thinning agent to reduce the risk of thrombosis, there were oral painkillers and anti-inflammatories dished out by the night nurse. The final - and biggest - drug hurdle was the hormone medication commonly used to suppress ovulation in order to give the reproductive system time to recover from surgery. I found it annoying to be asked every morning by an intimidating gaggle of medics whether I had made up my mind about taking it while still decidedly non compos mentis.

On one occasion my insistence that I didn't like taking drugs was met with the assertion that, in that case, I could be given a one-off injection that would last three months.

These drugs prompt a "mini-menopause" and possible side effects include loss of bone density, hot flushes, vaginal dryness, headaches. A doctor agreed with my observation that whatever benefits this drug brought were purely temporary and that if my body was determined to produce another cyst it would do so as soon as the medication stopped. I declined to take it. Other doctors I spoke to said they doubted the benefits of medication that deactivated the ovaries, and one told me that some women can develop simple cysts while taking the pill.

This settled, I just wanted to get well enough to go home. For the first few days of my week in hospital, visits to the loo were nerve-racking. I felt any "straining" would split my belly open like a ripe watermelon, even though the suture holding together my hip-to-hip wound made me think of a piece of cable from San Fransisco's Golden Gate Bridge, and a nurse assured me that more layers of stitching secured me inside.

My stomach ached constantly and I didn't sleep for three days. Finally, one of the night nurses gently ordered me to swallow a sleeping pill to give my body a chance to rest and heal. Seven days after the operation my brother arrived to take me home.

Six months on, I'm still angry at how my body has "let me down". And angrier still at a GP who told me, when I queried sharp pains in my ovary, that I'd "never be the same again".

Still, the ovaries are intact and what I thought would be a scar for life across my stomach has all but disappeared. I'm amazed at how the human body can bounce back from physical trauma. I just hope I'm not one of the unlucky few for whom ovarian cysts recur. I don't want to have to bounce back twice.

Ovarian cysts: the facts

Simple or "functional" ovarian cysts are fluid-filled blister-like growths on an ovary. Few are cancerous and doctors tend to take a "watch and see" approach to treatment.

Functional cysts tend to appear if the ovary produces too much oestrogen. Although common, especially in young women, they are usually small and disappear on their own in about three months. Most will cause no symptoms: you will feel nothing and probably never know you have a cyst.

But some functional cysts do grow large enough to cause problems. Symptoms may include a dull ache, bloating, pain during sex and irregular or painful periods.

If a large cyst breaks open, it can cause severe pain and swelling in the lower belly. The pill may help, but in extreme cases, when the cyst has grown larger than a tennis ball, surgery may be necessary.

Functional cysts are different from those associated with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), a hormonal condition thought to affect up to one in 10 women. Polycystic ovaries have a string of cysts around them (in what is often described as "a pearl necklace effect"). PCOS often goes undiagnosed because the symptoms are similar to those of premenstrual tension: weight gain, spots, tiredness, breast pain and depression.

But the condition can also cause excess body hair and infertility. The treatment - generally involving hormone pills - will depend on whether or not you are trying to get pregnant.

Symptoms may include a dull ache, bloating, pain during sex and irregular or painful periods. If a large cyst breaks open, it can cause severe pain and swelling in the lower belly. The pill may help, but in extreme cases, when the cyst has grown larger than a tennis ball, surgery may be necessary. Functional cysts are different from those associated with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), a hormonal condition thought to affect up to one in 10 women. Polycystic ovaries have a string of cysts around them (in what is often described as "a pearl necklace effect"). PCOS often goes undiagnosed because the symptoms are similar to those of premenstrual tension: weight gain, spots, tiredness, breast pain and depression. But the condition can also cause excess body hair and infertility. The treatment - generally involving hormone pills - will depend on whether or not you are trying to get pregnant.

webTitle: Livingstone 'a danger to London' says former aide

fields.headline: Livingstone 'a danger to London' says former aide
fields.trailText: A disillusioned aide resigned from Ken Livingstone's mayoral campaign fearing the independent candidate could become ''a danger to London'' if elected.
fields.body:
A disillusioned aide resigned from Ken Livingstone's mayoral campaign fearing the independent candidate could become ''a danger to London'' if elected.

Mark Goddard told the Times he resigned from the campaign after six weeks as a personnel manager claiming Mr Livingstone was a loose cannon ''hell bent" on confrontation with the government.

As the end of the campaign draws near, the Labour, Liberal Democrat and Tory candidates all attempted to inflict last-minute damage on Mr Livingstone, the runaway favourite to win the May 4 poll.

Labour's Frank Dobson said the Times article confirmed what he had been saying about Mr Livingstone, "that the people who know him best trust him the least."

But Mr Livingstone shrugged off the resignation today, claiming he had "never heard" of Mr Goddard.

"I am not commenting on someone whose name I had never heard of until I read the newspapers this morning. I don't recall any conversation with this person," the independent candidate said.

Conservative leader William Hague said yesterday's riots showed why voters should not support Mr Livingstone.

"After those riots yesterday are we going to have a mayor of London, when the bricks are being thrown, whose heart of hearts is with the rioters not the police?"

"This is what we are going to have if we have Ken Livingstone as mayor and the alternative to that, the only credible alternative, is Steve Norris," he told the Today programme.

But despite Mr Hague's support for Mr Norris, the wives of two prominent Tories today urged voters to support pro-family mayoral rival Ram Gidoomal. In a letter to the Daily Telegraph, Lady Sainsbury, wife of former trade minister Sir Tim Sainsbury, and Viscountess Brentford recommended support for Mr Gidoomal, of the Christian People's Alliance.

Liberal Democrat candidate Susan Kramer joined the attack, saying yesterday's riots were "yet another wake-up call to London" about the dangers of a voting Mr Livingstone as mayor.

"Ken has made it clear he supports direct action and yesterday he got direct action," she told a press conference. "If you want to protest in this city you can, but violence is not acceptable. If you have the kind of leadership Ken offers, in a way you have given a nod to this, to say this is a city where anarchy can get a warm reception."

The Times: Why I have quit Livingstone's campaign team
The Telegraph: Vote for Ram

webTitle: Philippine rebels threaten to behead hostages

fields.headline: Philippine rebels threaten to behead hostages
fields.trailText: At least one Philippine soldier died when Muslim rebels tried to break through a military cordon with their 21 hostages, including 10 foreign tourists.
fields.body:
At least one Philippine soldier died when Muslim rebels tried to break through a military cordon with their 21 hostages, including 10 foreign tourists.

The 100 heavily harmed Abu Sayyaf rebels clashed with soldiers in a firefight that left at least one government soldier dead and five injured. The rebels later retreated to their stronghold. The gunfight followed rebel threats to behead two of the tourists if the military did not withdraw troops surrounding the mountain hideout.

In announcing the rebel threat, Abu Escobar, an Abu Sayyaf leader, said the troops have moved so close to the hideout that the kidnappers can see them. If the government does not pull back the soldiers, "We will surprise them," he said in an interview with a local radio station. "Maybe two heads for tomorrow."

France said it was sending a senior diplomat to discuss with the Philippine government the plight of the hostages, including two French captives. A foreign ministry official said Paris had told Manila the safety of the hostages must be considered paramount. France is discussing the situation with Berlin, Pretoria and Helsinki. The hostages include three Germans, two French, two South Africans, two Finns, 10 Malaysians, one Lebanese and a Filipina.

They were kidnapped by the Abu Sayyaf Islamic rebel group from a Malaysian diving resort on April 23 and taken to a rebel camp in Jolo in the southern Philippines. Another group of Abu Sayyaf rebels who are holding 27 other hostages on neighbouring Basilan island claimed two weeks ago to have beheaded two of their captives, triggering a military assault on their stronghold which so far has failed to find the hostages.

The 21 hostages in Jolo appealed to the government to pull back the troops encircling them to avoid clashes and allow the kidnappers to obtain food. The kidnappers "can't get much food, much water because the camp is surrounded by the Philippine army and so they can't get anything for us," Stephane Loisy, a French hostage, told journalists, who were allowed into the camp. "We eat only rice, and the only water we have is the water from rain."

Nur Misuari, the government's negotiator, said he was told by the military that the encirclement of the area would stay "as is."

He said the Abu Sayyaf rebels have refused to begin formal negotiations unless the troops are moved. "They are demanding that government forces must withdraw from their present position to a safe distance," he said. "And as soon as that happens they are ready to open talks with me."

The Abu Sayyaf is the smaller of two groups fighting for a separate Islamic state in the impoverished Mindanao region of the southern Philippines. Government troops were also battling rebels Tuesday from the larger group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front, who occupied a major road in central Mindanao.

Reporters said the hostages looked dirty and exhausted. Some had cuts on their feet from walking barefoot in the jungle. The hostages said they were increasingly desperate and were beginning to succumb to illness and worsening conditions. Marie Michel, who is Lebanese, pleaded with the authorities to speed up the negotiations: "We are not used to the condition. We cannot take it anymore."

Werner Wallert, a German hostage, said: "We are in a very serious situation. I would like to make that clear. We are risking our lives here and if the Philippine government should try to march in and find a military solution, there will be bloodshed, nothing else."

fields.headline: Under the Skin by Michel Faber
fields.standfirst:
Under the Skin
Michel Faber
Canongate, £10
fields.trailText: 'Hop in,' she said.
fields.body:
'Hop in,' she said.

'Cheers,' he said breezily as he swung into the passenger seat.

Just from that one word, delivered without a smile despite the smiley facial muscles involved, Isserley already knew something about him. He was the type who needed to swerve round the saying of thanks, as if gratitude were a trap. In his world, there was nothing Isserley could do for him that would put him in her debt; everything was only natural. She had stopped to pick him up off the side of the road; fine. Why not? She was giving him, for free, something a taxi would have charged him a fortune for, and what he said to that was 'Cheers', as if she were a drinking pal and had just done him a trifling, perfunctory favour like sliding an ashtray into his reach.

'No problem,' responded Isserley, as if he'd thanked her anyway. 'Where are you heading?'

'South,' he said, looking south.

A long second idled by, then he pulled the seatbelt across his torso as if reluctantly conceding this was the only way to get the two of them moving.

'Just south?' she enquired as she eased the car away from the kerb, careful, as always, to flip the toggle for the indicators rather than the headlights or the windscreen wipers or the icpathua.

'Well . . . it depends,' he said. 'Where are you heading?'

She made a calculation in her head, then looked at his face to judge where he might figure in it.

'I haven't decided yet,' she said. 'Inverness, to begin with.'

'Inverness is fine with me.'

'But you'd like to go further?'

'I'll go as far as I can get.'

Another car had appeared suddenly in her rear-view mirror and she had to gauge its intentions; by the time she was able to turn back to the hitcher his face was impassive. Had his remark been impish arrogance? Sexual innuendo? Or just dull matter-of-fact?

'Waiting long?' she asked, to tease out more of his wit.

'Pardon?'

He blinked at her, interrupted in the act of unzipping his jacket. Was the challenge of pulling a zip and simultaneously listening to a simple question more than his intellect could manage? He had a thin black scab etched across his right eyebrow, almost healed - a drunken fall maybe? The whites of his eyes were clear, his hair had been washed in the not too distant past, he didn't smell - was he just stupid?

'Where I picked you up,' she elaborated. 'Had you been standing there long?'

'I don't know,' he said. 'I don't have a watch.'

She glanced down at his nearest wrist; it was big, with fine golden hairs, and two blueish veins passing over onto the backs of his hands.

'Well, did it feel long?'

He seemed to think this over for a moment.

'Yeah.'

He grinned. His teeth weren't so good.

In the world outside, the sun's rays intensified abruptly as if some responsible agency had just noticed they were shining at half the recommended power. The windscreen lit up like a lamp and beamed ultraviolet rays onto Isserley and the hitcher, pure heat with the nip of breeze neatly filtered out. The car's heater was on full as well, so the hitcher was soon squirming in his seat, taking his jacket off altogether. Isserley watched him surreptitiously, watched the mechanics of his biceps and triceps, the roll of his shoulders.

'OK if I put this on the back seat?' he presumed, bundling the jacket up in his big hands.

'Sure,' she said, noting the ripples of muscle momentarily expressing themselves through his T-shirt as he twisted round to toss the jacket on top of her own. His abdomen was a bit fatty - beer, not muscle - but nothing too gross. The bulge in his jeans was promising, although most of it was probably testicles.

Comfortable now, he settled back in his seat and flashed her a smile seasoned by a lifetime of foul Scottish fodder.

She smiled back, wondering how much the teeth really mattered.

She could sense herself moving closer to deciding. In fact, to be honest, she was more than half-way already, and her breathing was quickening.

She made an effort to forestall the adrenaline as it leaked from her glands, by sending calming messages into herself, swallowing them down. All right, yes, he was good: all right, yes, she wanted him: but she must know a little more about him first. She must avoid the humiliation of committing herself, of allowing herself to believe he would be coming with her, and then finding out he had a wife or a girlfriend waiting.

If only he would make some conversation. Why was it always the desirable ones that sat in silence, and the misshapen rejects that prattled away unprompted? She'd had one miserable creature who'd removed a voluminous parka to reveal spindly arms and a pigeon chest: within minutes he was telling her his whole life's story. The brawny ones were more likely to stare into space, or make pronouncements about the world in general, deflecting personal questions with the reflex skill of athletes.

Minutes flashed by and her hitcher seemed content to say nothing. Yet at least he was taking the trouble to peek at her body - in particular at her breasts. In fact, as far as she could tell from glancing sideways and meeting his own furtive eyes, he was keen for her to face front so he could ogle her undetected. OK, then: she would let him have a good stare, to see what difference it might make. The Evanton turn-off was coming soon, anyhow, and she needed to concentrate on her driving. She craned forward a little, exaggerating her concentration on the road, and allowed herself to be examined in earnest.

Immediately she felt his gaze beaming all over her like another kind of ultraviolet ray, and no less intense.

Isserley wondered, oh how she wondered, what she looked like to him, in his alien innocence. Did he notice the trouble she had gone to for him? She straightened her back against the seat, pushing her chest out.

The hitcher noticed all right.

Fantastic tits on this one, but God, there wasn't much of her otherwise. Tiny - like a kid peering up over the steering wheel. How tall would she be? Five foot one, maybe, standing up. Funny how a lot of women with the best tits were really really short. This girl obviously knew she had a couple of ripe ones, the way she had them sitting pretty on the scoop of a low-cut top. That's why this car was heated like an oven, of course: so she could wear a skimpy black top and air her boobs for all to see - for him to see.

The rest of her was a funny shape, though. Long skinny arms with big knobbly elbows - no wonder her top was long sleeved. Knobbly wrists too, and big hands. Still, with tits like that . . .

They were really odd, actually, those hands. Bigger than you'd think they'd be, to look at the rest of her, but narrow too, like . . . chicken feet. And tough, like she'd done hard labour with them, maybe worked in a factory. He couldn't see her legs properly, she was wearing those horrible flared seventies trousers that were back in fashion - shiny green, for Christ's sake - and what looked like Doc Martens, but there was no disguising how short her legs were. Still, those tits . . . They were like . . . they were like . . . He didn't know what to compare them to. They looked pretty fucking good, nestled next to one another there, with the sun shining on them through the windscreen.

Never mind the tits, though: what about the face? Well, he couldn't see it just now; she had to actually turn towards him for him to see it, because of her haircut. She had thick, fluffy hair, mouse-brown, hanging down straight so he couldn't even see her cheeks when she was facing front. It was tempting to imagine a beautiful face hidden behind that hair, a face like a pop singer or an actress, but he knew different. In fact, when she'd turned towards him, her face had kind of shocked him. It was small and heart-shaped, like an elf in a kiddie's book, with a perfect little nose and a fantastic big-lipped curvy mouth like a supermodel. But she had puffy cheeks and was also wearing the thickest glasses he'd seen in his life: they magnified her eyes so much they looked about twice normal size.

She was a weird one all right. Half Baywatch babe, half little old lady.

She drove like a little old lady. Fifty miles an hour, absolute max. And that shoddy old anorak of hers on the back seat - what was that all about? She had a screw loose, probably. Nutter, probably. And she talked funny - foreign, definitely.

Would he like to fuck her?

Probably, if he got the chance. She'd probably be a much better fuck than Janine, that was for sure.

Janine. Christ, it was amazing how just thinking of her could bring him right down. He'd been in a great mood until now. Good old Janine. If ever your spirits are getting too up, just think of Janine. Jesus . . . couldn't he just forget it? Just look at this girl's tits, blazing in the sun, like . . . He knew what they looked like now: they looked like the moon. Well, two moons.

'So, what are you doing in Inverness?' he said suddenly.

'Business,' she said.

'What do you do?'

Isserley thought for a moment. It was so long since anything had been said, she'd forgotten what she'd decided to be this time.

'I'm a lawyer.'

'No kidding?'

'No kidding.'

'Like on TV?'

'I don't watch TV.' This was true, more or less. She'd watched it almost constantly when she'd first come to - Scotland, but nowadays she only watched the news and occasionally a snatch of whatever happened to be on while she was exercising.

'Criminal cases?' he suggested.

She looked him briefly in the eyes. There was a spark there that might be worth fanning.

'Sometimes,' she shrugged. Or tried to. Shrugging while driving was a surprisingly difficult physical trick, especially with breasts like hers.

'Anything juicy?' he pushed.

She squinted into her rear-view mirror, slowing the car to allow a Volkswagen pulling a caravan to overtake.

'What would you think was juicy?' she enquired as the manoeuvre slipped gently into place.

'I don't know . . .' he sighed, sounding doleful and playful at the same time. 'A man kills his wife 'cause she's playing around with another guy.'

'I may have had one of those,' Isserley said noncommittally.

'And did you nail him?'

'Nail him?'

'Did you get him sent down for life?'

'What makes you think I wouldn't be defending him?' she smirked.

'Oh, you know: women together against men.'

His tone had grown distinctly odd: despondent, even bitter, and yet flirtatious. She had to think hard how best to respond.

'Oh, I'm not against men,' she said at last, changing lanes reflectively. 'Especially men who get a raw deal from their women.'

She hoped that would open him up.

But instead he was silent and slumped a little in his seat. She looked aside at him, but he didn't allow eye contact, as if she'd failed to respect some limit. She settled for reading the inscription on his T-shirt. AC/DC, it said, and in large embossed letters, BALLBREAKER. She had no idea what on earth this might mean, and felt suddenly out of her depth with him.

Experience had taught her there was nothing to do about that but try to go deeper.

'Are you married?' she asked.

'Was,' he stated flatly. Sweat was glistening beneath the hairline of his big prickly head; he ran his thumb under the seatbelt as if it were smothering him.

'You won't be so keen on lawyers, then,' she suggested.

'It was OK,' he said. 'Clean break.'

'No children, then?'

'She got 'em. Good luck to her.' He said this as if his wife were a distant and repugnant country on which there was no point trying to impose the customs of a more civilized society.

'I didn't mean to pry,' said Isserley.

'S'alright.'

They drove on. What had seemed like growing intimacy between them hardened into mutual unease.

But she had puffy cheeks and was also wearing the thickest glasses he'd seen in his life: they magnified her eyes so much they looked about twice normal size. She was a weird one all right. Half Baywatch babe, half little old lady. She drove like a little old lady. Fifty miles an hour, absolute max. And that shoddy old anorak of hers on the back seat - what was that all about? She had a screw loose, probably. Nutter, probably. And she talked funny - foreign, definitely. Would he like to fuck her? Probably, if he got the chance. She'd probably be a much better fuck than Janine, that was for sure. Janine. Christ, it was amazing how just thinking of her could bring him right down. He'd been in a great mood until now. 'I don't know . . .' he sighed, sounding doleful and playful at the same time. 'A man kills his wife 'cause she's playing around with another guy.' 'I may have had one of those,' Isserley said noncommittally. 'And did you nail him?' 'Nail him?' 'Did you get him sent down for life?' 'What makes you think I wouldn't be defending him?' she smirked. 'Oh, you know: women together against men.' His tone had grown distinctly odd: despondent, even bitter, and yet flirtatious. She had to think hard how best to respond. 'Oh, I'm not against men,' she said at last, changing lanes reflectively. 'Especially men who get a raw deal from their women.' She hoped that would open him up. But instead he was silent and slumped a little in his seat. She looked aside at him, but he didn't allow eye contact, as if she'd failed to respect some limit. fields.headline: Not Don for yet
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle believes Wimbledon's prospects aren't as bad as they seem. Even without a manager
fields.trailText: It has been a crazy season even by Wimbledon's standards; full of bitching and back-stabbing, half-hearted commitment and capitalistic individualism, rather than the never-say-die attitude and all-for-one camaraderie that used to encapsulate the Dons' indefatigable will to win.
fields.body:
It has been a crazy season even by Wimbledon's standards; full of bitching and back-stabbing, half-hearted commitment and capitalistic individualism, rather than the never-say-die attitude and all-for-one camaraderie that used to encapsulate the Dons' indefatigable will to win.

Now, after the shock departure of Egil Olsen, the club face the two most important games in their history. They must find a stay up or they will - like the state in a Marxist utopia - inevitably wither away.

It really is that stark. If Wimbledon go down most of the first team will leave, the Premiership money will dry up and the Norwegian owners, realising they've backed a loser will sell up. The team could easily roll down the divisions as quickly as they rose up the old Southern League.

But this Armageddon scenario is unlikely to happen - because despite their position in the league, despite all the rumour and rancour that has surrounded the club recently - Wimbledon are a good bet to survive.

Of course eight successive defeats is hardly the kind of form to stave off relegation. But Wimbledon have the easier run-in and, more importantly, seem to have - at last - rediscovered their old do-or-die mentality.

Before the match against Bradford, for instance, the team were shouting and bawling (and in John Hartson's case brawling), as well as banging on the dressing room walls.

They dominated large parts of that game - and, but for a couple of atrocious decisions by Jeff Winter, and Hartson stupidly getting himself sent off, they surely would have won.

Caretaker manager Terry Burton will know that if he can persuade the likes of Carl Cort and Jason Euell - who have been sulking off the pitch and slouching on it - to stop thinking about a big summer transfer and start playing, then Wimbledon can pick up points against Aston Villa and Southampton.

By contrast, battling Bradford face two much harder games, away at Leicester - who are basically a younger and more talented version of themselves - and then at home to Liverpool, who almost certainly will still be battling for a Champions League place. So it's unlikely that they will pick up maximum points.

Whether Burton will survive as manager if Wimbledon stay up is another matter though as higher-profile coaches will surely come forward to offer their services as manager. Earlier today Wimbledon's owners dismissed talk of either Vinnie Jones or John Fashanu following in Olsen's footsteps. This is the right decision. The club should stick with Burton, and bring in someone like Robbie Earle to assist him, to ensure that the Crazy Gang spirit remains - whatever happens in the last two games of the season.

sean.ingle@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Blair condemns anti-capitalism protests
fields.standfirst: Politicians' smear campaign links Livingstone to May Day violence
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today condemned the May Day protests against global capitalism as mainstream politicians attempted to discredit independent mayoral candidate Ken Livingstone by associating him with the violence.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today condemned the May Day protests against global capitalism as mainstream politicians attempted to discredit independent mayoral candidate Ken Livingstone by associating him with the violence.

Mr Blair hinted that the government would reconsider its approach to policing such demonstrations in the future, after police were criticised in some newspapers for not intervening to stop demonstrators removing grass from Parliament Square and defacing monuments. Ninety-five people were arrested in yesterday's demonstrations in London.

Metropolitan police deputy assistant commissioner Mike Todd praised the biggest police operation in central London for 30 years, for handling the riots "in a professional proportionate manner" despite putting up with "enormous provocation from a small minority of protesters".

On a visit to a Slough hospital, the prime minister declared he was "appalled" by events at yesterday's demonstrations.

"There's a long tradition that people in this country are entitled to demonstrate lawfully, but that right should not be abused in this way," he said. "This kind of thing cannot happen again. There is a right to demonstrate, but responsibly and within the law."

Meanwhile, other politicians sought to tar runaway London mayoral favourite Ken Livingstone with the rioters' brush.

Frank Dobson, Labour's mayoral candidate, accused Mr Livingstone of encouraging direct action and claimed the riots confirmed that he was "unfit to be mayor of London".

"Yesterday rioters who believe in direct action smashed up property, put working people in fear of their lives, assaulted the police and defiled the Cenotaph," Mr Dobson said.

"The police had the difficult and dangerous task of containing this outrageous behaviour. They are entitled to be sure that if they have to do this in future they will have the full and wholehearted support of the mayor of London. They have it from me."

He added: "If Ken Livingstone were mayor, the police and Londoners would not be sure whose side he would be on. That is because they know what he has said. The rioters know what he has said and they cannot have failed to have been encouraged to think that he was really with them."

Mr Livingstone attracted controversy in a magazine interview earlier this year in which he claimed he had "always been in favour of direct action". He later defended his comments by arguing that "you won't find a single time when I've ever supported violence" in the last 20 years.

The independent candidate kept a low profile yesterday, issuing an advance copy of a speech outlining his pro-business credentials which he will deliver to a City award ceremony tonight.

Conservative leader William Hague and the Liberal Democrats joined the criticism linking Mr Livingstone to yesterday's riots.

Mr Hague said the violence showed why voters should not support Mr Livingstone, "whose heart of hearts is with the rioters not the police".

"This is what we are going to have if we have Ken Livingstone as mayor and the alternative to that, the only credible alternative, is Steve Norris," he told the Today programme.

Liberal Democrat candidate Susan Kramer said yesterday's riots were "yet another wake-up call to London" about the dangers of a Livingstone mayoralty.

"Ken has made it clear he supports direct action and yesterday he got direct action," she told a news conference. "If you want to protest in this city you can, but violence is not acceptable. If you have the kind of leadership Ken offers, in a way you have given a nod to this, to say this is a city where anarchy can get a warm reception."

Mr Livingstone though issued a statement praising the police for their handling of yesterday's events.

He said: "Throughout the four days the police thereby set the tone that London both upholds the right to peacefully demonstrate and that it will clamp down with the full force of the law on those who threaten mayhem in the capital.

"This is precisely the tone that should be set for policing in London. I congratulate all those responsible for planning and executing this operation in the Met."

 Police arrested 95 people during yesterday's disturbances in central London. Scotland Yard gave the breakdown of offences as follows:
 29 cases of violent disorder
 Six rioting
 10 criminal damage
 Three theft
 Four drunk and disorderly
 One drunkenness in a public place
 Two arson
 10 affray
 Three breach of the peace
 Two possessing a pointed blade
 Four threatening words and behaviour
 Two possessing cannabis
 12 obstructing the highway
 One going equipped
 One on a warrant
 Two assault
 One shoplifting
 One miscellaneous
 One disorderly conduct.

fields.headline: McDonald's
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the most loved - and loathed - fast food company in the world.
fields.body:
1. It's 11.15pm. You've just rolled out of the pub and you're starving. Through the slick of rain and the traffic smog, you glimpse a familiar golden arch... thank God! McDonald's is still open.

2. Despite its ability to produce cheap, filling food with machine-line efficiency, the Ford of fast food has its detractors. The first target of yesterday's May Day protesters was the McDonald's on Whitehall - and last year's J18 rioters trashed another branch in central London.

3. What is it that makes McDonalds a target when Burger King and bourgeois office workers' refuge Pret a Manger escape untouched?

4. Detractors such as McSpotlight point to the merciless expansionism of the McDonald's empire. Launched in 1954, the chain now has over 23,500 outlets.

5. The McLibellers accused the multinational of cruelty to animals, deforestation, underpayment of workers and the exploitation of children.

6. In France, Basque separatists have bombed branches of the chain. French farmers, ever militant, have attacked them too.

7. French newspaper Libération made the hamburger one of the Objects of the Century - but still reserved special criticism for the imperialist McDo.

8. Yet the Big Mac remains, in some circles, the People's Burger. The first McDonald's in Moscow attracted huge queues. A recent two-for-one offer was hopelessly oversubscribed and apparently no two countries with a McDonald's chain have ever gone to war.

9. Indeed, the company has just embraced Britain's cultural diversity with an Indian range. The McJob has supported many an underfunded student through their degree.

10. Nonetheless, McDonalds remains a symbol of everything Europeans dislike about the States - brash, ruthless, profitable and ubiquitous. Even the Economist considers the Big Mac an excellent guide to a currency's relative value against the dollar. Which all makes biting into a Big Mac the biggest liberal dilemma some of us will ever face.

fields.headline: The Filth and the Fury
fields.standfirst: We have 50 reduced price tickets to an exclusive preview screening of this acclaimed Sex Pistols documentary, plus the chance to meet the director following the movie
fields.trailText: We have 50 reduced price tickets to an exclusive preview screening of this acclaimed Sex Pistols documentary, plus the chance to meet the director following the movie
fields.body:
Back in 1979, in the Great Rock 'n' Roll Swindle, Julian Temple explored the punk phenomenon of the Sex Pistols to dazzling effect. Twenty years on he gives them, erstwhile manager Malcolm McLaren, and the ethos of that era another affectionate but rigorous going-over with this superb documentary. Compiled largely from hitherto unseen footage shot at the time - from the group's rise in 1975 to their acrimonious break-up in 1978 - and from present-day interviews with John Lydon (formerly Johnny Rotten) and other survivors (Sid Vicious, of course, sadly conspicuous in his absence).

The result is hugely energetic and very funny; less expected, perhaps, the cool, critical look at a much-romanticised age, here vividly evoked. Never mind the bollocks, this is how it was.

Entertainment Weekly wrote of Julian Temple's film: "The Filth and the Fury is a great, searching, incendiary chronicle of the Sex Pistols.. there is perhaps only one word to describe its epic, righteous, buzz saw intensity. That word is passion. The Sex Pistols may have tried to destroy the world, but, as The Filth and the Fury reveals, that was only to save it."

Premiered to great acclaim at this year's Sundance Film Festival, The Filth and the Fury goes on limited UK release on Friday 12 May. But Film Unlimited readers can see an exclusive preview of the movie prior to its release, and meet the director, Julian Temple, at a Q&A session after the screening.

We have 50 tickets available at the discounted price of £5.50 (full price £9.50) for a preview of the movie followed by a Q&A session with the director on Monday 8 May at 8.30pm, at the National Film Theatre, London.

To take up this exclusive offer, please call the NFT box office on 020-7928 3232, quoting Film Unlimited offer. The box office is open 11.30am - 8.30pm. Tickets are subject to availability and will be issued on a first-come-first-served basis. Maximum two discounted tickets per caller.

Please note, this offer is for this cinema (National Film Theatre, South Bank, London) and for one night only (Monday 8 May). Tickets are not transferable.

webTitle: Hold elections or face sanctions, Cook tells Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Hold elections or face sanctions, Cook tells Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst: Commonwealth ministers discuss response to farm occupations
fields.trailText: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, today warned that Zimbabwe may be hit by economic sanctions if it does not hold elections by August as the country's constitution requires.
fields.body:
Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, today warned that Zimbabwe may be hit by economic sanctions if it does not hold elections by August as the country's constitution requires.

Mr Cook held out the prospect of economic pressure on Harare as Commonwealth ministers meet in London today to decide how to respond to the government-sponsored occupation of white-owned farms and a campaign of intimidation against opposition groups. Foreign ministers from eight Commonwealth countries are also expected to discuss the failure of Pakistan's military rulers to set a date for civilian elections.

Before the meeting, Mr Cook said he hoped ministers would take a firm line on the breakdown of the rule of law in Zimbabwe.

"That statement from the Commonwealth will have a considerable impact around Africa, but perhaps particularly in Zimbabwe, where President [Robert] Mugabe had tried to pretend that the problem is only Britain," Mr Cook said. "What President Mugabe is crying out for is for us to treat him as a martyr so he can then try to present himself, in elections, to his own people as somebody who is standing up on their behalf against the old colonial master."

Mr Cook said the committee would not consider imposing immediate economic sanctions on Zimbabwe or suspending it from the 54-member group of Britain and its former colonies. But he added that such punishments might follow if Mr Mugabe failed to hold elections by August, as Zimbabwe's constitution requires. No date has yet been set for the vote.

Although Mr Cook is hoping for a firm line from the Commonwealth on Zimbabwe, most analysts see South Africa as the key to the problem. Zimbabwe depends on South Africa economically and for its electricity, and President Thabo Mbeki has been trying to mediate behind the scenes. Mr Mbeki has been reluctant to criticise Mr Mugabe too openly as South Africa faces its own land issue, with only 6% of land claims resolved and less than 1% of the land redistributed since majority rule was introduced.

Last week, Britain said it would withhold £36m for land reform in Zimbabwe until Mr Mugabe holds free elections and halts the violence that erupted after armed black squatters began occupying white-owned farms in February. At least 13 people have died. Mr Mugabe has supported the occupations, saying they are a justified protest against the unfair distribution of land in a country where 4,000 whites own one-third of Zimbabwe's fertile land.

On Saturday Zimbabwean officials announced that Mr Mugabe would invoke special presidential powers to seize white farms without paying compensation, an indication that the long-serving autocrat has little intention of backing down under international pressure. Mr Mugabe is widely considered to be using the land issue to bolster his declining popularity before elections that could spell the end of his long rule.

Commonwealth leaders have also expressed concern that the generals who seized power in Pakistan in October 1999 have so far refused to name a date for elections. The Commonwealth suspended Pakistan after the coup and secretary-general Don McKinnon said earlier this month that the organisation must maintain the pressure on coup leader General Pervez Musharraf to hold a ballot.

fields.headline: Private health sector
fields.standfirst: The government is considering how the private health sector can help ease the NHS bed shortage. Jeannette Page explains what such a partnership will entail, and why it is being considered.
fields.trailText: The government is considering how the private health sector can help ease the NHS bed shortage. Jeannette Page explains what such a partnership will entail, and why it is being considered.
fields.body:
What is the government proposing?
Using private nursing homes in partnership with the NHS for elderly patients.

Why are hospitals short of beds?
Hospitals now operate at close to full capacity. A decade ago, around 75 per cent of beds in emergency wards were regularly occupied. Today the figure is 95 per cent. The shortage of beds is due to lack of money and "efficiency savings". Most areas have lost 40 per cent of acute beds since 1982.

How can the private sector help?
The government thinks a partnership could ease the bed-blocking problem.

What is bed-blocking?
This is due to elderly patients staying in a hospital bed because they are not well enough to look after themselves at home. They don't need to be there, but can't yet go home. They need rehabilitation. It's a long-standing but growing problem for the NHS which gets most of its patients in and out of hospital in ever-shorter times - and has fewer beds as a result. Most emergency admissions are among the over 75s.

What is Labour doing to solve the problem?
Tony Blair's NHS modernisation initiative is looking at several options, including special wards for elderly people on the mend which could be set up in mainstream hospitals, local community hospitals or new facilities. Labour is also stumping up a record 6.3 per cent increase in NHS spending, but Mr Blair is insisting on better value for money.

What do Labour MPs think of all this?
They are wary in case a private partnership weakens the NHS. They think integration of health and social services in the care of the elderly would be better and claim the private care sector has a record of encouraging dependence rather than independence.

What do the Tories think?
They're pleased and regard the move as long overdue.

What's the next move?
The partnership action team, chaired by John Hutton, junior health minister, is well aware of the need to woo older voters. The government will be insisting that private nursing homes do far more than they now do to help the elderly get better before NHS managers are allowed to use the private sector.

Will patients put in private nursing homes have to pay?
No. The NHS will foot the bill.

What about those who already pay for private health care?
They wouldn't be affected - there are around 200,000 private nursing home beds across the UK, of which around 30,000 are estimated to be empty at any one time. The NHS would take up the slack.

fields.headline: Good Friday gloom
fields.standfirst: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown sees little reason for optimism at the latest round of talks
fields.trailText: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown sees little reason for optimism at the latest round of talks
fields.body:
The British and Irish prime ministers are meeting the main Northern Ireland parties in a new attempt to breathe life into the moribund Good Friday peace agreement. The portents are not good.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson, who has maintained a curiously low profile in recent months, talked this morning of new proposals which "both sides could buy into", but offered little hope of progress, let alone a breakthrough.

The latest approach, he suggested, would tackle the issue of disarmament, and give the unionists confidence that paramilitary violence had genuinely ended. "But it is also one that gives nationalists and republicans the confidence that politics is going to be allowed to work; that the days of second-class citizens are over," he added.

The trouble with Mr Mandelson's vaguely worded formula is that it has been tried many times before, and found wanting. The impasse remains basically the same: the unionists want IRA disarmament as the price of sharing power with Sinn Fein, and the republicans want political progress before they will consider laying down their arms.

Previous formulae for ending the standoff included a final deadline of May 22 this year for the completion of disarmament. That is clearly a pipedream, and as it dissolves, the frustration of the parties - and of the people of Northern Ireland - is bound to increase.

With the loyalist marching season gathering pace, there are small but ominous signals of growing militancy. Police in Northern Ireland have captured a new and sophisticated kind of pipe-bomb of the kind favoured by loyalist paramilitaries for sectarian attacks. A token march of Orangemen in Dublin - the first since 1936 - has been called off amid claims of intimidation. In Derry, hardline Democratic Unionists have refused to attend a ceremony granting the freedom of the city to its most famous son, John Hume.

These may be straws in the wind, but they are drifting remorselessly in the same dreary, confrontational direction. The formidable task facing Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern today is to convince the parties that they must somehow move forward together - or remain forever bogged in mutual recrimination.

The message has got through to the moderate Social Democratic and Labour Party. Sean Farren, one of the party's assembly members who is to attend the Downing Street talks said that unless the present opportunity was grasped, it would slip away until after the summer, or even after the next British general election.

"We are at a very crucial stage and if the opportunity isn't taken, we may well end up by betraying the hopes and expectations that were so clearly expressed in the votes in the referendum two years ago," he said.

Sinn Fein's Mitchel McLaughlin was also guardedly upbeat, talking of the dialogue that had opened up between republicans and unionists.

But John Taylor, deputy leader of the Ulster Unionists, talked of the Dublin government "backsliding" on its commitment to disarmament, and said the republicans were entirely responsible for the lack of progress.

fields.headline: Fight for Rover goes on
fields.standfirst: Talks with Phoenix begin as Alchemy says it is still interested
fields.trailText: The Phoenix consortium said today it was confident it could avert the closure of Rover, as BMW moved to quell speculation that a rival bid by the London venture capitalists Alchemy was still on the table.
fields.body:
The Phoenix consortium said today it was confident it could avert the closure of Rover, as BMW moved to quell speculation that a rival bid by the London venture capitalists Alchemy was still on the table.

"We stopped our negotiations [with Alchemy] last week," a BMW spokesman said. "We want to start to get into negotiations with the Phoenix Group today."

BMW is meeting union-backed Phoenix to hear its plan to maintain Rover as a mass car manufacturer, in talks which are likely to last for several days.

Arriving at BMW's solicitors in London this morning, John Towers, the head of the Phoenix delegation and former Rover executive, said: "Thanks to BMW we've had a huge amount of information over the weekend. There are a number of points that we have to sort out today. We're looking forward to a very productive meeting."

Phoenix has made no official comment about its plans to keep mass car production at Rover's Longbridge plant in the west Midlands, but a source close to the consortium said it would table "ambitious and radical" proposals aimed at securing as many jobs as possible. It is thought to include a plea to build the new Mini at Longbridge, instead of BMW's intention of producing the car at Cowley, near Oxford.

Phoenix is also believed to want the same £500 million BMW is believed to have offered Alchemy to pay redundancy and pension entitlements.

BMW has warned that unless a deal can be reached within a month it will close Rover, which is losing about £2m a day. It would lead to the loss of 9,000 jobs at the Longbridge plant, and the loss of thousands more jobs in related industries in the region.

Rover workers arriving at Longbridge this morning said they were optimistic about the future. Shop stewards held banners aloft with the words "Business as usual" and "The fight goes on", while drivers sounded their horns in support.

John Hemming, a local businessman, arrived to show his support as did Duncan Simpson, chief negotiator for the AEEU.

Mr Hemming said he was not surprised by the latest move by Alchemy. "Obviously we don't want to see Alchemy, we want to see the Phoenix bid in there. We want to see them selling Rover cars, making a profit and providing a lot of work for people in the west Midlands.

"I'm not surprised by Alchemy's move but they gave up a major advantage with their exclusivity arrangements. They have given up that advantage."

The talks with Alchemy broke down amid reports of disagreements about which side would take responsibility for some of the redundancy costs associated with closing Longbridge. Alchemy planned to roughly halve output at the plant and turn Rover into a niche maker of sports cars.

But Jon Moulton, head of Alchemy, claimed on BBC radio's Today programme that Alchemy's bid remained the best hope for Rover.

"It is the best one because it is the only viable route," he said. "I would love to think that the Phoenix bid would protect a lot of jobs for a long time, but I don't."

Tony Blair yesterday pledged to work "night and day" to help secure as many jobs as possible at Rover.

"I and the government stand ready to do whatever we can for the workers of Longbridge and the region as a whole," Mr Blair said in a statement.

It has been reported that the government is willing to offer £150m in aid, although insiders say Phoenix would need a sum closer to £700m.

webTitle: There is a gap in the market for serious radicalism

fields.headline: There is a gap in the market for serious radicalism
fields.standfirst:
Hugo Young witnesses a shambles on the streets in the name of anti-politics

May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: In Parliament Square, there was nobody on the grass as the big clock struck 10.30. The guerrilla gardening was due to start, but decorum still kept hundreds of people to the paved edges of the target zone. A very British sight. An hour later, a couple of thousand had gathered, muddying up the turf. A bit of symbolic planting began, followed by the relaying of some sods on the car-infested tarmac. These seemed nice people, herbivores to a man and woman, seasoned by a few dressy exhibitionists. They didn't threaten anybody, least of all the bastions of British politics or capitalism.
fields.body:
In Parliament Square, there was nobody on the grass as the big clock struck 10.30. The guerrilla gardening was due to start, but decorum still kept hundreds of people to the paved edges of the target zone. A very British sight. An hour later, a couple of thousand had gathered, muddying up the turf. A bit of symbolic planting began, followed by the relaying of some sods on the car-infested tarmac. These seemed nice people, herbivores to a man and woman, seasoned by a few dressy exhibitionists. They didn't threaten anybody, least of all the bastions of British politics or capitalism.

They were caught both ways. They were always going to be either ridiculed or hated. More likely the former. Be violent, and you get noticed. Be peaceful, and be patronised or ignored. As many knowledgeable observers predicted, a minority of May Day exploiters were bent on violence. They duly carried out their assaults on McDonald's, beating up some bits of central London despite a police presence so massive that it acted as a challenge to the anarchist hard core, which swiftly succeeded in breaching the uniformed cohorts. This wasn't wanted by the herbivores, many of whom, suspecting it was coming, apparently stayed away. But it makes one think a little harder about their hopeless way of taking on the system.

Reclaim the Streets, the herbivores in question, is proud to be a "non-hierarchical, leaderless, openly organised, public group", in which, according to its website, no individual "plans or masterminds anything". Many of its self-directed people are idealists, if not utopians. Most have an environmental agenda, which they believe organised politics is refusing to address. So they make a virtue out of being disorganised. They're proud to be inchoate, delighted to expose opponents who can't handle the fact that a leaderless entity is non-negotiable.

But they face enemies who are not inchoate. They're innocents who have been given a profile of menace they do not merit. The state and the corporations can see off events like feel-good occupying and digging without the slightest trouble. The anarchists exploit it as perfect cover for violence that will lose every shred of public sympathy. Meanwhile, some crippling defects in the British system of politics and power are stubbornly unaddressed, and will remain so as long as the shambles that took place yesterday is held to be state-of-the-art rebellion, the last word in revolutionary democracy.

No mainstream party dares have a truly radical idea about any environmental question. All confine themselves within a frightened consensus that refuses to challenge the philosophy of economic growth, however it touches on the non-economic aspects of society. None is capable of applying to the future of traffic a creativity that measures up to the coming crisis. But then nor does RTS, for whom the sincere, even romantic lunge, despairing of conventional politics, is supposed to make a decisive statement. A more serious political radicalism would engage with the economic complexities, and find a better way of pressing the case than supplying a backdrop for anarchist destruction.

More glaring is the absence of a coherent political challenge to large corporations. Corporate power is the prime beneficiary of Labour's evolution into a party of capitalism. A necessary development, perhaps. But its place of reverence in the British scheme of things was more awesomely asserted last week, when the chairman of BP, Sir John Browne, was permitted to deliver one of the Reith lectures. These used to be the apex of the BBC's contribution to serious British life, an occasion for original thesis-building to challenge received opinion. How far have we sunk that a corporate boss should be offered the assignment to talk about global environmental challenges, which he duly seized for his company, providing no insight that was other than self-serving and no research that did not originate in BP propaganda.

No part of the political system contests such degeneration. Yet corporations are not popular. Their judgment of self-interest seldom extends to making people approve. Barclays Bank may be an extreme case, but its recent conduct revealed an indifference to public concerns which showed, more luridly than any recent episode, what corporate power will do when its short-term financial interest is threatened. Barclays' mix of brutality and complacency over branch closures could not, you might have thought, be surpassed - until you heard its chief executive's seigneurially contemptuous response to any notion that his £5m personal package might be open to debate.

Such attitudes do not attract public support. Yet few elected politicians are prepared to attack them. Like democracy, capitalism, for all its defects, is the best system anyone can think of. But it needs constant criticism. And the downside of capitalism and its perversions has no spokesman. A gap in the political market opens up. Segments of the electorate await it. There's space for forceful attack, rooted in ideas not gestures.

The political system does respond to force. Arguably it responds to nothing else. Not violence, which is easily seen off by the superior violence of the state, but the force of a competing political reality which threatens the power of those who control the system. The herbivore world itself has sometimes proved this. Targeted campaigns, based on rational arguments, diligent planning and accountable leadership, have changed the political and economic landscape.

No more major bypasses will be built in a hurry, after the trouble direct action caused at Newbury and the fulfilment of the protesters' predictions that the bypass would merely relocate congestion. Though ministers won't admit it, past protest has shifted the limits of future policy. It did more with Monsanto and its terminator seeds, which aspired to change modern agriculture. Consumer resistance, marshalled and informed by campaigns of popular protest, put paid to a product which Monsanto expended vast sums on developing and trying to push through.

Seattle and Washington, from which the London event was supposed to be drawing inspiration, connected with a different sort of reality. Much to the herbivores' distress, violence was not absent from the efforts to disrupt the meetings of the World Trade Organisation and International Monetary Fund. But Seattle worked by amplifying real political forces already at large, especially in the third world. Direct action was the ally not the enemy of political reality. Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth try to do the same. In the end, they make their effect by argument and action - very old operating principles - not by a bogus romance with anti-politics.

hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: Softly, softly approach falls down as McDonald's is wrecked by anarchists

fields.headline: Softly, softly approach falls down as McDonald's is wrecked by anarchists
fields.standfirst: May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: When protesters stormed the City of London last June in the first anti-capitalist demonstration the police were out of their depth, an independent review later suggested. Yesterday, they had a point to prove.
fields.body:
When protesters stormed the City of London last June in the first anti-capitalist demonstration the police were out of their depth, an independent review later suggested. Yesterday, they had a point to prove.

In June, senior police officers betrayed their inexperience and made errors of judgment as they struggled to deal with a level of violence not seen since the Trafalgar Square poll tax riots of 1990, and security guards at the Liffe building, home of the London futures market, were forced to fight off the activists before the 390 police officers arrived.

The clashes injured 44 people - one officer suffering a serious spinal injury - and left a £2m trail of devastation, but the damage to the capital's combined police force was equally severe.

The commissioner of the City of London police, which masterminded the response to the June riots, was forced to admit that his officers' handling of the pitched battles inside the Liffe was "highly unsatisfactory". Anthony Speed, the retired Metropolitan police assistant commissioner who conducted the review, exposed not only inexperience but lack of communication and confusion between the two forces involved, the Met and the City.

This time the Met, together with the British Transport police and the City of London force, was determined to prevent any possible criticism, and to learn from the handling of the June riot and the November 30 demonstration, when rioting at Euston station led to a police van being set on fire and 34 arrests.

Scotland Yard cancelled leave for all uniformed officers and allocated 5,500 to deal with the protest, leaving a further 9,000 outside the centre, ready to be diverted from other duties if necessary.

More than 100 were scrutinising CCTV pictures and passing on intelligence from a packed operations control room, while photographers were busy gathering evidence on the ground.

Army barracks in London were said to be on standby against any intrusion, and security was stepped up at the Millennium Dome, where activists had promised a "very big surprise".

Despite the vastly increased numbers, the Met was determined to operate a "softly softly approach", minimising the police presence and turning a blind eye to minor offences to avoid provoking violence clashes.

Deputy Assistant Commissioner Mike Todd told Sky News: "We have in effect almost allowed minor offences of criminal damage to take place to protect public order.

"We were intending [that] these people were filmed and held accountable at a later date for their actions."

This approach left uniformed officers standing by as activists dug up the paving stones in Parliament Square and planted seeds as part of a "guerrilla gardening" action.

The approach foundered once a breakaway group of anarchists began to smash up and loot a branch of McDonald's in Whitehall.

Within minutes specially equipped riot police arrived to contend with the flying bottles and bricks.

"We've been forced to change our approach because of the violence," a Met spokeswoman admitted.

Condemning the McDonald's attack as "thuggery", Mr Todd added: "We tried desperately not to inflame the situation and not have too many officers there, but what we have to do is to regain control of the situation and that's what we've been doing with our officers."

fields.headline: Protests erupt in violence
fields.standfirst:
'Guerrilla gardening' action turns ugly with looted shops and battles with police

May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: A protest against capitalism in central London involving 4,000 people descended into ugly scenes of violence yesterday when shops were looted and bricks and bottles were hurled at police.
fields.byline: Will Woodward, Paul Kelso  and John Vidal
fields.body:
A protest against capitalism in central London involving 4,000 people descended into ugly scenes of violence yesterday when shops were looted and bricks and bottles were hurled at police.

For the first three hours of the "guerrilla gardening" action, police did not intervene as activists dug up the grassy area of Parliament Square and daubed paint and graffiti on monuments including the Cenotaph and a statue of Sir Winston Churchill. But hundreds of officers in riot gear were brought in to break up the demonstrators after a McDonald's restaurant and a bureau de change on Whitehall were broken into and wrecked shortly after 2pm.

Police contained the protests in Parliament Square and Trafalgar Square for several hours before allowing protesters to leave. But fighting between demonstrators and police continued into the evening. The windows of a Carphone Warehouse and a Rymans store were smashed on the Strand. Officers followed a group of about 400 from Parliament Square to Kennington Park, south London, where, after stones were thrown, they once again surrounded them.

Tony Blair last night said the perpetrators were "beneath contempt". He added: "The people responsible for the damage caused in London today are an absolute disgrace. Their actions have got nothing to do with convictions or beliefs and everything to do with mindless thuggery."

The Metropolitan police said its operation, the biggest in the capital for a political demonstration for 30 years, had been "professional and proportionate".

There were about 30 arrests. Four members of the public and one policeman, who was hit in the face by a brick, were taken to hospital. Eight other police were injured. But the violence and damage was nowhere near the scale of the assault on the City on June 18 last year, which had caught police unawares.

"The violence this afternoon was not about peaceful and lawful protest, and we have had to change our policing style accordingly to ensure both officer and public safety," said Michael Todd, deputy assistant commissioner of the Metropolitan police.

From 11am police stood back as supporters of the Reclaim the Streets "dis-organisation" took over Parliament Square. Activists dug up most of the grassy area of the square opposite the Commons, putting down plants and seeds and digging ponds. Turf was ripped up and put on the road. Protesters hung banners from lamp-posts and forced police to block through traffic.

At about 1.40pm most of the demonstrators headed up Whitehall, where bottles were thrown at riot police guarding Downing Street.

Further on, a group of 13 police officers, some with cameras, was forced back by a small group of demonstrators and at 2.05pm a small McDonald's restaurant in the north of Whitehall, which was closed, was smashed and looted.

Staff fled to safety at the back of the building as, to cheers from the crowd, two protesters pounded the windows until they smashed and then one protester, wearing a black scarf over his face, smashed the McDonald's sign.

Paint was thrown over the yellow "M" sign, and smoke bombs were let off inside the building. There were roars as a demonstrator brought out the till, wielding it above his head, and then food was thrown into the street.

Shortly after, a store next door, both a souvenir shop and a bureau de change, had its windows smashed with staff still inside. Goods from the shop were thrown to the crowd.

At 2.30pm riot police charged the crowd. In a well-practised manoeuvre similar to that used at a Reclaim the Streets protest at Euston station on November 30 last year, police rushed in from a side road and split the demonstration, pushing about 3,000 towards Trafalgar Square and the rest towards Parliament Square.

Other police in riot gear sealed off the exits to both squares, which at Trafalgar Square included several hundred tourists.

Entrances to Westminster and Charing Cross underground stations were closed, as was the National Gallery.

Demonstrators threw bottles and cans at riot police and an officer was punched. Trafalgar Square was daubed with graffiti. Some tried to storm St Martin's-in-the-Fields church.

By 4.20pm Whitehall was cleared of demonstrators. Shortly afterwards, following an 11-minute stand-off, police began to allow the crowd to leave Parliament Square. At about 6pm, police "retook" Nelson's Column.

The "guerrilla gardening" action was on the fourth day of a series of events over the May Day holiday in opposition to global capitalism. Yesterday's event was the most heavily advertised and, as protesters had acknowledged, some violence was expected.

Some 5,500 officers policed yesterday's event, with 9,000 on duty elsewhere. But no more than a sprinkling of officers were in Parliament Square for the start of the protest. They did not react when a protester jumped on a police van and intervened only to help a woman whose car had been surrounded in Great George Street.

In Manchester city centre about 200 Reclaim the Streets supporters tried to storm the Arndale centre. Eight people were arrested.

Three people were arrested yesterday by British Transport police at their home addresses in Bedfordshire in connection with the riot at Euston on November 30.

fields.headline: Making the garden grow
fields.standfirst:
Trashing McDonald's won't change minds
May 2K: special report
fields.trailText:
Trashing McDonald's won't change minds
May 2K: special report
fields.body:
You announce a demonstration against capitalism, and all sorts of people who count themselves anti-capitalists duly turn up. That is both the glory of the exercise, and the hazard. Some come out of pure disgust at corporate greed and a thrusting, buffeting, me-first consumer culture, or out of a shining conviction that Jerusalem might be built here if people could be brought to see beyond their noses. Others come because they belong to political groupings which parasite on any demonstration around; because they despise the police, and want to get even; because their philosophy resents every form of order; or simply because they enjoy the taste of violence. There were perhaps 5,000 people on yesterday's London demonstrations, with all these tendencies represented. Some, recalling radical ancestors like the 17th-century Diggers, were armed with spades and trowels for guerrilla gardening. Flowers bloomed on the dreary lawns of Parliament Square: illicitly, but at least this was protest with vision, a vision beyond town planning. But others got into McDonald's, and trashed it. That was the bit which got on the TV news.

Though not part of the design, that was expected. It was why the turnout was down on expectations. It was also why the police were out in such force: perhaps 30,000 deployed to face one-sixth of their number. That is condemned as excessive. But it was clearly done in response to what happened in the stop the city riots last year, when the rage was higher, and the pubs - unlike those in Westminster yesterday - were open for trade. The earlier phase of the day suggested lessons learned not just from that but from the World Trade Organisation fiasco in Seattle and the later, less successful attempt to wreck the Washington conference of the IMF.

A lot of yesterday's agenda simply reflects an urgency about what passes most people by; a determination to wake the world up before we reach catastrophe. Tim Radford's report in the Guardian on Friday on the implications of global warming for much of the under-privileged world shows how much we need such urgency. But you do not advance that cause by trashing McDonald's, by defacing the Cenotaph or the statue of Winston Churchill, all of which many decent people prize. Those who staged yesterday's London rally know that. But some do not care. And unhappily, those who do care are unable to stop them.
