webTitle: Europe's far right loses its way

fields.headline: Europe's far right loses its way
fields.standfirst: May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: The extreme right was on the march in several European cities yesterday, muscling in on the traditional leftwing May Day celebrations. In Germany, the neo-Nazi National Democratic party held rallies in five cities including Berlin, where there were brief clashes with the police.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Berlin and  Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
The extreme right was on the march in several European cities yesterday, muscling in on the traditional leftwing May Day celebrations. In Germany, the neo-Nazi National Democratic party held rallies in five cities including Berlin, where there were brief clashes with the police.

But the far right's performance generally served to highlight its weakness more than its strength. The NPD, which had appealed to supporters to converge on Berlin, managed a turnout there of only about 750. And in Paris the French anti-immigrant leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, drew a crowd of just 1,500.

The suit-and-tie hard right, as represented by Jörg Haider, has made telling advances of late, not only in Austria, but also in Italy and Switzerland. But the more rugged brand of neo-fascism is clearly on the defensive, notwithstanding occasional violent outbursts.

Polish riot police moved in with shields and batons to restore order in the Baltic port of Gdansk after skinheads threw eggs full of red paint at left-wing May Day marchers.

In the eastern Berlin suburb of Hellersdorf, police units intervened to prevent NPD supporters attacking left-wing counter-demonstrators chanting "Nazis go home".

Some 2,500 police officers had been posted to the area to keep the two sides apart.

The star speaker at the rally was Friedhelm Busse, 71, formerly one of the youngest members of the Hitler Youth. He delighted the crowd with a line from a Hitler Youth song: "We're marching for Hitler day and night because of the need for freedom and bread".

The neo-Nazis, mostly young men, cheered loudly and waved illegal imperial German black-and white flags. Anti-Nazi protesters whistled from behind police lines.

In Paris the traditional May Day parade of France's National Front had an air of despair about it. There was a time, maybe five years ago, when the audience would have been 10 times as big.

"Together, we'll liberate France," read the slogan behind the party's pugnacious leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, as he harangued the faithful for more than an hour from a wooden grandstand on the Place de l'Opéra in central Paris. But, watched closely by several hundred police, the crowd was muted.

"Globalisation and its Trojan horse, a federal Europe, are leading France to its death," Mr Le Pen roared during a rambling speech that attacked immigration, information technology and crime. He called on his supporters to "adopt Joan of Arc as a symbol for the rebirth of France, a rebirth that will be spearheaded by the National Front".

But the party he founded in 1972 split disastrously in late 1998 when his former deputy, Bruno Mégret, emerged at the head of a rival faction that accused the blustery former paratrooper of being an electoral liability. Mr Mégret's National Movement yesterday held an even smaller parade that was turned back by police at the Place de la Concorde and prevented from reaching it's objective, the Assemblée Nationale.

Mr Le Pen admitted that the Front was going through a crisis, but insisted that the its self-inflicted wounds had now largely been healed.

"We are a heavy-weather ship," he said. "We have a heavy keel. We need wind to make headway."

But he has struggled to regain credibility since being given a three-month suspended jail sentence and disqualified from public office for a year for assaulting a woman Socialist candidate during a 1997 local election campaign in Mantes-la-Jolie, west of Paris.

Last week, in a gesture timed to cause him maximum embarrassment before the parade, the French government barred him from sitting in the European parliament.

Mr Le Pen also faces prosecution for expressing his revisionist views on the Holocaust during a visit to Germany.

Meanwhile, the Rassemblement pour la France, an altogether more acceptable anti-European party founded two years ago by a former interior minister, Charles Pasqua, has taken much of the wind out of the Front's sails.

"We're not much of a serious force at the moment," conceded Jean-Philippe, a National Front stalwart from Lyon whose jacket was covered with Le Pen stickers. "We seem to have lost momentum. Actually, I am not sure how much longer we will stay afloat."

webTitle: Ben threw the first stone - and the garden party erupted into running fights with police

fields.headline: Ben threw the first stone - and the garden party erupted into running fights with police
fields.standfirst: May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: If anyone from the Met, or the 30,000 other officers who were either on call or present in central London yesterday for the biggest mobilisation of police in 30 years, should read this - note this man. Called Ben, or "Benny". Small, weasly, little piggy eyes. From north London. Wears a black anorak, black trousers and several rings. He also snorts coke, drinks cider and when tanked up enough puts on a black handkerchief and hat, shouts obscenities at "hippies" planting flowers, and throws missiles at the police .
fields.body:
If anyone from the Met, or the 30,000 other officers who were either on call or present in central London yesterday for the biggest mobilisation of police in 30 years, should read this - note this man. Called Ben, or "Benny". Small, weasly, little piggy eyes. From north London. Wears a black anorak, black trousers and several rings. He also snorts coke, drinks cider and when tanked up enough puts on a black handkerchief and hat, shouts obscenities at "hippies" planting flowers, and throws missiles at the police .

Ben threw the first stone yesterday. His mates followed up with bottles. A dozen police officers patrolling Whitehall executed a smart backwards canter and, within seconds, vans of riot police had moved in, disgorging hundreds of officers with truncheons and shields even as the anarchists reached into rucksacks for missiles and donned their masks.

What had been a good-natured, if incoherent, May Day garden party in Parliament Square turned into a running fight with police, with a McDonald's ritually smashed and missiles raining on everyone. Which was exactly what Ben and up to 300 of his anonymous mates had wanted from the start.

Until then, Reclaim The Streets' action had been more like a post-socialist garden party without the tea - a reasonably-behaved mob looking for a catalyst. By 10am, several hundred cyclists and others had gathered in Hyde Park, many with seeds and shrubs to turn, they said, the wastelands of the city green.

By 11am, with 2,000 tourists in Westminster Abbey, 1,000 people were milling around Parliament Square, keeping off the grass, greeting old friends, jawing over GM crops or the upcoming terrorist bill.

Churchill and a geranium

By 11.30am, the drums were starting, people were up the trees, the statue of Winston Churchill had "blood" coming out of its mouth and it was holding an upturned policeman's hat with a geranium in it, Lord Derby in the north-east corner had a massive joint in his right hand, and General Smuts had a mask against traffic pollution and a rose in his left hand. The banners were out: "Let London sprout," "Global capitalism is not working," "Chant down Babylon", they said.

By 12.30pm, slowly but surely, Parliament Square was being dug up to make 100 mini-allotments. The police had swamped the one acre field with water the previous night, presumably to discourage people from sitting around.

It was a godsend for the guerrilla gardeners who found the turf easier to strip back. In the middle, Charles and Zoe were planting lemon balm and garden gnomes. Jane, from Bristol, and her family and friends were digging in runner beans, willow and daisies, and replacing the sand and clay with peat substitute. Carol, Ann and their friends had a furrow of rhubarb, sunflowers, rosemary, and night scented stock. Where once there was turf, went manure, fertilisers and seeds including hemp. "We should have brought a rotavator, said Phil, from Slough, admiring the irrigation channels that one family were constructing in a particularly boggy patch as a trumpet played the Archers' tune and Old McDonald had a farm.

"I'm just planting seeds," said John, from south London. "They'll trash the trees and veggies tomorrow, but the square should be sprouting hemp for the rest of the year."

But what do you do with half an acre of best turf? Plant it on the road, that's what. Within an hour, the tarmac was green, a maypole had been erected, the dancing had started, and a group from Bristol had spread out a giant "non-opoly" board where at a throw of the dice you could land on local currencies, farmers' markets or sustainable transport instead of Pall Mall, King's Cross or Edgware Road.

Meanwhile, the anarchists had been distributing leaflets telling people to follow the red flag for the location of the rally. By 2.30pm, 3,000 people were swilling up Whitehall behind a samba band, shaking fists and throwing insults and plastic bottles at Downing Street. One man, to cheers, shinned up a lampost and covered up the CCTV cameras. Others were spraying the street with anarchist symbols.

The confrontation had to happen. The first 400 people went past McDonald's barely believing it was there, unboarded and unguarded. The second 300 gathered round it. Benny hurled his rock and, to cheers, others waded in, smashing the glass, ripping out chairs, trying to pull down the golden arches and finally throwing chips into the crowd.

Vanloads of riot police

The police had to act. Five vanloads of officers in full riot gear moved in, splitting the crowd. Those to the north of the McDonald's fled towards Trafalgar Square, the rest retreated over the river to Kennington Park. As the police lined across the road, they were attacked by gangs but slowly and relentlessly they pushed the crowd into the sqaure.

Skirmishes broke out on the corner of Trafalgar Square and Northumberland Avenue. For the first time, some of the gardeners tried to stop the anarchists. Arguments broke out: "Plant your fucking veggies, fucking hippies, see what that'll do." "Idiots," countered the dirty-handed ones. "You won't change anything with violence." Others in masks tried to stop people attacking the police: "They're just the monkeys. Kill the sheriff, not his deputies." Meanwhile others sat down in front of the police, and bantered with them.

All roads into Trafalgar Square had now been closed by double or triple lines of riot police, leaving several thousand bemused tourists. "What is happening?" asked a Japanese mother, feeding grain to the pigeons. "Don't worry ma'am," said one man. "We're just overthrowing the state". "I see," replied the woman.

By now Nelson's Column was a sea of banners and groups, stacked with Kurds, Maoists, anarchists, socialists, ecologists, situationists, guerrilla gardeners and not a few tourists lining up as if for a school photograph of apprentice dissenters. Flowers adorned the lions, with stickers and banners on the railings reading "Reinvent democracy," "Blair, we won't go away", and "Queen Mum drop dead."

In front of the column, Bill, a "freelance" from Peckham, had gathered all the socialist and Marxist literature that he could find and set fire to it, to cheers. "It's just boring politics," he says. "I'm just into thinking for myself."

By early evening, the party was effectively over, with people drifting into streets that for once were without cars. "I love London," said Manuel, a Peruvian sitting on the steps of St Martin's in the Fields. "Compared to South America it is so ... calm."
fields.bodyText: If anyone from the Met, or the 30,000 other officers who were either on call or present in central London yesterday for the biggest mobilisation of police in 30 years, should read this - note this man. Called Ben, or "Benny". Small, weasly, little piggy eyes. From north London. Wears a black anorak, black trousers and several rings. He also snorts coke, drinks cider and when tanked up enough puts on a black handkerchief and hat, shouts obscenities at "hippies" planting flowers, and throws missiles at the police . Ben threw the first stone yesterday. His mates followed up with bottles. A dozen police officers patrolling Whitehall executed a smart backwards canter and, within seconds, vans of riot police had moved in, disgorging hundreds of officers with truncheons and shields even as the anarchists reached into rucksacks for missiles and donned their masks. What had been a good-natured, if incoherent, May Day garden party in Parliament Square turned into a running fight with police, with a McDonald's ritually smashed and missiles raining on everyone. Which was exactly what Ben and up to 300 of his anonymous mates had wanted from the start. Until then, Reclaim The Streets' action had been more like a post-socialist garden party without the tea - a reasonably-behaved mob looking for a catalyst. By 10am, several hundred cyclists and others had gathered in Hyde Park, many with seeds and shrubs to turn, they said, the wastelands of the city green. By 11am, with 2,000 tourists in Westminster Abbey, 1,000 people were milling around Parliament Square, keeping off the grass, greeting old friends, jawing over GM crops or the upcoming terrorist bill. The banners were out: "Let London sprout," "Global capitalism is not working," "Chant down Babylon", they said. By 12.30pm, slowly but surely, Parliament Square was being dug up to make 100 mini-allotments. The police had swamped the one acre field with water the previous night, presumably to discourage people from sitting around. It was a godsend for the guerrilla gardeners who found the turf easier to strip back. In the middle, Charles and Zoe were planting lemon balm and garden gnomes. Jane, from Bristol, and her family and friends were digging in runner beans, willow and daisies, and replacing the sand and clay with peat substitute. Carol, Ann and their friends had a furrow of rhubarb, sunflowers, rosemary, and night scented stock. Where once there was turf, went manure, fertilisers and seeds including hemp. "We should have brought a rotavator, said Phil, from Slough, admiring the irrigation channels that one family were constructing in a particularly boggy patch as a trumpet played the Archers' tune and Old McDonald had a farm. "I'm just planting seeds," said John, from south London. "They'll trash the trees and veggies tomorrow, but the square should be sprouting hemp for the rest of the year." But what do you do with half an acre of best turf? Plant it on the road, that's what. Within an hour, the tarmac was green, a maypole had been erected, the dancing had started, and a group from Bristol had spread out a giant "non-opoly" board where at a throw of the dice you could land on local currencies, farmers' markets or sustainable transport instead of Pall Mall, King's Cross or Edgware Road. By 2.30pm, 3,000 people were swilling up Whitehall behind a samba band, shaking fists and throwing insults and plastic bottles at Downing Street. One man, to cheers, shinned up a lampost and covered up the CCTV cameras. Others were spraying the street with anarchist symbols. The confrontation had to happen. The first 400 people went past McDonald's barely believing it was there, unboarded and unguarded. The second 300 gathered round it. Benny hurled his rock and, to cheers, others waded in, smashing the glass, ripping out chairs, trying to pull down the golden arches and finally throwing chips into the crowd. Those to the north of the McDonald's fled towards Trafalgar Square, the rest retreated over the river to Kennington Park. As the police lined across the road, they were attacked by gangs but slowly and relentlessly they pushed the crowd into the sqaure. "What is happening?" asked a Japanese mother, feeding grain to the pigeons. "Don't worry ma'am," said one man. "We're just overthrowing the state". "I see," replied the woman. By now Nelson's Column was a sea of banners and groups, stacked with Kurds, Maoists, anarchists, socialists, ecologists, situationists, guerrilla gardeners and not a few tourists lining up as if for a school photograph of apprentice dissenters. Flowers adorned the lions, with stickers and banners on the railings reading "Reinvent democracy," "Blair, we won't go away", and "Queen Mum drop dead." webTitle: Non à l'exil fiscal, oui à la liberté

fields.headline: Non à l'exil fiscal, oui à la liberté
fields.standfirst: Laetitia Casta, the symbol of France as Marianne, has caused a stir by moving to London. Is she a tax exile? asks  Karine Vandenhove
fields.trailText: Laetitia Casta, the symbol of France as Marianne, has caused a stir by moving to London. Is she a tax exile? asks  Karine Vandenhove
fields.body:
Laetitia Casta, la nouvelle Marianne, symbole de la République française, dément avoir voulu échapper au fisc français en s'installant à Londres. Cette affaire, qui, ces dernières semaines, a fait les choux gras des journaux britanniques, avait vivement fait réagir la classe politique française. Certains maires avaient même refusé de placer le buste de la Marianne dans leur Hôtel de Ville. Beaucoup de tapage pour rien, puisque le mannequin affirme séjourner effectivement en Grande-Bretagne pour des raisons privées et professionnelles mais non fiscales. Je vis à Londres lorsque j'y travaille, confiait-elle récemment sur Europe Un. Je loue un appartement car je ne veux pas rester à l'hôtel, parce que j'aime cuisiner et parce que j'ai un petit ami. Je n'ai rien fait de mal, je n'ai pas commis de crime et pourtant, j'ai l'impression d'être jugée. Laissez-moi tranquille !

Que pensez-vous de l'affaire Laetitia Casta ?

Sandra, 19 ans, vendeuse: Elle se fait la malle à Londres pour ne pas se faire arnaquer par le fisc, et alors ? Il y en a tellement qui le font !

Léa, 19 ans, étudiante: C'est son droit le plus strict. Encore heureux que chacun soit libre de vivre où il veut !

Aurélie, 21 ans, étudiante: Je comprends que les gros salaires se barrent de France pour payer moins d'impôts. Le problème, c'est qu'elle est censée représenter la France. Pour l'instant, c'est plutôt mal parti.

Que représente Marianne pour vous ?

Sandra: Rien du tout !

Léa: Égalité, fraternité et liberté, mais c'est un symbole tombé en désuétude.

Aurélie: La révolution française et la liberté.

L'idée que Laetitia Casta, alias Marianne, puisse s'exiler à l'étranger pour des raisons fiscales vous choque-t-elle ?

Sandra: C'est son poîgnon. Si j'étais pétée de tunes, moi aussi je partirais. Si le fisc ne nous pompait pas autant de fric, l'exil fiscal n'existerait pas.

Léa: Avant son élection, personne ne savait où elle vivait. Ça n'avait aucune importance. Elle était bien foutue, c'est tout ce qui importait aux yeux des maires ! Rien ne prouve qu'elle vive à Londres pour des raisons fiscales. Son métier l'oblige à être par monts et par vaux, comme tout mannequin.

Aurélie: Maires et politiciens ont été déstabilisés mais les Français moyens s'en foutent royalement ! Je comprends que les maires patriotes qui ont voté pour elle se sentent trompés, mais de là à dire que c'est une trahison nationale, il y a un pas ! Peut-être aurait-elle d refuser d'incarner Marianne sachant qu'elle irait vivre à l'étranger. Mais si ça ne lui pose pas de problème de conscience, qu'on la laisse tranquille !

Que pensez-vous du choix de Laetitia Casta pour incarner la Marianne ?

Sandra: J'aurais aimé quelqu'un de plus intellectuel, une femme de caractère, intelligente et forte. Casta n'a pas l'air très fufute. Elle a été élue parce qu'elle est bien gaulée, mais ça ne suffit pas !

Léa: Elle ne me fait ni chaud ni froid, elle n'est pas représentative des Français. Ce n'est qu'un mannequin. Poser à demi-nu ne donne pas une bonne image de notre pays. Marianne devrait véhiculer certaines valeurs, ce qui n'est pas le cas actuellement. J'aurais vu une femme d'âge plus mûr, méritant, de par ses actes et sa carrière, le titre de Marianne. Catherine Deneuve était très bien.

Aurélie: Elle est belle comme un cur mais ne représente pas la Française moyenne. Elle fait potiche. Il faudrait une femme, pas spécialement connue, ni bien foutue, une mère de famille par exemple, en qui chaque Français puisse s'identifier.

Plus généralement, que pensez-vous de la fuite des riches vers les paradis fiscaux ?

Sandra: Pourquoi devraient-ils se faire piquer leur poîgnon par l'État ? Ils ont raison ! Quand on voit les scandales financiers qui éclatent, la tune détournée sur le dos des contribuables, ça ne donne pas envie de rester !

Léa: C'est plus intéressant pour eux mais c'est injuste. C'est encore le Français moyen qui trinque, car lui, il reste ! Après tout, on devrait tous être logés à la même enseigne. La solution : baisser les impôts, pour tout le monde.

Aurélie: Il faut baisser les impôts, car on est pris à la gorge ! C'est vrai qu'avec le niveau de vie en France, on n'est pas si mal loti, mais les impôts sont vraiment trop lourds. Surtout quand on voit le montant de la cagnotte fiscale !

Glossaire/Glossary

se faire arnaquer to get ripped off
se barrer (coll.) to split
symbole tombé en désuétude obsolete symbol
faire ses choux gras d'une situation to make capital out of a situation
elle n'a pas l'air très fufute (futée) (very coll.) she doesn't seem to be very clever
elle est bien gaulée (bien foutue) ! (coll.) she's a damn good looker
encore heureux que it's just as well that
nous sommes tous logés à la même enseigne we are all in the same boat
se faire la malle to scarper
par monts et par vaux up hill and down dale
si j'étais pétée de tunes (very coll.) if I were very rich
si le fisc ne nous pompait pas autant de fric (very coll.) if the taxes were not so high

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer gossip including, at last, some good news for Spurs fans
fields.trailText: • Sergei Rebrov has agreed a sensational £10m move to Spurs according to The Sun. The 25 year-old Ukranian international has apparently turned his back on clubs like AC Milan, Inter, Chelsea and Manchester United, and agreed £25,000 a week personal terms with the North London club. The final transfer fee isn't yet settled - Dinamo Kiev want £12m but Spurs are confident of wrapping up a £10m deal in the next few days.
fields.body:
 Sergei Rebrov has agreed a sensational £10m move to Spurs according to The Sun. The 25 year-old Ukranian international has apparently turned his back on clubs like AC Milan, Inter, Chelsea and Manchester United, and agreed £25,000 a week personal terms with the North London club. The final transfer fee isn't yet settled - Dinamo Kiev want £12m but Spurs are confident of wrapping up a £10m deal in the next few days.

 Vinnie Jones has demanded that Wimbledon ditch Terry Burton and appoint him as their new manager. "I'm here. And I can save you. You made one mistake in appointing Olsen. Don't make another," Jones told The Mirror. "Terry Burton is a nice bloke, and has a good soccer brain, but he moved himself when Joe Kinnear was manager because he couldn't handle the pressure. He is a natural number two, not the type you need to lead at this stage."

 Gianluca Vialli says he will buy British from now on. The Daily Mail reports that Chelsea are interested in Jamie Redknapp, Robbie Fowler, Frank Lampard and Trevor Sinclair aswell as Andy Cole and Richard Wright.

 Des Walker will leave Sheffield Wednesday at the end of the season according to the Daily Express. West Ham are likely to repeat their £1.5m offer from earlier this season and Charlton, Manchester City and Coventry are also interested.

 Team Talk believe West Ham's hopes of signing Frederic Kanoute are in the balance after his club Lyon placed a £6.25m valuation on him - £2.25 more than originally thought.

 Real Betis have sacked their Dutch coach Guus Hiddink, with Planet Football speculating that he will now join Celtic. The Glasgow club have refused to comment on the speculation, while Leeds have warned the Glasgow side not to approach David O'Leary.

webTitle: Under the Skin by Michel Faber

fields.headline: Under the Skin by Michel Faber
fields.standfirst:
Under the Skin
Michel Faber
Canongate £10
fields.trailText: Isserley always drove straight past a hitch-hiker when she first saw him, to give herself time to size him up. She was looking for big muscles: a hunk on legs. Puny, scrawny specimens were no use to her.
fields.body:
Isserley always drove straight past a hitch-hiker when she first saw him, to give herself time to size him up. She was looking for big muscles: a hunk on legs. Puny, scrawny specimens were no use to her.

At first glance, though, it could be surprisingly difficult to tell the difference. You'd think a lone hitcher on a country road would stand out a mile, like a distant monument or a grain silo; you'd think you would be able to appraise him calmly as you drove, undress him and turn him over in your mind well in advance. But Isserley had found it didn't happen that way.

Driving through the Highlands of Scotland was an absorbing task in itself; there was always more going on than picture postcards allowed. Even in the nacreous hush of a winter dawn, when the mists were still dossed down in the fields on either side, the A9 could not be trusted to stay empty for long. Furry carcasses of unidentifiable forest creatures littered the asphalt, fresh every morning, each of them a frozen moment in time when some living thing had mistaken the road for its natural habitat.

Isserley, too, often ventured out at hours of such prehistoric stillness that her vehicle might have been the first ever. It was as if she had been set down on a world so newly finished that the mountains might still have some shifting to do and the wooded valleys might yet be recast as seas.

Nevertheless, once she'd launched her little car onto the deserted, faintly steaming road, it was often only a matter of minutes before there was southbound traffic coming up behind her. Nor was this traffic content to let her set the pace, like one sheep following another on a narrow path; she must drive faster, or be hooted off the single carriageway.

Also, this being an arterial road, she must be alert to all the little capillary paths joining it. Only a few of the junctions were clearly signposted, as if singled out for this distinction by natural selection; the rest were camouflaged by trees. Ignoring junctions was not a good idea, even though Isserley had the right of way: any one of them could be spring-loaded with an impatiently shuddering tractor which, if it leapt into her path, would hardly suffer for its mistake, while she would be strewn across the bitumen.

Most distracting of all, though, was not the threat of danger but the allure of beauty. A luminous moat of rainwater, a swarm of gulls following a seeder around a loamy field, a glimpse of rain two or three mountains away, even a lone oystercatcher flying overhead: any of these could make Isserley half forget what she was on the road for. She would be driving along as the sun rose fully, watching distant farmhouses turn golden, when something much nearer to her, drably shaded, would metamorphose suddenly from a tree-branch or a tangle of debris into a fleshy biped with its arm extended.

Then she'd remember, but sometimes not until she was already sweeping by, narrowly missing the tip of the hitcher's hand, as if the fingers might have been snapped off, twig-like, had they grown just a few centimetres longer.

Stepping on the brake was out of the question. Instead, she'd leave her foot undisturbed on the accelerator, stay in line with the other cars, and do nothing more than take a mental photograph as she, too, zoomed past.

Sometimes, examining this mental image as she drove on, she would note that the hitcher was a female. Isserley wasn't interested in females, at least not in that way. Let them get picked up by someone else.

If the hitcher was male, she usually went back for another look, unless he was an obvious weakling. Assuming he'd made a reasonable impression on her, she would execute a U-turn as soon as it was safe to do so - well out of sight, of course: she didn't want him to know she was interested. Then, driving past on the other side of the road, as slowly as traffic allowed, she'd size him up a second time.

Very occasionally she would fail to find him again: some other motorist, less cautious or less choosy, must have slewed to a halt and picked him up in the time it had taken her to double back. She would squint at where she thought he'd been standing, and see only a vacant hem of gravel. She'd look beyond the road's edge, at the fields or the undergrowth, in case he was hidden in there somewhere, urinating. (They were prone to do that.) It would seem inconceivable to her that he should be gone so soon; his body had been so good æ so excellent æ so perfect æ why had she thrown away her chance? Why hadn't she just picked him up as soon as she saw him?

Sometimes the loss would be so hard to accept that she just kept driving, for miles and miles, hoping that whoever had taken him from her would set him down again. Cows blinked at her innocently as she sped by in a haze of wasted petrol.

Usually, however, the hitcher was standing exactly where she'd first passed him, his arm perhaps just marginally less erect, his clothing (if rain was setting in) just that little bit more piebald. Coming from the opposite direction, Isserley might catch a glimpse of his buttocks, or his thighs, or maybe how well-muscled his shoulders were. There was something in the stance, too, that could indicate the cocky self-awareness of a male in prime condition.

Driving past, she'd stare straight at him, to verify her first impressions, making totally sure she wasn't pumping him up in her imagination.

If he really did make the grade, she stopped the car and took him.

Isserley had been doing this for years. Scarcely a day went by when she didn't drive her battered red Toyota Corolla to the A9 and start cruising. Even when she'd had a run of successful encounters and her self-esteem was high, she'd worry that the last hitcher she'd picked up might prove, with hindsight, to be her last truly satisfactory one: perhaps no-one in the future would measure up.

In truth, there was for Isserley an addictive thrill about the challenge. She could have some magnificent brute sitting in her car, right next to her, knowing for sure that he was coming home with her, and she could already be thinking ahead to the next one. Today hadn't started well.

Driving the car across the railway overpass near the comatose village of Fearn, before she'd even reached the highway, she became aware of a rattle somewhere above the wheel on the passenger side. She listened to it, holding her breath, wondering what it was trying to tell her in its quaint foreign language. Was the rattle a plea for help? A momentary grumble? A friendly warning? She listened some more, trying to imagine how a car might make itself understood.

This red Corolla wasn't the best car she'd ever had; she especially missed the grey Nissan estate she'd learned to drive in. It had responded smoothly and placidly, made almost no noise, and had lots of room in the back - enough to put a bed in, even. But she'd had to dump it, after only a year.

Only a few hundred metres short of the junction with the highway, a hairy youngster was ambling along the side of the narrow road, thumbing a lift. She accelerated past him, and he threw up his arm lazily, adding two fingers to the gesture. He knew her face, vaguely, and she knew his, vaguely. They were both locals, though they'd never met except at moments like this.

Isserley had a policy of steering well clear of locals.

Turning onto the A9 at Kildary, she checked the clock on the dashboard. The days were lengthening fast: only 8:24, and the sun was already off the ground. The sky was bruise blue and flesh pink behind a swaddling of pure white cumulus, hinting at the frigid clarity to come. There would be no snow, but frost would sparkle for hours yet and night would fall well before the air had a chance to get warm.

For Isserley's purposes, a clear raw day like this was good for safe driving, but wasn't so good for assessing hitchers. Exceptionally hardy specimens might go short-sleeved, to show off their fitness, but most would be bundled up in overcoats and layers of wool to make things difficult for her. Even a starveling could look musclebound if he had enough gear on.

There was no traffic in her rear-view mirror and she gave herself permission to pootle along at 40 miles an hour, partly to test out how the rattle was doing. It seemed to have fixed itself. That was wishful thinking, of course. But it was a cheering thing to think when setting out in the morning, after a night of nagging pain, bad dreams and fitful sleep.

She sniffed deeply and laboriously through her narrow, barely patent little nostrils. The air was fresh and sharp, slightly intoxicating, like pure oxygen administered through a mask, or ether. Her consciousness was hesitating at a crossroads between hyperactive wakefulness and a return to sleep. If she didn't get the stimulation of some action soon, she knew which way it was likely to go.

Isserley drove past some of the usual spots where hitchers were set down, but there was no-one. Just the road and the wide world, empty.

A few stray drops of rain spattered the windscreen, and the wipers smeared two filthy monochrome rainbows across her line of vision. She squirted bottled water from inside the bonnet, a seemingly endless stream of it against the glass, before she was able to get a clear view again. The manoeuvre left her more tired somehow, as if she'd had to give up vital fluids of her own.

She tried to project herself forward in time, visualizing herself already parked somewhere with a hunky young hitch-hiker sitting next to her; she imagined herself breathing heavily against him as she smoothed his hair and grasped him round the waist to ease him into position. The fantasy was not enough, however, to keep her eyes from drooping shut.

Just as Isserley was considering finding a place to pull in and doze for a while, she spotted a silhouetted figure just below the horizon. Instantly she roused herself and dilated her eyelids attentively, pushing her glasses on straight. She checked her face and hair in the rear-view mirror. Experimentally, she pouted her lips, which were red as lipstick.

Driving past the hitcher the first time, she noted he was a male, quite tall, broad-shouldered, casually dressed. He was using both thumb and forefinger, rather slackly, as if he'd been waiting ages. Or maybe he didn't want to appear too eager.

On the way back, she noted he was quite young, with a very short haircut in the penal Scottish style. His clothing was drab as mud. What he had inside it filled up his jacket impressively, although whether with muscle or fat remained to be seen.

Driving towards him the final time, Isserley realized he really was uncommonly tall. He was staring at her, possibly figuring out that he had already seen her a couple of minutes before, as there wasn't much other traffic. Nevertheless, he didn't beckon to her any more urgently, just kept his hand lazily extended. Begging was not his style.

She slowed down and brought her car to a standstill right in front of him.

webTitle: She wasn't much of an actress, but...

fields.headline: She wasn't much of an actress, but...
fields.standfirst: As a film season, a photo show and a gala night celebrate her career,  Tom Dewe Mathews asks, why are we still in love with Elizabeth Taylor?
fields.trailText: As a film season, a photo show and a gala night celebrate her career, Tom Dewe Mathews asks, why are we still in love with Elizabeth Taylor?
fields.body:
How do you fall out of love with Elizabeth Taylor? It's not easy. Time should have made a difference. After all, she is nearly 69, with a history of ballooning weight, and looks nothing like her original screen self. Also, as everybody knows, she has been spoilt rotten by film studios and successive husbands. She's got a foul mouth and a fouler temper, and even she admits her films are either "a piece of shit" or, like the over-upholstered Cleopatra, so excessive and clunky they made her "throw up". In a final blow to any lingering lustre, this year Liz received the matronly accolade of Dame of the British Empire. So why do we forgive her all this and continue to revere her as our queen of the screen?

Because she can't act. Her fans may cite Cat on a Hot Tin Roof or Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf as evidence to the contrary, but real lovers of Liz know that while her roles and even her image may change, her performances remain the same. And that goes for the TV films, the studio rubbish and MGM leftovers that litter her career, as well as for the great moments opposite Burton or Brando. That's why we can't stop looking at her - precisely because, like Garbo before her and Monroe, she never becomes the character she's playing. She always remains gloriously herself.

"She never appeared to be acting," observed a Picturegoer reporter in 1950, when he visited a 17-year-old Taylor on the Pinewood set of Conspirator, where she was playing her first adult part. "She always seemed to be natural. I doubt that anyone has taught her how to act or face the camera." He was right. Five years earlier, after her first hit for the studio, National Velvet, she had suggested to the dreaded studio boss Louis B Mayer that she take drama classes. "You're so goddamned stupid," he yelled at her. "Don't come in here and try to tell me how to make a picture." "You and your studio can both go to hell," the 12-year-old screamed back.

Her mother patched up the row but she never got her acting lessons. "The atmosphere," Liz later remembered, "was one of tremendous brown-nosing and of a genuine fear that you could smell. Stars at MGM were born or died more or less at the whim of LB Mayer. But I was too young to know why all of a sudden a young woman could be blackballed and never be heard of again." Stuck as she was in a revolving seven-year contract, she learned how to put on a courageous face, but not the nuts and bolts of acting. She was rarely given roles that would stretch her instinctive combination of guile and grace.

Everything depended on her beauty. The raven hair, the petulant mouth, not to mention what Richard Burton called "her over-developed chest"; but most of all, the timeless seduction of those legendary violet eyes. The downside of this unabashed beauty is that it can knock a film off balance, especially when it is allied to her lack of technique.

Take the climactic death scene of Ivanhoe, where the Jewish heroine, Rebecca, is being led to the stake. Liz holds her head up. She is serenely proud, but then, as a critic pointed out, she pouts on the pyre "as though she'd been stood up for a date". Sometimes her voice will reinforce the inappropriateness of her looks, as it does in Cleopatra when she sees Richard Burton's Mark Antony strolling by and invites him from behind a pillar in pure nasal Californian to, "C'mon in."

But she can't be blamed for the way her beauty scuppers Cat on a Hot Tin Roof. She gives her all in the role of Maggie, and that's part of the problem. To see a virile young Newman writhing away from a woman who could raise sap from a petrified tree because he's not "ready for it" is a perfect study in disbelief.

Yet when Taylor's beauty is allied to a plot, we are made to believe. All of us want Montgomery Clift to get away with murder in A Place in the Sun, not just because his reward - Taylor - is rich and will keep him in style, but because she is so heartachingly unattainable. We believe these beautiful beings deserve each other, even if it means disposing of an inconvenient wife who is plain, pregnant and a social embarrassment. There's an almost physical sense of loss when we realise Clift will never attain these giddy heights of unparalleled beauty, but instead is going to drop through the hangman's trap-door with an image of those wonderful eyes imprinted on his mind.

Even the grotesque historical inaccuracies of Cleopatra were almost transcended by the pulling power of Taylor's aura. Who else could have been preceded into imperial Rome by 50 fanfarers mounted on Arabian horses, followed by eight chariots drawn by matching teams, each one accompanied by a bowman shooting multicoloured smoking arrows into the sky, and not be upstaged? And then there are the scantily-clad dancing girls with streamers, the Watusi warriors, the dwarfs tossing sweets from painted donkeys to the 300 sweating Nubian musclemen pulling the three storey-high black-marbled Sphinxmobile, upon which sits our Anglo-Californian Queen of the Nile. At last she descends, lifts her veil and bows to Caesar. For a second there is silence, then pandemonium. Cleopatra has captivated Rome. She looks up to Caesar - and winks.

By the time the scene was set up, Liz's affair with Burton had pushed the cold war and the imminent Cuban missile crisis off the front pages, and, then, in the middle of the brouhaha, the Vatican accused her of "erotic vagrancy". The terrified actress feared that once her procession got through the Arch of Titus, the 6,000 waiting Roman extras would deliver an impromptu stoning. Instead they cheered and blew kisses. The script may have been Cleopatra's beauty conquering Ancient Rome, but the real triumph was Liz Taylor's.

However, her fundamental lack of acting ability has prevented her from ever becoming a middle-aged character actress, and so she has not appeared in what anybody would consider to be a serious film in nearly four decades. In the meantime her over-indulgence in double-chocolate fudge has lead to successive, unsuccessful battles of the bulge and jokes such as Joan River's announcement that Taylor is doing a remake of National Velvet: "It's called Crushed Velvet." Nonetheless, while Liz's fluctuating weight may have made her a (fuller) figure of fun, her battles with double pneumonia and cancer - when she defiantly displayed her bald head - have revealed her vulnerability, and at the same time made her increasingly invulnerable. Added to that, she's raised more than £100m for HIV and Aids charities.

At heart our Liz is a beautiful, brawling survivor, whose vulgarity and excess of appetite have paradoxically enabled us to share the cinema's great age of glamour. Most of the stars had to fight for fame, then they died or withered under the glare. But because Liz never knew anything else, her normal state has always been one of stardom. She was born a child of the studios, but became her own woman. What a dame.

 A season of Elizabeth Taylor films runs till May 28 at the National Film Theatre. Elizabeth Taylor: a Photographic Celebration opens at the National Portrait Gallery on May 18. The Royal Albert Hall Gala for Elizabeth Taylor's Aids Charitable Trust is on May 26.

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Submarine movie is buoyant at US box office, the original Charlie's Angels want nothing to do with remake, Angelina Jolie and Billy Bob Thornton marriage rumours denied, Christopher Plummer teams up with Wes Craven, and Four Weddings stars reunite in London comedy
fields.body:
Universal's big-budget submarine drama U-571 showed no sign of sinking at the US box-office over the holiday weekend, holding on for the second week at the top of the chart, with an estimated $12.7m in ticket sales. The same studio's much hyped but savagely reviewed family comedy The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas limped in second with a disappointing $10.8m from its opening weekend, while Fine Line's supernatural thriller Frequency debuts as number three with $9.1m. But despite the poor showing of both The Flintstones and Frequency (which had been tipped as this year's Sixth Sense), the US film-going market looks in a rosy state of health. Overall ticket sales for the top ten hit an estimated $65m over the May Day weekend - a jump of 29% on the same weekend a year ago.

Jolie has been wed once before - to British star Jonny Lee Miller - while Thornton can look back on an impressive four previous marriages. The Sling Blade star must be hoping for a case of fifth time lucky with the Oscar-winning actress.

British thesp Christopher Plummer has signed on for a role in Wes Craven Presents: Dracula 2000. The star the saccharine musical The Sound of Music will take on a very different role as an anguished antique dealer battling to save his daughter from a crazed vampire. The film will be produced by horror legend Wes Craven and directed by Patrick Lussier, who served as an editor on Craven's Scream pictures.

Andie MacDowell and Anna Chancellor, who last appeared together in Four Weddings and a Funeral are to be re-united in another London-set comedy. Written and directed by John McKay, The Sad Fuckers Club stars MacDowell, Chancellor and Imelda Staunton as a trio of girls behaving badly and begins shooting in the UK next month. Here's hoping that title survives the post-production process.

fields.headline: Books for children
fields.trailText: Some authors write for a specific readership others cast their story to the winds, hoping it will catch on the imaginations of young minds...
fields.body:
While some authors write successfully for a specific readership - disenfranchised boys, romantically inclined girls - others cast their story to the winds, hoping it will catch on the imaginations of young minds. Good publishing balances those market-led elements against less predictable storytelling that doesn't immediately lend itself to neat classification. The nature of reading and of readers is so diverse that we need all kinds of approaches, but it is always exhilarating to open a book and begin a story that connects and extends our lives.

William Nicholson's long-heralded The Wind Singer (Mammoth, £12.99) is a gripping read, set in a fantasy world that echoes contemporary preoccupations and pressures which are somehow clarified when presented with a "real" setting.

Aramanth is a city beset by rules and regulations. It runs like clockwork, everybody knowing their place and why they are there. Progress - better housing and greater status - is dictated by exam results. When the Hath family begins to question the narrow confines of their proscribed lives, the vengeance of the ruling authorities takes immediate effect. All seems lost, but for their spirit of independence, their courage, and the love that sustains the family. Having sensed what is missing from their lives, they are driven to find the solution. What follows is a beautifully narrated, warm thriller of a book, full of inventiveness, action and passion.

Secrets in the Fire, by Henning Mankell (Allen and Unwin, £5.99), is the story of Sophia, a 12-year-old girl growing up in newly independent Mozambique. Mozambique is a country at war with itself and Sophia just one of thousands caught up in the resulting anarchy. Her world is upturned by the brutal murder of her father, one of many massacred by bandits. Her survival, and that of her mother, sister and brother, is a miracle, and they go on the run, desperate to find a place of safety.

A gruelling journey ends with their arrival in a refugee camp where they create a new life amongst strangers. Gradually the little family establishes itself, only to be ripped apart once more when a playful push detonates a landmine. This is a true story, the awfulness of which is made bearable by the spare, honest storytelling. Events speak for themselves. Sophia has to face terrible loneliness following her sister's death, the consequences of her own injuries and, later, the realisation that she can no longer live at home. But throughout, she drives herself on, with the support of individuals who admire her outstanding courage and stoic inability to concede defeat.

Sophie Large was killed, aged 19, in a car crash. In her memory, her parents have published many of her letters, poems, diary entries and even emails in order to raise funds for Sophie's Silver Lining Fund, which supports young would-be actors and singers. Sophie's Log (£7 inc p&p from TheLarges@aol.com) presents a picture of a caring, committed, delightful and very human being. Teenagers will find their own worlds reflected in her thoughts, her enthusiasms and her sadder moments.

Scottish Friendly Assurance has sponsored Scottish Book Trust's four age-ranged leaflets, which reflect a variety of books for readers of all kinds up to 14 years. They feature Bumface by Morris Gleitzman, (Puffin, £3.99) a former Education Guardian Book of the Week, and the section for teenagers features The Sterkarm Handshake, by Susan Price, (Scholastic, £14.99) winner of the Guardian Children's Fiction Award, 1998. The ideal starting point for parents seeking the right book for their child, they are available free on receipt of an A4 sae, marked with the age of the child, from Scottish Book Trust, 137 Dundee Street, Edinburgh EH11 1BG.

fields.headline: An open secret
fields.standfirst: Introduce your child to books early in life and the benefits will show for years
fields.trailText: Introduce your child to books early in life and the benefits will show for years
fields.body:
Zoe is three and loves playing at being a bookshop owner. She has a toy till with a barcode reader and her shelves are neatly stacked with books. Yet her family are not great book lovers, and her mother Jayne admits she was surprised when her health visitor suggested reading to her daughter when she was only four months old.

"I would never have dreamt that a young baby would sit with me and look at pictures," she says. "At first I felt a bit silly because I was doing all the talking, but after a few weeks she was putting her hand out to the books and, instead of me turning the pages, she was trying to turn them herself."

Jayne had expected Zoe to rip up the books, but instead she treated them well from the start. "I've been to friends' houses where they haven't had books from babies. You see books scribbled in, torn and with the pages out. They don't know what to do with them."

Reading experts Dr Maggie Moore and Professor Barrie Wade are delighted by Zoe's enthusiasm and confident that the time spent sharing books with her parents will stand her in good stead for her school years.

Now the former teachers have written Baby Power, a practical guide to choosing the right books for all parents, relatives and carers who want to introduce pre-school children to books but are not sure how. It is complemented by a series of books for children aged nine months to three years that teaches them how to hold a book, that text goes from left to right and about sequence and prediction.

Wade, who has taught in primary and secondary schools, stresses that the emphasis in the parental guide is on fun: "Enjoyment is the key to success and parents get just as much out of it as children. We know this because parents have told us how much pleasure they have reading with their children. In short, having fun is a strong motivating factor."

And although he shared books with all three of his daughters, Wade, professor of English in Education at Birmingham University, never intended to teach his three daughters to read: "I just wanted them to enjoy books, but it reached a point where to not allow them to read would have meant hindering the curiosity and appetite for learning which they had developed through book sharing."

Moore, director of the School of Arts and Social Sciences at Newman College, Birmingham, spent 17 years teaching primary school pupils, including those with special needs, and says she could tell within hours whether or not a child had experience of sharing books with parents.

"Those who had spent lots of time book-sharing had a flying start when entering school because they were confident and enthusiastic - crucial foundations for successful learning. A lot of the time pupils finding learning difficult were not less able - they had simply missed out on the benefits of sharing books, and as a result were less confident." What started off as a hunch has now been confirmed by statistical evidence from the Bookstart project, which Wade and Moore launched in 1992, when 300 babies and their families across Birmingham were given free books and encouraged to read together.

Their latest research focuses on the performance of the original Bookstart babies, who are now aged seven and eight in their key stage 1 Sats. The aim was to see if those who started primary school so far ahead of their peers remained so. The results show that these children are still approximately 30% ahead in English-based subjects and 25% ahead in maths and science-based subjects - the same advantage as they had on entering the education system in 1997.

Jessica Garvey, eight, is one of the original Bookstart babies, and Wade and Moore have dedicated Baby Power to her. After asking the Bookstart babies to take part in tests in 1997, Wade sent a book to them all to say thankyou. Jessica was the only one who wrote a letter back, enclosing a three-page book that she had made at school.

"Jess is no superstar, but she was above average in her Sats, both in literacy and numeracy," says her mother Gill. "She is confident, loves books and often sits down with her six-year-old brother Samuel and reads to him and gets him to read to her."

Gill Garvey says that if it were not for the Bookstart research she would never have thought about sharing books with Jessica when she was only four months old. She and her husband read to their daughter on a daily basis and "only when they had time", but soon noticed the results. "Jess was inquisitive and lively, and when she started speaking had a good range of vocabulary. I would recommend Bookstart to all parents."

Through a £6m sponsorship deal with Sainsbury's, the scheme is now operating throughout Britain and aims to provide every baby with a free book by the end of this year.

The millionth book was given out earlier this year. Impressed by the success of Bookstart, the Japanese government is setting up a scheme along the same lines and other countries have expressed interest.

Wade even goes as far as to suggest that with adequate funding Bookstart could meet all educational targets. "We know that regular book sharing will lay the foundations of literacy, and that should mean fewer learning difficulties when the child starts school. I would even say that GCSE results could be affected by the way a baby interacts with its parents."

But although Wade and Moore hope that nearly all parents will realise the benefits of reading, they do not want parents to become competitive about their children's progress.

"We are making real progress at the moment," says Moore. "But if we end up like America, where children undergo assessment all the time, we will have failed."

Early readers

Do

 Make it fun for both you and the baby and praise him or her.

 Talk about the book and its pictures even if you think your baby doesn't understand.

 Let your baby hold and handle the book and turn the pages.

 Take your baby to the library and let your baby choose the books.

 Read a book lots of times because your baby won't get bored.

Don't

 Worry if the baby chews the books (even library books).

 Expect too much of your baby or criticise.

 Be disappointed if your baby isn't interested - try again later.

 Have the television on at the same time, because it is distracting.

 Feel guilty about taking time out to read to your baby.

 Baby Power: Give your child real learning power by Barrie Wade and Maggie Moore is published by Egmont, priced £4.99.

webTitle: Bus rage driver took passengers on five-mile chase

fields.headline: Bus rage driver took passengers on five-mile chase
fields.trailText: It is a scenario most drivers are familiar with: a car brakes abruptly and then drives erratically, forcing those around to back off.
fields.body:
It is a scenario most drivers are familiar with: a car brakes abruptly and then drives erratically, forcing those around to back off.

But when one Bristol driver was confronted with such behaviour, he responded with an extreme case of road rage. The additional problem was, he was driving a packed double decker bus.

For five miles, the irate bus driver chased a dark Saab through the narrow streets of upmarket Clifton, hurling abuse at him and swerving to overtake him on blind bends.

Children were flung into the aisles as the bus sped down a steep road from the heights of the city to the bottom of a valley.

Melanie Greenwood, a journalist who experienced the ride with her 12-year-old daughter Laura, said: "People were quiet with fear. We just couldn't believe what was happening. I kept yelling at him to stop. I thought he was going to kill us all."

The ordeal began at around 4pm on Sunday as the Badger Line double decker -crammed with about 80 passengers, many standing - left Clifton Downs for a park and ride car park.

Minutes into the routine trip, they were flung forward as the bus braked abruptly. "One young girl hit her head on the pole as she went for ward and children fell on the floor," said Ms Greenwood. "You would have expected the driver to turn round and say: 'Is everyone all right?' but instead he put his head out of the window and yelled abuse."

The other driver jeered in response and set off before braking abruptly, causing the bus to stop and start again.

The bus driver tried to overtake as they raced through the streets. He persisted in trying as he careered down a hill. Ms Greenwood said: "It's a steep road, with sharp corners and he was trying to overtake when there was no way he could see if something was coming."

The chase continued as the two reached the dual carriageway, but, before the bus managed to overtake, the car pulled off at a junction.

As the passengers got off, the bus driver offered no apologies and refused to give his name. No one from Badger Line was available for comment.

webTitle: Rapid crossing at the fundraising frontier but still no money in the bank

fields.headline: Rapid crossing at the fundraising frontier but still no money in the bank
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Some people make it sound so easy. We attended a First Tuesday debate a couple of months ago about people's experiences of their first year running an internet start-up.
fields.body:
Some people make it sound so easy. We attended a First Tuesday debate a couple of months ago about people's experiences of their first year running an internet start-up.

Many of the entrepreneurs there gave the impression that raising launch funds had actually been one of the simpler tasks. Combined with stories about people obtaining funding on the back of an idea sketched out on a matchbox it appeared to make the prospect of raising millions seem as easy as getting out of bed. We were sceptical.

The UK, and particularly London, is said to be dripping with venture capital gold, and there has never been a better time to seek start-up funding. It is clear that it is easier to find people to invest in internet start-ups. Investors now have confidence in the established new technologies and are much more likely to take in ternet-based business models seriously. "Oh! How much more difficult it was in my day," lament the pioneers.

However, the opportunities and high profile success of early net entrepreneurs has also meant the number of people demanding investment has more than matched the increase in funds supply. The manager of a London venture capital firm told us he was receiving over 50 business proposals a day.

How can you attract the attention of serious investors when there are hundreds of other candidates out there, each enthusing about a "unique business model", a "fantastic market opportunity" and an "experienced management team"?

Our fundraising strategy for Rools is clear: our plan is for an online debit facility enabling young people to shop online with a network of partner retailers without using a credit card. We need substantial investment, particularly in technology, infrastructure and marketing.

Our belief was that we would be in a better position if we could draw up a comprehensive and compelling business plan, develop a prototype of the service and obtain commitments from a number of leading retailers and strategic partners before we sought external funding.

We believed that demonstrable success in these areas would help convince potential investors of the strength of the core idea and the ability of the management team to deliver. We hoped that it might also increase the value of the business when the investment did arrive.

In the end we approached a couple of people we already knew in the industry and six other candidates with a phone call and a copy of the summary of our proposal.

There are numerous myths about the workings of the net venture capital world but we were genuinely surprised at the speed of response. At our very first meeting, only three days later, we received our first offer. This seemed to act as a trigger for other investors and, although we did have a couple of rejections, it now appears that we have three investors keen to enter into a joint venture.

Our experience seems to support the belief that it can be easy to attract investment - but we are already seeing signs that actually getting the money in the bank is a longer and potentially much bumpier journey.

The authors are co-founders of Rools.com

How can you attract the attention of serious investors when there are hundreds of other candidates out there, each enthusing about a "unique business model", a "fantastic market opportunity" and an "experienced management team"? Our fundraising strategy for Rools is clear: our plan is for an online debit facility enabling young people to shop online with a network of partner retailers without using a credit card. We need substantial investment, particularly in technology, infrastructure and marketing. Our belief was that we would be in a better position if we could draw up a comprehensive and compelling business plan, develop a prototype of the service and obtain commitments from a number of leading retailers and strategic partners before we sought external funding. We believed that demonstrable success in these areas would help convince potential investors of the strength of the core idea and the ability of the management team to deliver. We hoped that it might also increase the value of the business when the investment did arrive. In the end we approached a couple of people we already knew in the industry and six other candidates with a phone call and a copy of the summary of our proposal. There are numerous myths about the workings of the net venture capital world but we were genuinely surprised at the speed of response. At our very first meeting, only three days later, we received our first offer. This seemed to act as a trigger for other investors and, although we did have a couple of rejections, it now appears that we have three investors keen to enter into a joint venture. Our experience seems to support the belief that it can be easy to attract investment - but we are already seeing signs that actually getting the money in the bank is a longer and potentially much bumpier journey. webTitle: Diaz signs up for Scorsese picture

fields.headline: Diaz signs up for Scorsese picture
fields.trailText: Cameron Diaz is the latest big name to sign up to Martin Scorsese's The Gangs of New York
fields.body:
Cameron Diaz is the latest big name to sign up to Martin Scorsese's The Gangs of New York. After a month of negotiations, the actress yesterday confirmed that she will be co-starring opposite Leonardo Dicaprio in the period drama, which plays out in a corrupt 19th century Manhattan.

Diaz (currently completing work on the troubled Charlie's Angels movie) will play the role of Jenny, a streetwise cat-burglar who joins forces with DiCaprio's character, Amsterdam Vallon. DiCaprio's hero is a thrusting young gangster who rises to power during the neighbourhood turf wars between New York's Irish and Italian immigrants. Variety reports that Scorsese is still eyeing Liam Neeson and Pete Postlethwaite to fill the film's two other major roles.

Backed by Miramax, The Gangs of New York is shaping up to be Scorsese's most expensive production yet, with a budget nudging towards the $100m mark. The script began as a collaboration between Scorsese and Jay Cocks (his writer on The Age of Innocence), but the final draft has been overseen by respected Hollywood script-man Steven Zaillian (who won an Oscar for his screenplay for Schindler's List). The film begins shooting in August in locations in Rome before moving back to the US in the autumn.

fields.headline: Blair's promise to Rover workers
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair promised to work "night and day" to help rescue jobs at the stricken car maker Rover, and Downing Street officials are intervening directly to win breathing space for the Phoenix consortium in its attempts to take over the Longbridge plant.
fields.body:
Tony Blair promised to work "night and day" to help rescue jobs at the stricken car maker Rover, and Downing Street officials are intervening directly to win breathing space for the Phoenix consortium in its attempts to take over the Longbridge plant.

Senior officials are taking advantage of the close relations between the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, and Mr Blair to exert political leverage on Rover's parent, BMW, not to shut the plant until Phoenix has had every opportunity to put together a viable offer.

In a statement yesterday Mr Blair said: "I want to reassure the people of the West Midlands that I and the government stand ready to do whatever we can for the workers at Longbridge and the region as a whole. I have asked Stephen Byers [the trade secretary] to keep me personally in touch with the developments and I am pleased that he has helped ensure that any bid from Phoenix will be given proper consideration.

"At the end of the day, it has to be a commercial decision for BMW and any potential bidder. We will continue to work night and day to secure the best interests of the workers, their families and the West Midlands."

European Union rules on state aid necessitate lengthy examination of any government aid and a guarantee that the rescue will be viable. Brussels will also insist on a sizeable proportion of the funding for Phoenix coming from private sources, which may cause further delay.

With Phoenix executives due to hold a critical meeting today with BMW chiefs, it emerged that a No 10 aide had asked Chancellor Schröder's office to impress upon BMW the need to give the consortium every opportunity to rescue Rover and the plant in Birmingham.

BMW warned last week that failure to strike a deal within a month would result in the liquidation of Rover.

On Friday, BMW's favoured bidder for Rover, the Alchemy venture-capital fund, unexpectedly pulled out of talks to buy Longbridge. The fund said there was a "chasm" between itself and BMW on several financial issues, believed to include the costs of paying off redundant workers and compensating Rover dealers.

Alchemy had made it clear that it was interested only in manufacturing a relatively small number of sports saloons and would wind up Rover's volume car activities.

Trade unions denounced Alchemy as an asset stripper, and Mr Byers called for a solution that would maintain mass production at Longbridge.

Phoenix is headed by Rover's former chief executive, John Towers, and its backers include Rover dealers, venture capitalists and John Hemming, the software multi-millionaire and would-be Liberal Democrat mayor of Birmingham.

Mr Towers knows the bid must not rely on heavy public assistance. However, an aid package of some sort would be essential to get Longbridge back in business, possibly similar to the £152m in grants that Mr Byers was proposing to BMW before it decided to end its six-year entanglement with Rover.

Yesterday the Department of Trade and Industry confirmed that this proposal will have lapsed and that any new aid deal will need to be resubmitted to the EU for approval.

There is no "fast track" and the process could take several months.

Meanwhile sales of Rover cars soared in April amid heavy discounting. The group's market share more than doubled to top 12%.

webTitle: LA lawyers line up for copyright battle of the Blobs

fields.headline: LA lawyers line up for copyright battle of the Blobs
fields.trailText: It is red and gooey and it eats everything in its path, and it's ahhhhrgh!!! The Blob is back, and this time it's heading for the federal court.
fields.body:
It is red and gooey and it eats everything in its path, and it's ahhhhrgh!!! The Blob is back, and this time it's heading for the federal court.

In 1958 The Blob, starring a young Steve McQueen, was a spectacular drive-in-movie hit in America. It told the story of a disgusting slimey creature that devoured all it saw and threatened to gobble up an entire town.

Now another Blob, pinkish in hue, is eating up an entire town in a book called The Blob that Ate Everyone. This has prompted the film's creator to sue in the Los Angeles federal district court, arguing that the Blob is his, publication of the book should cease, and initial damages of $100,000 should be paid.

So can you copyright a blob? Should Mr Blobby be consulting his learned friends? And when does a blob become a Blob?

These are the tricky issues the court will have to resolve if the lawyers cannot agree before the trial starts.

Jack Harris says in his suit that his Blob is "a monster in the form of a reddish gooey substance which dissolved, absorbed or ingested what it came across and kept growing until it was finally stopped".

The rival in the book published by the Goosebumps suspense series also manages to eat up an entire town. But has it bitten off more than it can chew? The argument is one that followers of science fiction will be familiar with.

Can weird creatures from outer space be copyrighted unless they have a specific name? And is the use of the Blob, whose Son appeared on the screens as far back as 1971, merely an act of homage by the publishers of the book?

The sequel failed to eat up the audiences in the same way as the original, but another film called The Blob surfaced in 1988 and was described by Variety as "a great B-movie with an A-pic budget".

Quite a few people in Los Angeles might cruelly suggest that the only bloated, slimey creatures that devour everything in their path in this town are called lawyers, but more than a few sci-fi buffs will be watching with concern to see how their old friend The Blob deals with his day in court.

webTitle: Help for film makers taking on Hollywood

fields.headline: Help for film makers taking on Hollywood
fields.trailText: British films will have bigger budgets - but fewer of them will be made - in the most radical shake-up of the industry in a generation.
fields.body:
British films will have bigger budgets - but fewer of them will be made - in the most radical shake-up of the industry in a generation.

The Film Council, which will be launched this morning by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and the film director, Alan Parker, is to steer filmmakers towards making commercial movies which will be able to compete head-to-head with Hollywood.

With little more than half of the 110 films made in the UK last year ever likely to be seen in cinemas, what Mr Parker - who directed such hits as The Commitments and Bugsy Malone - has created is a powerful, hard-nosed, semi-state talent factory which will be able to pick winners and be unafraid of getting into bed with American studios.

Nearly half the council's £22m will be used to back "popular, mainstream films" - the sort which Mr Parker and fellow board member Duncan Kenworthy, who produced Four Weddings and a Funeral, tend to make, and which the public flock to the multiplexes to see. A further £4.2m will go towards European co-productions, which again is likely to be tilted towards out-and-out commercial projects.

A £5m New Cinema Fund will back more radical films, although even here the council expects the odd offbeat hit. "No one wants to make films that are only seen by the filmmakers, their families and the crew," said Mr Kenworthy. "We are about building a sustainable industry that can stand on its own feet."

The major shift of emphasis, however, is that a quarter of the budget will be spent on developing screenplays and training writers, an area in which the British industry has a woeful record.

One of the main criticisms of the previous lottery system was that films rushed into production without sufficient work on their scripts in order to qualify for lottery money.

With less than a tenth of the £105m doled out by the lottery so far recouped from successful films, something had to be done.

Although the deluge of cash sparked a boom in filmmaking, the lottery will be more remembered for turkeys like Rancid Aluminium and The Secret Laughter of Women.

There were notable successes - Lynne Ramsay's Rat catcher might never have been made without it - but its main legacy is a glut of mundane £3m films, many made without an audience in mind.

Mr Kenworthy, whose production arm DNA is one of three separate, and so far more successful mini-studios set up by the lottery, said that there was an imbalance in the British industry, with too many low-budget films. "One of the truisms of the film business is that the more money a film costs the more it is likely to make."

John Woodward, chief executive, said the new council would not be hamstrung by the arcane rules which restricted the Arts Council's lottery film board to giving money to productions that would not otherwise be made.

The lottery principle of "additionality" - which in effect filtered out those films that stood a chance of making money, by insisting that lottery funds should be in addition to existing public spending - was the first thing to go when the council was first mooted by Mr Smith.

Mr Woodward said the council wanted to be in at the beginning of projects where it could exercise the most leverage from its initial investment.

Mr Parker, the chairman, said the key was to bring on screenwriters and industry executives.

"The measures we are announcing are geared to specific priorities which must be addressed if we want the basis for a real industry producing stronger films."

Lottery losers at box office

 Stephen Poliakoff's Food of Love cost £2.1m to make (£800,000 from the lottery) but made only £1,507 at the box office.

 The Secret Laughter of Women, starring Colin Firth, cost £3.3m but took just £2,832 after getting a lottery of grant of just less than £1m.

 Los Angeles Without a Map cost £4.9m - £870,000 of which was from the lottery - but took only £ 3,641 here.

 The Last Yellow got a £500,000 lottery grant but took less than £5,000 at the box office.

 A Kind of Hush created a kind of hush by taking £5,800 despite a lottery investment of £750,000.

 The Slab Boys made £16,000 from £500,000 given by the Scottish Arts Council.

fields.headline: Valuers
fields.trailText: Valuers
fields.body:
I 'll give you a ton for that picture. Sorry?

OK. I'll make it £200. What are you on about?

Hmm. Playing hardball, eh? A monkey then. But that's my final offer. Er. I think you've got the wrong end of the stick. A valuer doesn't go around trying to buy stuff on the cheap. He or she is expected to provide an independent assessment of how much something is worth, taking into account age, condition and rarity.

Oh well. So what sort of things do you value then? The most common duties in general practice are valuations of land and property.

I get it. Location, location, location. That's estate agent speak and we're not just trying to impress potential vendors on how much they might get for their properties. We're a little more sophisticated than that, as we provide the information on which banks and building societies lend money. So we take into account the location, the state of repair and the price similar properties sell for at public auction, which is often lower than that achieved with private treaty sales.

Is that it? Far from it. We also negotiate compensation for compulsory purchases, determine fair rents and advise clients on the development potential of a piece of land. So you have to be able to understand technical drawings, be familiar with planning law, and to assess building costs. If you specialise in agricultural practice you will also be expected to be involved in and be familiar with farm management, tenants rights, the construction and repair of farm buildings, live and dead stock, cattle auctions and the markets for agricultural machinery and construction.

You make it sound just like The Archers. Are there any other media jobs going? What about those blokes on the Antiques Road Show who get to tell all those punters who have queued up for days that their family heirlooms are valueless? Yes, the job does have its perks. And yes, valuation does include fine art, antiques and various other goods and chattels for the purposes of inheritance tax, probate, insurance and sale by auction. However, these are highly specialised areas and you will probably be expected to have taken a full-time degree or diploma in fine arts valuation.

Will I have to wear a silly bow-tie, as well? No. But it wouldn't hurt if you wanted to make a career on the telly out of it.

So what else should I know? A clean driving licence is a big help. You should also be able to present ideas and information clearly, both verbally and in writing, and you must also be numerate, accurate and up to date with the relevant legislation and technology.

Are there any entry requirements? Membership of a professional body, such as the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors is strongly recommended. The Architects and Surveyors Institute will also send out information on becoming a valuer. There are also HND and degree courses in some subjects, such as estate management and surveying, that exempt you from certain professional exams. It is also possible to be trained on the job with part-time or correspondence courses?

Who will employ me? Building societies, insurance companies, property companies or any other organisation that needs information on commercial value.

So, how much will I earn? A trainee will start on £8,000-£13,000 depending on age and qualifications.

Can we call that £10,000-£15,000? No.

 The Royal Institute for Chartered Surveyors, Surveyor Court, Westwood Way, Coventry CV4 8JE Telephone: 020-7235 2282

 The Institute of Revenues, Rating & Valuation, 41 Doughty Street, London WC1N 2LF
