fields.headline: Trend setters
fields.standfirst: The concept of traditional degrees is changing radically
fields.trailText: The concept of traditional degrees is changing radically
fields.body:
"Does the new qualifications structure mean we will soon be offering degrees in line dancing?" asked the principal of a Midlands further education college at a conference in Bournemouth recently. Lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks, a former university don, replied that that was a matter for the Higher Education Quality Council.

Two developments are now turning the traditional conception of degrees upside down - and they were no doubt behind the principal's question. First, the new learning and skills bill is abolishing the distinction between vocational and non-vocational courses. Second, the government proposal for two-year foundation degrees may remove the dividing line between higher and further education. Perhaps the universities' monopoly of the degree market may soon be questioned.

In a recent radio interview, chief inspector of schools Chris Woodhead derided the pretensions of media studies to be a degree subject. He might just as well have been King Canute commanding the waves to stop coming in. Media studies is now a respected part of the higher education scene with a growing following in schools and further education colleges. In the knowledge society of the new millennium, employment prospects for media studies graduates are flourishing.

The new two-year foundation degrees could be well suited to mature students wishing to upgrade their qualifications or change career. These are the people who have been most disadvantaged by the new tuition fee structure, who do not want to spend three or four years running up loan debts. Like Scottish pound notes, foundation degrees may attract some strange looks on the other side of the counter. But so did the old DipHEs before them. Yet employers soon found DipHE students were serious and sensible: even the sociologists wore ties at job interviews. The two-year diplomas, both part and full-time, were a sound foundation for lifelong learning. As their name implies, foundation degrees could fulfil the same function.

The continual flux of the employment market increasingly has demanded professional and technological updating and re-skilling. Employees have required a varied mix of recurrent education and training in their thirties and forties, including sabbaticals, study leave and refresher courses, management and professional career development, succession planning and pre-retirement sessions. As a result, higher and further education had to be redefined.

Tomorrow the new learning centres may not be in the universities at all, but in the internet café or learning shop or library. Companies will have their learning suites online or in their sales offices. Home and college and university will be linked in one technological network so that the knowledge is shared and spread. Degrees will then come out of the cloisters and into the marketplace.

The future of vocational courses will change, too: vocationality will exist in the eye of the learner. Their duration, content and method of delivery will be variable and flexible to meet new needs of individuals and society. The old time-serving apprenticeship model is already largely dead, as even Prince Philip has realised. Following some recent seminars at Windsor, the duke has taken the initiative and urged industrialists and employers to adapt their training systems or face extinction.

Next week, by royal command, the City and Guilds qualifications body, of which he is the patron, is staging a conference on the future of work, skills and qualifications in the new era. Even the royal coachmen are now expected to take City and Guilds qualifications, and, as the recent posters advertised: "You can get to university with a City and Guilds".

So perhaps the day when the line-dancers form up on stage to receive their degree diplomas in advanced movement studies may not be long in coming.

 George Low is editor of Education Journal.

Lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks, a former university don, replied that that was a matter for the Higher Education Quality Council. fields.headline: The Guv'nor
fields.trailText: I often hear myself saying to governors that you can delegate responsibility but not accountability...
fields.body:
I often hear myself saying to governors that you can delegate responsibility but not accountability - it's true, but what a conundrum!

Essentially, accountability means a system of checks and balances that calls for the head and staff to account for what has or has not been achieved, and covers development planning, reporting, responsibilities and systems of monitoring and evaluation underpinned by open relationships.

Policy making in general should be a shared process that spells out the criteria for successful performance of the school and offers evidence of improvements in pupils' learning.

Reporting systems must be agreed with the school's head. Information is vital in judging performance, so make sure you have an agreement on what should be reported and how. All governing bodies must have a headteacher's report at least once a term. The reports should focus on monitoring progress and must also provide governors with a clear account of spending.

The governors' annual report provides an account of the school's standards of achievement. All such reporting should refer to agreed performance indicators, to assist in monitoring standards of attainment.

When it comes to responsibilities, these should be clearly defined and recorded. Systems must be agreed that monitor progress and evaluate how successfully the headteacher and staff implement policies. The results of all reviews must be shared openly with governors, and governors should know their school well enough to confirm or question the reliability of reports.

 Mary McKay is the governor training manager in Warwickshire and a governor of a primary school.

fields.headline: World trade-off
fields.standfirst: In a perfect world, all nations would have what they needed. Jerome Monahan explains the imperfections of free trade
fields.trailText: In a perfect world, all nations would have what they needed. Jerome Monahan explains the imperfections of free trade
fields.body:
All countries have to trade because no country has all it needs within its own borders. By selling (exporting) the things it has to offer, a nation gets the money to buy what it must import.

In a perfect world, trade would ensure that goods and services were evenly distributed. Countries would always get enough money from what they sold to cover their bills and ensure their populations were fed, educated, healthy and fairly paid.

Unfortunately, countries do not trade on equal terms. Those that lose out are often the ones that sell raw or "primary" materials such as coffee beans or metal ores to more industrialised countries where they are processed. Frequently, raw materials are less valuable than processed ones. This means some countries find themselves at a big disadvantage - selling commodities cheaply and importing expensive manufactured goods. It is hard for such countries not to get into debt.

Another problem arises when a country's industries cannot produce certain goods as cheaply as those of other countries. If nothing is done, imports of these items will increase, threatening the survival of home-grown industries.

One way governments can prevent this happening is through protectionism. This involves erecting trade barriers such as putting taxes on imported goods or setting quotas (limits) on how much of something can be imported.

The opposite of protectionism is free trade. In 1948, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (Gatt) was established to promote free trade among its member nations. It was very successful. Each "round" of Gatt talks resulted in reductions in world tariffs. In 1995, Gatt was replaced by the World Trade Organisation (WTO), which has even stronger powers.

Fans of the WTO see free trade as an essential force for good. If countries hide behind protectionist barriers, world trade slows and jobs are lost, or never created. People in poor countries need jobs, and if it means they have to work long hours for little pay, then that is the price that must be paid for future prosperity.

Some critics of the WTO represent the traditional industries of the world's richer nations. For them, protectionism is essential to preserve their jobs, which are being threatened now that over a third of manufactured goods are coming from developing countries where labour is cheaper.

Others are convinced free trade is of benefit mainly to the huge transnational corporations who care only for profits. In a free marketplace they can locate their industries where it suits them, holding governments to ransom with the threat that they will take their investment elsewhere.

Many also point out that big business has a poor record for protecting the environment and that one way of controlling their activities is the threat of imposing restrictions on goods whose production damages eco-systems.

The WTO does not agree. WTO meetings are becoming violent affairs. When its 135 members met in Seattle in 1999, so did huge numbers of anti-free trade protesters. This year's Washington meeting of the WTO has proved just as troubled.

fields.headline: French lessons
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor gives a roundup of French resources
fields.body:
Bonjour
***
Aimed at: everyone

You may have seen the Howard School in Rainham in the Guardian's Cool School feature recently. Teacher Stéphane Derne set it up with his pupils in mind, but plenty of the exercises and vocabulary here will be of interest to other schools. Completely bilingual, the teacher's toolbox wasn't fully operational when I last visited, but teachers should still visit the cutting and colouring page.

Sommaire des chansons
***
Aimed at: everyone

A number of traditional French songs available in midi format (playable online) and with lyrics. Parents and teachers of young children may find them particularly useful, although there are no English translations and some of the songs are distinctly dark.

ClicNet
*****
Aimed at: teachers

ClicNet is a directory of useful resources for teachers of French as a second language. One of the sections is dedicated to laughter - an excellent resource for anyone intrigued by the French sense of humour. The number of links is colossal and merits at least an hour. (In French).

Radio France
***
Aimed at: everyone

Listen to a 90-second news bulletin from Radio France. The contents are updated 42 times each day and students can replay the broadcast for listening practice.

Universal French Dictionary Online
***
Aimed at: everyone

A basic French-French dictionary, placed online for the benefit of French-speaking populations around the world. For English-French and French-English translations, try Babelfish.

Teaching with Internet FAQ
****
Aimed at: teachers

The American Association of Teachers of French has compiled a useful collection of links for teachers. The copyright information, however, draws on US law and should be treated cautiously.

Really Useful French Teaching Site
****
Aimed at: teachers

A witty, sympathetic site assembled by a teacher at a Beacon School in Lancashire. Teachers are invited to download worksheets, the cartoon adventures of photographer Victor Vaurien, and online and offline exercises.

Kolymbia Midis Sound
***
Aimed at: everyone

Don't be misled by the sight of a naked, pouting woman with only a newspaper to cover herself: it is no guide to the contents. The site holds sound files and lyrics from French pop, which you can follow on screen.

The (virtual) baguette
***
Aimed at: everyone

Despite the title, this online zine is written entirely in French and aimed at teenagers. It successfully taps into the adolescent preoccupations of music, sci-fi, TV, computers and football.

Premiers Pas sur Internet
***
Aimed at: everyone

Written for native speakers of primary age, Premiers Pas is also a useful source of stories and activities for French teachers of young children and their parents.

fields.headline: Skilled but unemployed
fields.standfirst: Low-cost courses rather than the needs of business are driving training
fields.trailText: Low-cost courses rather than the needs of business are driving training
fields.body:
Nearly two centuries after Napoleon dismissed us as a nation of shopkeepers, Professor John Field of Warwick University has accused our further education colleges of turning out a generation of florists and hairdressers. "There's nothing wrong with either profession," he said last week, "or indeed jobs in nursery nursing or leisure and tourism. But the volume of money and effort put into education in those fields is disproportionate to other areas that are vital to our future, like e-business or information technology."

On the face of it, the country's first Professor of Lifelong Learning - as Field was on his appointment in 1998 - is at odds with the government's targets for ever-expanding education for the over-16s. Constant expansion, he argues, means nothing if many students are being encouraged to enrol on courses that are of little use either to themselves or to society.

"At the moment, well over a third of those who enter further education don't gain a qualification," he says. "Colleges are working hard to bring that figure down. But until we have an achievement rate closer to 80% or 90% than 60%, what's the point of encouraging more to come in? I do think the government is right to seek to improve the skills level of the population. But much more attention needs to be paid to setting up an accessible, flexible and high-quality system whereby skills and qualifications can be gained in the workplace."

He cites Germany and the Republic of Ireland as having schemes that are models of good practice. Both offer apprenticeships with either block-release or day-release college courses. But surely there were similar apprenticeships operating in this country until 20 years ago?

"There were," he says, "and there were problems with them. The biggest problem of all, though, is that they were killed off with nothing adequate put in their place. This government has inherited those problems but it hasn't yet come to terms with the scale of them. If a quality, national, work-based system was set up, a lot of employers would sign up for it. As it is, many of them are unhappy about the standard of recruits coming through the present system."

He quotes approvingly, however, from a government report by its national skills task force when it pinpoints a major flaw in the funding system: "If a college can achieve its funding units by training large numbers of nursery nurses or GNVQ leisure and tourism students, then it can do so regardless of whether there is a demand for such skills. At the same time, colleges struggle to respond to demands from employees for short courses which may be highly significant for the local economy."

In other words, further education is being driven by the funding system rather than by business. "As a college," Field goes on to explain, "it's strongly in your interest to have a lot of activity in low-cost areas. That's why courses in floristry and hairdressing are flourishing and those like computer-aided design, which require a high level of tutor support, are not."

But the cost of "pretending that the problem doesn't exist," as Field puts it, would be to fall further behind some of our major competitors.

fields.headline: Quite a performance
fields.trailText: The Forest Gate 2000 project is taking the performing arts to young people in east London
fields.body:
Whilst the number of black men amongst our leading ballet dancers continues to grow, there are still comparatively few black women who choose to take up this career. But the ranks of the latter may be set to swell by at least one, thanks to the Forest Gate 2000 project, based in inner-city east London and funded in part by a millennium lottery grant. As a result of the project, Dionne Sakupwanya, aged 12, is set to audition for the Royal Ballet School.

The aim of this project is to get some of Britain's most "happening" performers to help the young people and their families who live in one of England's poorest areas by promoting educational success and boosting pupils' self-esteem through the performing arts. This has involved the youngsters in sessions on rap, hip-hop, jazz, artwork, producing a world cookbook, theatre, storytelling, making a film about the project and a variety of different dance forms.

Pupils can then confront prejudices - both their own and that of society at large - about "culture" in general, and look at the increasingly influential part played by members of the ethnic minorities. The climax of the project was to be in December 2000, when all the activities over the course of this year would culminate in a multi-media production. This is now in jeopardy unless further funding for the project can be found urgently.

Some 1,300 pupils, including hundreds from five local primary schools, participated in one element of the project, the "Dance Taster" fortnight held at Stratford secondary school in Newham. Pupils aged nine to 16 were introduced to dance with African roots in the first week, and south Asian dance in the second. Visiting artists included Jonzi D, a hip-hop artist who has worked in many places, including Soweto in South Africa; Mavin Khoo, one of the highest profile south Asian dancers in Britain today, and Ben Love who is a teacher with the Royal Ballet School.

Love was so impressed by Dionne, who is a pupil at Stratford, that he urged her to audition for the Royal Ballet School. If successful, Dionne would be one of only a few black women to dance with the company. Dionne is unfazed by the prospect of pirouettes and tutus - when asked if she was looking forward to the chance of trying some ballet, she replied "I'll give it a try"!

 Anyone wishing to find out more about the Forest Gate 2000 project can contact Lisa Warshaw, fund-raiser and director, on 020-8471 4684. The Royal Ballet School is keen to recruit all young people who have talent and commitment, and can be contacted on 020-8748 6335.

webTitle: It's new, but what exactly is it?

fields.headline: It's new, but what exactly is it?
fields.standfirst: John Beckett finds confusion over the new curriculum wherever he looks
fields.trailText: John Beckett finds confusion over the new curriculum wherever he looks
fields.body:
The phrase "a little slow in coming forward" may have its place in school reports, but it also applies to the speed at which universities are publicly embracing the new curriculum.

Whilst most university vice-chancellors have broadly welcomed the 16-19 qualifications reform, few have spelt out what the implications for university admissions might be.

Students will be embarking on the new curriculum this September. For the past six months they and their parents have been seeking, often with little success, information and guidance on their post-16 studies. At the same time, schools and colleges have been struggling to work out how to deliver the new curriculum with its many resource and financial implications. And the feeling that there is an unawareness amongst university admissions tutors has persisted.

The reforms aim to provide school and college leavers with a broader range of qualifications more suited to higher education, the workplace and society. Instead of concentrating on traditional A levels, 16- and 17-year-olds will be able to follow a broader mix of subjects, including the vocational GNVQs. This will enable students to cross the perceived divide between academic and vocational study.

Advanced subsidiary levels (AS levels), designed to encourage breadth, flexibility and better progression from GCSE, will form the first half of an A-level programme, and some of these will be studied to A level at the end of the second year.

It is thought that four AS levels and three A levels will become a common combination. GNVQs will be offered as full, half or part awards and so can be studied in combination with A and AS levels. In addition, the study and assessment of the key skills of communication, application of number and information technology become part of the post-16 curriculum. Advanced extension awards are being designed.

Immediately it is clear that there are many issues for progression onto higher education. How many AS levels will be required and should they all be studied in year 12? Will universities make offers based on AS results, assuming a correlation between them and eventual A-level grades? How will they view the reformed GNVQ, especially in conjunction with AS and A-level subjects? What will be the attitude to key skills? Will the difficulties and subsequent differences in schools and colleges offering post-16 programmes be taken into account?

The response from higher education has been patchy. Cambridge, UCL, York and Bristol were the first out of the starting blocks with statements in late 1999. Others, including Swansea, Aston and Middlesex have followed in recent months.

UCL expects offers to be based on three A levels and a pass in a fourth subject at AS (or three-unit GNVQ). They will not demand the key skills certificate, but will expect evidence of a range of key skills in a personal statement and at a later interview.

Cambridge's guidelines incorporate the hope that candidates will have studied four or five subjects in year 12, with at least one in a contrasting discipline. As with UCL and Oxford, key skills certification will not be required; advanced extension levels are welcomed.

Oxford colleges will be flexible in their attitude where different patterns of qualifications occur and will give serious consideration to every applicant. Goldsmiths also recognises the "heavy burden on resources" placed on schools with the reforms and promises not to disadvantage their students. Their intention of continuing to encourage students from a variety of different backgrounds, cultures and interests is clearly stated. Both Leeds and Newcastle expect offers to be conditional on year 13 achievement as at present. Both welcome the inclusion of key skills in the curriculum, Newcastle adding: "We may require successful completion as part of the offer made."

Universities seem to be equally cautious about the reformed GNVQ, although Goldsmiths does state: "We will continue to consider all vocational awards."

There have been other more general concerns, both about academic quality (greater breadth at the expense of depth) and the lack of time for extracurricular activities. Some colleges will be unable to provide advanced extension levels. Also there are worries that the academic-vocational divide in higher education might actually be widened by the new structures.

Last December, Ucas announced the new tariff, an attempt to unify all post-16 qualifications in the applications process. Some universities appeared to immediately reject the system in favour of continuing to make grade offers. This does throw a shadow over the relevance of the reforms in 16-19 education for higher education.

Whilst most university vice-chancellors have broadly welcomed the 16-19 qualifications reform, few have spelt out what the implications for university admissions might be. Students will be embarking on the new curriculum this September. For the past six months they and their parents have been seeking, often with little success, information and guidance on their post-16 studies. At the same time, schools and colleges have been struggling to work out how to deliver the new curriculum with its many resource and financial implications. And the feeling that there is an unawareness amongst university admissions tutors has persisted. The reforms aim to provide school and college leavers with a broader range of qualifications more suited to higher education, the workplace and society. Instead of concentrating on traditional A levels, 16- and 17-year-olds will be able to follow a broader mix of subjects, including the vocational GNVQs. This will enable students to cross the perceived divide between academic and vocational study. Advanced subsidiary levels (AS levels), designed to encourage breadth, flexibility and better progression from GCSE, will form the first half of an A-level programme, and some of these will be studied to A level at the end of the second year. It is thought that four AS levels and three A levels will become a common combination. GNVQs will be offered as full, half or part awards and so can be studied in combination with A and AS levels. In addition, the study and assessment of the key skills of communication, application of number and information technology become part of the post-16 curriculum. Advanced extension awards are being designed. Immediately it is clear that there are many issues for progression onto higher education. How many AS levels will be required and should they all be studied in year 12? Will universities make offers based on AS results, assuming a correlation between them and eventual A-level grades? How will they view the reformed GNVQ, especially in conjunction with AS and A-level subjects? What will be the attitude to key skills? They will not demand the key skills certificate, but will expect evidence of a range of key skills in a personal statement and at a later interview. As with UCL and Oxford, key skills certification will not be required; advanced extension levels are welcomed. Oxford colleges will be flexible in their attitude where different patterns of qualifications occur and will give serious consideration to every applicant. Goldsmiths also recognises the "heavy burden on resources" placed on schools with the reforms and promises not to disadvantage their students. Their intention of continuing to encourage students from a variety of different backgrounds, cultures and interests is clearly stated. fields.headline: Oprah understood
fields.standfirst: The University of Alberta is running a course on the female star
fields.trailText: The University of Alberta is running a course on the female star
fields.body:
Oprah Winfrey, the ubiquitous American television chat-show host, has entered the academic canon. Reading Oprah, a new fourth-year undergraduate course at the University of Alberta, in Canada, examines themes ranging from the celebrity's performances in the movies The Color Purple and Beloved, the cultural significance of her role as a television presenter and even her diet and exercise book.

The course concludes with an Oprah exam, in which students create an edition of The Oprah Winfrey Show complete with a detailed proposal and a guest lineup. Reading Oprah comes at a time when some students on both sides of the Atlantic will be doing just that - if their bookstores stock The Oprah Magazine, whose first issue appears in the US and Britain this month.

The magazine maintains that one can and should feel better about oneself - "This magazine is about helping you become more of who you are," says Winfrey's introductory note. There are many references to overeating, and in a nine-page interview she talks to the wife of actor Bill Cosby, Camille, about menopause and the pain of learning to love oneself.

The three-month-long course is the brainchild of Daphne Read, an associate professor of English, and springs from its instructor's interest in women's studies, group counselling and African-American literature. Elements of all three are present in the televisual persona of Winfrey, says Read. What the programme attempts, she says, is to "encourage people to go beyond the normal knee-jerk response to Oprah, positive or negative, and take a look at her on a deeper level."

Reading Oprah was sparked by an afternoon spent in Edmonton watching the programme. Soon afterwards, she recalls, "I was back at the university talking with a couple of colleagues about how bright and vital I thought she was. 'Somebody should do a course on her,' I said. My colleagues said I sounded like the person to do it - so I did."

Reading Oprah made its debut late last year, attracting 23 participants, two of them men. Students examined the "works" of Winfrey and, says Read, sought to locate her personality "within a larger intellectual and activist context, tracing her explicit and implicit affiliations with contemporary African American intellectuals and casting her self-help work in a more politicised historical framework".

Contemporary feminism, says Read, "has many strands, but among all of them there is this issue of reaching out beyond the converted, of getting to a wider audience. And Oprah, for me and others, is somebody who's doing this."

And trousering lots of loot along the way. By the reckoning of Forbes magazine, Winfrey's personal worth currently stands at £420m. Ironically enough, perhaps, a portion of that income has come from academe. Last year she taught a course on the dynamics of leadership at Northwestern University in Chicago, during which she was an adjunct professor of management and strategy. She has also been known to give academics a boost - in 1997 exposure on her programme's book club turned Stones From the River, written by the American scholar Ursula Hegi, into a respectable national seller.

In these other ways, Read believes, "Oprah has presence - and yes, that comes from having economic power. But she uses this to promote a coherent social vision. What she does is encourage people to think critically, at least in terms of where they're at. And that's what I've tried to do with this course."

fields.headline: Mayoral vision
fields.standfirst: Graham Lane  says a London mayor has a crucial role to play in higher education
fields.trailText: Graham Lane says a London mayor has a crucial role to play in higher education
fields.body:
Few people realise that the London mayor will not actually run anything. None of the candidates have appreciated that the mayor will be there to influence matters and have little or no executive power.

Education has not featured in the candidates' statements so far but the issues which concern Londoners are jobs, education and training, housing needs and travel. Schools remain the responsibility of the boroughs with heads and governors managing most of the daily decisions. The mayor will have some role in London schools and will be involved in teacher recruitment and retention issues but, on the whole, school matters will be a more local issue.

London is in a chaotic state over education and training, post 16. There are colleges, school sixth-forms - many of them too small to offer any kind of adequate curriculum - and training agencies all competing for a varied and complex market. The result is that many young people receive poor careers advice and find it difficult to access the most suitable course for themselves. Also many courses are not related to the needs of London and the employment situation.

Unemployment is very high in many areas of London with many jobs not being filled because people do not have the relevant skills.

While the city requires highly skilled staff, particularly in the high tech sector, there remain thousands of adults who left school without basic skills.

In Newham, recently, Safeway tried to recruit local people to work in a new supermarket, but 60% failed a simple numeracy test. In the borough unemployment has fallen below 10% for the first time in 25 years mainly due to the new deal arrangements. But throughout London there are no serious planning arrangements to match training opportunities to employment.

That is where the mayor will find a crucial role. The new learning and skills councils are appointed by the secretary of state for education, David Blunkett. There will be five for London but someone will have to get them to work together. That role can only be filled by the mayor. Bringing together the learning skills councils and the boroughs, insisting on a comprehensive careers service for all young people and adults and making sure that employment policies are connected to the education agenda is the mayor's chance to make a difference for Londoners.

The other need is to have a consistent system of financial student support that is not based on where you happen to live or on the decisions made by the educational institution you are in.

The mayor should be able to negotiate a London-wide special travel scheme for all students. It is not unusual for students to run up annual bills of £500 simply getting to college. Maintenance grants, especially for poorer students, are also essential if participation is to happen on an equitable basis. A mayor could ensure that all the different agencies including national government, the benefit agencies, educational institutions and local councils all work together to provide a coherent student support system which removes the barriers from preventing students participating in education and training courses.

London attracts many young people to live here and their needs are bound up with training, jobs and affordable housing.

The mayor will have to address the role of higher education by bringing institutions into a democratic framework. This will be a challenge, especially as there are some which are making themselves even more elitist by charging top-up fees. However, many higher education institutions, especially the former polytechnics, have a reliable record of catering for local people.

The mayor and the assembly members will have little executive power but their influence could extend much further than the average London MP.

In particular, they will have a mandate to deal with the European parliament, which has the power to allocate considerable financial resources to London. If central government was foolish enough to deny matching funding to any European grant for London, the mayor would have the considerable weight of the local electorate behind him to pressurise for action.

 Graham Lane is an education leader for local government.

fields.headline: Further behind
fields.standfirst: Francis Beckett  on how FE teachers' pay was pushed to the bottom of the heap
fields.trailText: Francis Beckett on how FE teachers' pay was pushed to the bottom of the heap
fields.body:
This month Natfhe begins the annual struggle to persuade colleges that starvation doesn't improve teaching standards.

FE teachers really are the paupers of the education system. The best paid get 8% less than the pittance paid to schoolteachers. More than half of them get even less, because they work in colleges that were too stingy to implement last year's miserable award.

It was not always thus. Once, some years ago, university lecturers noticed to their horror that their pay had been overtaken by that of some college lecturers. They marched down Whitehall to lobby their MPs, carrying banners that expressed with academic precision their sense of grievance. The banners bore the memorable slogan: Rectify the Anomaly. (I am not sure whether anyone tried to chant it.)

So what, or who, pushed FE teachers to the bottom of the heap? Mostly, Roger Ward, who used to run the employers' organisation, the Association of Colleges, until newspapers revealed that a relationship with a commercial supplier of services to colleges was, well, unwise. So he started a restaurant in the north London street where Natfhe's chief FE negotiator, Sue Berryman, lives.

She ran into him the other day. He was putting a brass plate on the door of his restaurant. He boasted to her that he'd just sold his Hampstead home for well over £1m and was opening a chain of restaurants. What was she doing? She said she was getting a few agreements with the Association of Colleges. "You'd never have got them in my day," said Roger, and flashed her his wide, friendly grin.

I once thought Ward was amusing, a card. In his enormous office, opposite his huge black desk, he and I sat on his deep black leather-covered sofa, beside his famous black fridge where he kept his champagne, and I interviewed him while La Bohème boomed out of the state-of-the-art sound system.

I asked him about the time in a Blackpool hotel when he had a bottle of champagne delivered to the top table in a silver bucket. He said: "I was saying, look, boys and girls, understand from day one that if you're going to employ Roger, you're going to enter a world which is very different, more upfront."

Some of the college principals badly wanted to hear that message. They began to treat themselves to executive-level salaries and jet-setting lifestyles with public money and at the expense of their staff, who were bullied into submission, and for whom teaching became an impoverishing experience.

Today, in deference to the spirit of the times, college principals like to tell you that it's all different. There's a caring, sharing spirit in the air. But until they put right the scandal of lecturers' pay, they are still tolerating the legacy of the past.

I look forward eagerly to the day that Ms Berryman emerges from negotiations wreathed in smiles. "Listen, comrades," she'll say. "I've got you double pay, and you only have to work on Fridays." And, the atmosphere having truly changed, someone will shout: "What, every bloody Friday?"

Meanwhile, I thought of suggesting that FE lecturers boycott Ward's restaurant, but none of them could afford to eat there.

fields.headline: The one and only
fields.standfirst: John Beckett on writing a fantastic personal statement
fields.trailText: John Beckett on writing a fantastic personal statement
fields.body:
Anyone planning to apply to higher education will find themselves having to write a 500-word personal statement. Not an easy prospect - especially when the aim is to persuade someone you've never met to offer you a place at their university.

So if you're a 2001 entrant, you need to start thinking about it now.

The trouble is that there is no right or wrong way to write this essay. Just getting started can be a major problem - putting pen to paper, or digit to keyboard somehow defeats many at this stage.

The best way to overcome that initial stage fright is to start by compiling a "headline" list of what to include. The major ingredients of your essay will be the reasons for choosing your proposed course in higher education, accompanied by evidence that you are a keen, well-motivated student in your current studies. There should also be a section on what keeps you busy outside your time spent in pursuit of qualifications.

The area an admissions tutor will automatically look at is the reasoning behind your choice of course. "I want to study law because I want to become a lawyer" is unlikely, on its own, to persuade an academic to send out an unconditional offer by return of post. Likewise, "medicine is my chosen profession as I have never missed an episode of ER".

This section, usually forming the opening paragraph, must include some substance and show that you've done thorough research and know what the course is all about.

For vocational degrees this is especially important. Here, relevant work experience can be desirable if not essential, together with an obvious desire to study the academic subject. Even if your current studies do not relate directly to the course you've chosen, you should still attempt to describe what you do in a positive way. An interested and involved attitude to study (especially if backed up by your reference!) always looks good on a personal statement.

Special lectures, summer schools or courses you have attended are also musts for inclusion. Extra study you undergo in addition to your A level or GNVQ coursework should also find its way onto the form.

Describing what makes you tick gives an academic the chance to see you as a fully rounded person, so don't hold back on detailing your interests and how you fill your time, avoiding an overemphasis on partying and sleeping, of course!

You are trying to sell yourself so be positive and honest - bending the truth is fine as long as you can justify, at an interview, what you've written. Innovative ways of expressing yourself will attract attention - avoid starting all your sentences with "I like" or "I enjoy". "I am an Irish Roman Catholic who believes in the power of Guinness rather than the Pope" was a somewhat unusual and risky opening sentence to a personal statement, but it certainly got the reader's attention!

 John Beckett is a higher education adviser.

fields.headline: In your image
fields.standfirst: John Crace on a scheme that supports innovative art teaching and learning
fields.trailText: John Crace on a scheme that supports innovative art teaching and learning
fields.body:
It's the moment the visitors to the Chardin exhibition at the Royal Academy have clearly been dreading. They don't say anything, mind, because gallery types are far too polite. But you can tell from the lowered lids and clamped teeth that an invasion of 30 pupils from year 6 of the Nicholas Hawksmoor Primary School in Towcester is not exactly their idea of a good time. Not that any of the schoolchildren either notice, or would care if they did, as they beetle round the gallery with a naive enthusiasm that is completely at odds with the more self-conscious attitudes struck by the adult visitors.

Art has an image problem in this country. It tends to be seen either as the sacred refuge of a middle-class intelligentsia or as the playground for would-be bohemians who imagine that an alternative lifestyle equates to creativity. Either way, it exudes an exclusivity, a sense of a professional in-crowd with a monopoly on taste and culture. So you know that the gut-felt reactions to the still lifes and portraits that are so obvious in many of the 10- and 11-year-olds will be hammered out of all but a very few within the next 10 years.

Or maybe not, if Artworks, the new national children's art awards, has anything to do with it. In recent years art has taken a back seat in most schools, due to the pressures of fitting literacy and numeracy initiatives into an already over-crowded timetable. Artworks, which was launched last November by the culture secretary Chris Smith and the philanthropist Vivien Duffield, aims to redress the balance by recognising distinctive and innovative teaching and learning in art, which demonstrates the benefits of experiencing works of art.

The awards fall into three categories: group projects, motivated individuals and gallery partnerships. Unsurprisingly, it's the last for which the Nicholas Hawksmoor school is entered and explains their appearance at the RA.

"We're submitting a project on portraits, called Faces of Ages," says Marilyn Barnes, deputy head and art co-ordinator. "The school is decorated with the children's portraits, some based on the work of Paul Klee, others on Picasso and Seurat, inspired by trips to London galleries. In one year, for example, each child is working on a series of different self-portraits - the first as the child sees him or herself now, and then the rest visualising themselves as a pop star, a diva and belonging to a different race.

"Today we've brought year 6 to London for the Chardin exhibition in the morning and this afternoon we'll be walking around Covent Garden looking at statues. The national curriculum wants 3D art to be taken as seriously as 2D, so I'm hoping the children will get new perspectives on faces by learning what they look like from the back and the side."

For a few of the kids the trip is little more than an authorised day off school, and they are having a laugh and doing the bare minimum to keep the teacher happy. Barnes is more than aware of this, but reckons that even a passive exposure to art, along with the sights and sounds of a busy city, makes the trip worthwhile. The others pencil away assiduously, never less than competently and, just occasionally, outstandingly.

One such is Rhodri, a dead ringer for the angelic schoolboy in any advert you care to mention. His drawings have a depth and sophistication well beyond what you expect from his age, and when he talks about them it is obvious there is a considered emotional connection between what he has seen and what he has drawn.

"I've sketched The Draughtsman," he says. "You can only see his back, but you can easily imagine his face. I picture him to be silent and lonely, concentrating hard on what he is doing. A bit like Chardin himself." Louise, too, has an eye for the unusual. "I particularly like the shading on Soap Bubbles," she says. "The bubble has the shine of a real bubble. Art has an image problem in this country. It tends to be seen either as the sacred refuge of a middle-class intelligentsia or as the playground for would-be bohemians who imagine that an alternative lifestyle equates to creativity. fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: I seem to have raised a couple of couch potatoes. How can I persuade them to get some physical exercise?
fields.body:
I seem to have raised a couple of couch potatoes who watch TV or play on the computer as long as they can. Without coming on all "heavy", how can I persuade them to get some physical exercise - at the moment, they seem to view this with something approaching disgust!

John Matthews is chief executive of the Physical Education Association of the United Kingdom.

The key is to get youngsters involved in exercise as young as possible - and for them to see it as a fun, enjoyable way to spend their time. The best way is to keep it simple, and involve the whole family. Too often it is tempting to overlook the basics in pursuit of the "organised" activity.

What about a walk in the local park, woods or along the beach? How about hopping on your bikes for the afternoon? Is there anywhere for a football to be kicked around or a tennis ball chucked about safely? These are all straightforward, cheap and accessible ways of getting your "couch potatoes" outside and active. Positive attitudes stay with us - physical activity is fun!

It is an unfortunate fact of life that many parents/guardians feel uncomfortable about letting their children out unaccompanied, due to fears over strangers and traffic. But this just makes it all the more compelling for you to go out as a family to enjoy some exercise. Studies have proved that seeing one or both parents/guardians exercising in some way has a positive effect on children towards getting active themselves.

And don't forget it doesn't have to be regimented - savour the spontaneity of a sunny spring day and all go for a walk, or provide opportunities for your children to simply mess about outside. This could be before tea/supper, bath time, or some other set activity so that playing becomes a period of free and independent time for your children, and enjoyable for that very reason alone. This way you can gently lead your children into exercise as a leisure pursuit, not a chore.

As an association, we try to push the message that providing good quality, enjoyable opportunities for children when they are very young will make it a lot easier to encourage them when they are teenagers to continue in some kind of exercise. It is a message that we would hope physical education departments in schools are also promoting.

It may be worth investigating what is offered at your son's/daughter's school in terms of sports clubs. Help to make it easier for your child to attend any that they show even the vaguest interest in - or less easy for them to make an excuse not to go! For example, perhaps offer to collect them afterwards, but don't be too heavy about it. Try to keep your approach as casual as possible. After all, your child - especially if he/she is a teenager - may well feel that it is rather "uncool" to go to a sports club, and mum or dad openly encouraging them may well confirm this!

If this is not an option, investigate the possibilities at your local sports or leisure club. They may well do "taster" courses on a range of sports - many of which might not be available in schools - and if you can afford it these are an excellent way for children to explore their interests. Some also run "turn up and play" sessions. These are very informal. No special kit or equipment is necessary, nor long-term commitment to a training programme, etc.

Your local sports development officer would also be able to suggest what unusual activities are available in your area. For example, indoor rock climbing is an increasingly popular activity, and can often appeal to those youngsters for whom the more traditional sports are a bit of a turn-off. In general, think beyond the "norm" and go with the interests of your children. Something like an adventure holiday will not make up for a year's inactivity, of course, but it could spark the imagination of your child and prompt them to get involved in a club when they get home.

For those who are not very interested in team games, but who would benefit from a sense of team spirit, see whether your school or a local youth centre are involved in the Duke of Edinburgh scheme.

But, remember, it doesn't need to be expensive or complicated - and it is most successful if exercise is encouraged at a young age and becomes a family event.

Next week's query: We've given in to our children's badgering and bought a computer, but worry that our children won't get the most out of the internet. We know there are lots of educational websites, but don't know where to look for them. We don't want our kids to use the internet as a shortcut to complete homework, etc. Can you offer any useful guidelines on this?

fields.headline: French lessons
fields.standfirst: A new report suggests that while French children appear to value their education more than English pupils, our creative schoolchildren are better equipped for business
fields.trailText: A new report suggests that while French children appear to value their education more than English pupils, our creative schoolchildren are better equipped for business
fields.body:
Teachers in England are losing their vision and becoming increasingly more formal and authoritarian in their approach to teaching, according to a new study. They are, in short, becoming more like the French.

The research carried out by Quest (the Quality of Education: Children's Experiences of Schooling in England and France) and led by Patricia Broadfoot, Professor of Education at Bristol University and co-author of Promoting Quality in Learning: Does England have the answer? suggests that by adopting an educational system which mirrors the French one, Britain will cease to produce a workforce of team players and lateral thinkers.

Although, according to the French government, there are now more than 250,000 French people living and working in Britain, Broadfoot and her team argue that the English education system is actually becoming very much like the French one in its constant quest for academic excellence. The project highlights the unique benefits of education in Britain and suggests that for the British economy to succeed in the global market, these strengths must be maintained.

The Quest team compares the opinions and outlook of British and French children between nine and 11, and challenges the dominant belief that the French educational system is innately better than its British counterpart. "One of the significant differences between English and French children is that English children are a lot more confident when it comes to thinking on their feet, they are very good at knowing what to do when they don't know what to do," says Broadfoot. "Although French children are significantly more positive about school, they are subjected to a much more formal, authoritarian approach to teaching and this can often be very constricting."

Broadfoot and her team believe that this raises questions about the benefits of many of the current educational reforms being introduced by the government. By limiting the role of the teachers to the very narrow boundaries of the classroom, the researchers feel that the education system will suffer. "The French teacher's goal is quite simply that pupils should master the material being taught, whereas English teachers place a lot more emphasis on encouraging children to think for themselves, they are also more active in promoting understanding and knowledge through problem-solving," says Broadfoot.

The researchers believe that education plays a different role in different societies and this is likely to affect motivation as much as pupils' experience at school. The Quest team discovered that French children were significantly more positive about school than their British counterparts and were "more likely to see teaching as helpful and useful to them even though the classroom was typically more formal and authoritarian".

While only 35% of English children were proud of their nationality, 57% of French children felt glad that they were French. The research also found that French children were a lot less concerned with the personal characteristics of their teachers and thought that a good quality in a teacher was that they would make their pupils work hard.

Parent of three Jo Putler has had experience of both the French and English education systems and believes that Britain is increasingly adopting a more continental approach in both primary and secondary education. "With the increased rigidity of the national curriculum, the English education system is becoming very much like the French one; however, French teachers are a lot more comfortable with their system because it has been in place for years," says Putler.

The Putlers lived in a small French village for a year during 1987. "The children were educated at the village school and there was a lot of sitting in rows and teaching by the book, especially in grammar and handwriting. However, they also had the opportunity to do extra-curricular activities. The teacher would take them out on country walks to elaborate on the science and geography lessons," remembers Putler.

After moving back to England, the Putlers decided to send their children to London's French Lycée. "The Lycée is very old-fashioned in its approach to teaching and the children are not offered much in the way of creative writing, but I don't think it is typical of all French schools," says Putler.

Sam Banner, a French language teacher at a state comprehensive in Birmingham, believes that French education is generally more narrow in its scope than in Britain. Having taught in Aix-en-Provence for two years, she believes that "although French children generally seem a lot keener to benefit from their education they are limited in their ability to take risks and experiment." Banner thinks that "French teachers see their teaching role as one which should focus on good results; although British teachers do this, they tend not to be so strict, they encourage the children to experiment to a greater extent."

The study documents the achievements of British children and although the researchers admit that there are weaknesses in certain areas, they emphasise that there are also many strengths. "The study highlights the fact that British children are trailing behind in their mathematical skills, but they are holding their own in writing, grammar and spelling, and they are excellent in thinking for themselves and being creative. This is something which the French children lack," says Broadfoot. "A lot of improvements have been made to the standard of British education recently, but it is important that we look to the future and do not get tied down with relentless testing and the quest for better results at the expense of losing the unique talents of British teachers."

Jean-Michel Fouquet, headmaster of the Charles de Gaulle French Lycée in London, thinks that it is important not to exaggerate the differences between the two systems. "Both the English and French systems are much less clear-cut than they once were," says Fouquet. "It is true that some of the more creative aspects of teaching may not be implemented in French schools, especially in subjects like science and mathematics, but things are changing and French teachers are listening to what their pupils have to say to a greater extent."

Fouquet believes that the French system is more rigid when it comes to the levels of attainment of its pupils. "French children are very structured in what they achieve each school year. For example, any French child could go to any French school and learn exactly the same thing wherever he or she was. Equally, if you were to go into any French school on any day of the week, the teachers would be teaching exactly the same thing to the same year group."

All too often the British education system is seen as the poor cousin of other countries within western Europe and beyond. However, the Quest team is keen to stress the importance of many aspects of the British system. "Whilst other countries have been the envy of the world in the capacity of their students to achieve on conventional tests of achievement, it is these same countries that are now desperate to find ways of encouraging their students to be creative problem-solvers, team-workers and risk-takers," says Broadfoot. "It is these skills which will determine the economic tigers of tomorrow."

When Napoleon Bonaparte remarked that the British were a nation of shopkeepers, he may well have been referring to the entrepreneurial spirit and creativity that underpin the economy and which Broadfoot believes must be kept alive in British schools.

 Promoting Quality in Learning: Does England have the answer? Patricia Broadfoot, Marilyn Osborn, Claire Planel and Keith Sharpe, Cassel, £16.99.

fields.headline: Locked out
fields.standfirst: Large sections of society are still being denied access to higher education. Brian Roper, Alistair Ross and Dave Thomson propose ways of measuring inequality and social exclusion
fields.trailText: Large sections of society are still being denied access to higher education. Brian Roper, Alistair Ross and Dave Thomson propose ways of measuring inequality and social exclusion
fields.byline: Brian Roper, Alistair Ross and Dave Thomson
fields.body:
David Blunkett's speech at Greenwich called for universities to "contribute to social justice on a sustained, sector-wide basis". We are enjoined to "pursue wider social inclusion as an institutional objective" in which "success must be understood and measured by how far institutions serve the population as a whole", which he then spelt out as meaning all social classes, all ethnic groups, at all stages of their lives.

The track record of the university sector in achieving social inclusion has, to date, been woefully inadequate. It could even be argued that universities have become even more socially divisive than they were before the Robbins report in 1963. Between 1928 and 1947, some 8.9% of all boys from non-manual backgrounds entered university, compared to 1.4% of all boys from manual backgrounds. By the time of Robbins, 16.8% of boys from non-manual backgrounds entered higher education, and 2.6% of boys from manual backgrounds (data on the background of women students does not seem to have been reported).

The expansion of the past decade has made it even more likely that the higher socio-economic group participate in higher education: 80% of children from social class one backgrounds attend university, while less than one in eight children from an unskilled manual background enters higher education.

What of gender equality? Whilst the earlier under-representation of women in higher education overall has been rectified, there remain major gender inequalities in many subjects: for example, insufficient men taking education courses, too few women in science and engineering. The incorporation of ethnic minorities into higher education shows a similar erratic pattern. What appears overall to be a major change as substantial numbers of ethnic minorities enter higher education, masks the exclusion of particular groups - Bangladeshi females, African-Caribbean males - as well as the fact that they are particularly concentrated in a few universities.

This is a system - as Blunkett says - of "the entrenched exclusion of large sections of our society from higher education". Universities are now reproducing social inequality more efficiently than they ever have in the past. They have replaced the grammar school as the prime instrument of entrenching social stratification.

Lord Dearing pointed out in the National Committee of Inquiry into Higher Education that higher education was not powerless to affect the participation rates of under-represented groups. The Hefce Performance Indicators in Higher Education 1996-98, which were produced last December, were supposed to offer a measure of the extent to which different institutions were addressing social exclusion. However, they did this through setting individual "benchmarks" for each institution, based simply on the degree of social inclusion that might be expected given the particular entry qualifications of their current students.

This amounts to saying that if an institution only takes students with very high A level grades, then it can't be expected to take on many students from the lower socio-economic classes, or students from ethnic minority backgrounds. The Hefce tables for the participation of under-represented groups are simply an acceptance of the status quo, and are being used to justify inaction.

The excuse offered is that our universities have diverse missions, and thus cannot be directly compared: this apparently allows some universities to have a mission that does not address questions of social inclusion.

We propose to construct alternative measures of the role of individual universities in contributing to social inclusion.

Dearing included amongst the purposes of universities the promotion of social cohesion and the development of lifelong learning and the creation of "the learning society", as well as economic regeneration and development. Blunkett has echoed this in his Greenwich speech. We propose the creation of three new scales to measure how much each area of each university's work contributes to these objectives.

First, we propose to measure added social inclusion: how much does each institution, in each subject band, contribute to the inclusion of all socio-economic groups and of all ethnic groups, in a gender-neutral manner?

We know that overall, universities recruit males and females equally, but we should be measuring success in this area in terms of balances in each subject band, not in gross terms.

Compare two hypothetical institutions, each recruiting only engineers and teachers:

Institution A appears to do better overall than institution B: but given the overall national gender imbalance in undergraduate numbers in these two subjects, institution B is in reality doing a better job at addressing under-representation. What is needed is a measure that reflects which groups are under-represented in each area in higher education, compared to the distribution of each group in the 18-30 year-old population of the country. If there are 51% of females of student age in the country, then we should expect to find that proportion in each subject area in the higher education sector.

We will determine - by gender, ethnicity and social class - the distribution of young people receiving higher education in each subject grouping, and compare this to the distribution of the same groups in the population of young people in the country as a whole. Where there is a shortfall, we will then determine which institutions are recruiting to address that shortfall, weighting each contribution according to the degree that the group is under-represented in the higher education population.

To develop the example above, assume that the proportion of male to female engineers in higher education undergraduate courses across the country is 80:20, and in education courses is 30:70.

The difference between the population as a whole and the percentage of students in the higher education sector in the subject indicates where the under-representation lies, and its magnitude.

In engineering, there is a 31% shortfall of females, in education, there is a shortfall of 19% males. We therefore weight each of these students according to how much they are not represented in the total higher education population.

In our measurement system, institutions that successfully recruit these under-represented groups are rewarded by multiplying the percentage that they recruit by the degree of under-representation. Thus, in our two hypothetical institutions, institution A, even though it has a 50:50 male/female split, emerges with no points, while institution B gets 9.3 for attracting rare and valuable female engineers, and a further 9.0 for attracting more (but not quite so rare) male education students. Our calculations will be more detailed than the example above, as we will examine subjects on a three-way table of gender, ethnicity and social class. This will allow us to address such particular groups as Caribbean men, and Bangladeshi women.

Second, we propose to measure the added economic value of institutions. We know the incomes achieved by university graduates three years after graduation - by the type of university, subject, and by the gender and ethnicity of the individual, from the recent report from the Institute for Employment Research/CSU, entitled Moving On: Graduate careers three years after graduation.

Given the total subject mix, degree class results and ethnic and gender composition of each institution's graduates, we can calculate the average earnings of the graduates from every institution. We also know what a similar person, of the same age, would be earning if they had chosen not to go to a particular university, despite having the qualifications to do so. The difference between the two would seem to be a very real proxy for the "added value" of a degree in a particular subject area, from a particular university, for an individual with a particular social background.

Our third proposed measure is of lifelong learning. We propose three equal elements to this scale. An age-on-admission index of full-time and part-time students will show how good institutions are at recruiting students during life, rather than simply post-school. And a measure of how much institutions are recognising and valuing qualifications acquired by applicants after formal schooling. Third, a simple index of the proportion of part-time students will show how much an institution is allowing students to study concurrently with "life" outside.

At Greenwich, David Blunkett proposed "extra resources [to] unlock engagement in higher education from communities in which there is no expectation of it at present". The measures we propose may well tell him where to direct those resources in future.

fields.bodyText: David Blunkett's speech at Greenwich called for universities to "contribute to social justice on a sustained, sector-wide basis". We are enjoined to "pursue wider social inclusion as an institutional objective" in which "success must be understood and measured by how far institutions serve the population as a whole", which he then spelt out as meaning all social classes, all ethnic groups, at all stages of their lives. The track record of the university sector in achieving social inclusion has, to date, been woefully inadequate. It could even be argued that universities have become even more socially divisive than they were before the Robbins report in 1963. Between 1928 and 1947, some 8.9% of all boys from non-manual backgrounds entered university, compared to 1.4% of all boys from manual backgrounds. By the time of Robbins, 16.8% of boys from non-manual backgrounds entered higher education, and 2.6% of boys from manual backgrounds (data on the background of women students does not seem to have been reported). The expansion of the past decade has made it even more likely that the higher socio-economic group participate in higher education: 80% of children from social class one backgrounds attend university, while less than one in eight children from an unskilled manual background enters higher education. What of gender equality? Whilst the earlier under-representation of women in higher education overall has been rectified, there remain major gender inequalities in many subjects: for example, insufficient men taking education courses, too few women in science and engineering. The incorporation of ethnic minorities into higher education shows a similar erratic pattern. What appears overall to be a major change as substantial numbers of ethnic minorities enter higher education, masks the exclusion of particular groups - Bangladeshi females, African-Caribbean males - as well as the fact that they are particularly concentrated in a few universities. This is a system - as Blunkett says - of "the entrenched exclusion of large sections of our society from higher education". Universities are now reproducing social inequality more efficiently than they ever have in the past. They have replaced the grammar school as the prime instrument of entrenching social stratification. Lord Dearing pointed out in the National Committee of Inquiry into Higher Education that higher education was not powerless to affect the participation rates of under-represented groups. The Hefce Performance Indicators in Higher Education 1996-98, which were produced last December, were supposed to offer a measure of the extent to which different institutions were addressing social exclusion. However, they did this through setting individual "benchmarks" for each institution, based simply on the degree of social inclusion that might be expected given the particular entry qualifications of their current students. This amounts to saying that if an institution only takes students with very high A level grades, then it can't be expected to take on many students from the lower socio-economic classes, or students from ethnic minority backgrounds. The Hefce tables for the participation of under-represented groups are simply an acceptance of the status quo, and are being used to justify inaction. The excuse offered is that our universities have diverse missions, and thus cannot be directly compared: this apparently allows some universities to have a mission that does not address questions of social inclusion. We propose to construct alternative measures of the role of individual universities in contributing to social inclusion. Dearing included amongst the purposes of universities the promotion of social cohesion and the development of lifelong learning and the creation of "the learning society", as well as economic regeneration and development. Blunkett has echoed this in his Greenwich speech. We propose the creation of three new scales to measure how much each area of each university's work contributes to these objectives. First, we propose to measure added social inclusion: how much does each institution, in each subject band, contribute to the inclusion of all socio-economic groups and of all ethnic groups, in a gender-neutral manner? We know that overall, universities recruit males and females equally, but we should be measuring success in this area in terms of balances in each subject band, not in gross terms. Compare two hypothetical institutions, each recruiting only engineers and teachers: Institution A appears to do better overall than institution B: but given the overall national gender imbalance in undergraduate numbers in these two subjects, institution B is in reality doing a better job at addressing under-representation. What is needed is a measure that reflects which groups are under-represented in each area in higher education, compared to the distribution of each group in the 18-30 year-old population of the country. If there are 51% of females of student age in the country, then we should expect to find that proportion in each subject area in the higher education sector. We will determine - by gender, ethnicity and social class - the distribution of young people receiving higher education in each subject grouping, and compare this to the distribution of the same groups in the population of young people in the country as a whole. We therefore weight each of these students according to how much they are not represented in the total higher education population. fields.headline: English class where?
fields.standfirst: Many refugees in Britain are desperate for language lessons
fields.trailText: Many refugees in Britain are desperate for language lessons
fields.body:
Straight into the college foyer on Monday morning, and I see the first asylum seeker of the week at the reception desk, looking Middle Eastern, and tired. "I need English. English class where?" Reluctantly, I declare myself. "I teach English. Can I help you?"

The answer is that I can't. We have no more spaces in any of our classes for English as a second language (Esol). We have a file bulging with names and addresses of desperate refugees. We are no longer enrolling students, and I should simply tell him to come back in three months' time when we are starting summer courses.

But I can't face the disappointment in his eyes. So we go upstairs and I ask him to write down his name and address and promise to get in touch if there are any spaces. "But please you give me class soon," he begs.

I glance down at his address, Primrose Heights, another of these privately run hostels whose living conditions belie the promise of its name.

"I come back again tomorrow."

"No, not tomorrow. Wait until we write to you," and I mimic the act of writing with an imaginary pencil in the air. "I at home all day," he says. "Do nothing. Need English. Need class."

He starts to follow me into the staff-room to plead his case and colleagues look up wearily. I manage to get rid of him at last, after marking his name with an asterisk and the words "very keen". We date all entries and try to offer places on a first-come, first-served basis, but many names have special pleas for clemency attached, and when we trawl the files we try to take these into account. We also have to work out whether to offer several classes to a few students, thereby enabling them to learn English more quickly, or one class a week to many students. We eventually decide to send notes round to all the Esol staff again, asking them to look at their class lists and see if they can squeeze in a few extras.

The week continues in the same pattern, the normal demands of teaching and administration being punctuated by the extra requests of the new arrivals in the corridors.

We started our classes and filled them in September, but huge numbers of asylum seekers began to arrive without warning in the middle of winter. We have laid on as many extra classes as we can without notice, but we are stretched to breaking point, as are other nearby colleges and Esol centres.

We have taken on new staff, thus increasing the overcrowding in our squalid staffroom. We are even bussing students twice a day to a nearby campus where new IT facilities are proving a boon to the new refugee students. (Many with a smattering of English and an interest in computing have enrolled on a Start IT course while awaiting the holy grail of Esol.)

Meanwhile our role in the college extends far beyond that of mere teaching. We are worried about the students' living conditions. Some came to us from a hostel where there was no hot water for a week. They smelt so bad that teachers on enrolment duty were gagging as they filled in the forms. Others are suffering from the bad diets forced on them in these hostels, or from the fact that they have been housed out of town but are not being given their bus fare to attend college.

We find ourselves phoning social services in the south of England to plead for students to be rehoused, as they have been placed in unsuitable housing without local consultation. Other teachers are phoning the churches to find out about secondhand clothing and furniture for our students. We have to deal with mental health problems too. Many asylum seekers are traumatised and deeply unhappy. A few are aggressive.

What is going on? Who is responsible for all this? Why were we not given any warning of these numbers in September so that we could prepare to run extra classes? We have always taken pride in our Esol department, seeing ourselves as a happy and successful part of the college, efficiently led by a section leader who is both professional and compassionate and with classes of satisfied and hard-working students.

Now we find ourselves exhausted, demoralised and embarrassed at having to turn so many people away. We are haunted by the corridor people, their faces pressed against the glass of our staffroom door. It feels as if we are in a kind of corridor too, a halfway place between compassion and frustration, and Britain seems to be in a kind of large-scale corridor of its own, not sure whether it is helping asylum seekers or punishing them.

One thing seems certain - if we continue to move vast numbers of people around the country to areas of high unemployment without any support systems in place for them, we are storing up trouble that will explode in a way which lowly further education teachers cannot control.

I recently set a class the mundane homework task of designing an information leaflet for public library users. A Kurdish refugee wrote: "You have to be careful when you choose the book because from those books which you will read, the Iraqi security service will know how do you think. You can find these books are against the Iraqi government but you cannot read them. If you read them, you will go to the prison as soon as possible."

In a country where we have the luxury of reading the books of our choice, could we not also offer a little more practical help to people from countries where this is not possible?
