fields.headline: Earth to earth
fields.standfirst: An artist's exhibit of a box of soil, imported from Transylvania, highlights a feverish interest in Dracula.  Tim Radford  disinters a cultural phenomenon
fields.trailText: An artist's exhibit of a box of soil, imported from Transylvania, highlights a feverish interest in Dracula. Tim Radford disinters a cultural phenomenon
fields.body:
It could be just a box of soil in an art gallery. Or it could be a metaphor for the gothic novel's darkest horror, and London's most sinister asylum seeker, Dracula. It all depends on your point of view, says Roman Vasseur, 33, artist and lecturer at the Chelsea College of Art and Design and other centres, including the University of the West of England.

Vasseur plans a poker-faced little exercise later this month. He will fill a cubic-metre crate with earth from the Borgo Pass in Transylvania, and ship it to Vienna and thence to London, where it will go on display at the Austrian Cultural Institute, along with a solemn array of paperwork involved in the sepulchral transaction. Every attempt will be made, he says "to avoid direct reference to myths and fictions commonly associated with this region of Eastern Europe".

He knows people will make the connection anyway. Every buff of Dracula, fiction's most famous fanged fiend, knows that the old prowler could only rest on his own soil. In Bram Stoker's 1897 novel the young lawyer Jonathan Harker finds himself in Dracula's castle at the head of the Borgo Pass arranging the details of the undead count's emigration to Whitby and then London, and a reign of lurid terror which ends climactically in a knife thrust and a crumble of dust on a box of earth in the Borgo Pass. That ought to have been that.

Right now, the sinister aristo with a limited diet and a thing about mirrors and garlic is as active as ever, and widening his audience with enthusiastic help from assorted scholars who find Dracula either mesmerising in himself, or something to make the students sit up a bit; who see Dracula as an emblem of the larger fascination with evil, or as a metaphor for the nightmares of society.

Best known of these is probably Elizabeth Miller, a professor of English at the Memorial University of Newfoundland. She is the architect of Dracula's homepage, as well as the editor of the Journal of Dracula Studies.

Vasseur's excavation will be the climax of an academic gathering in the Transylvanian town of Poiana Brasov next month. It will be the second such congress of the Transylvanian Society of Dracula, part solemn conclave of gothic scholars, part circus of ghouls, and will focus on such dark questions as Dracula and the Blair Witch Project; and Satanic panics: the diabolic presence in America. The congress will also listen to a lecture from the actress Ingrid Pitt, better known to Hammer horror film buffs as Countess Dracula, about the notorious Elizabeth Bathori who bathed in the blood of virgins.

Ethnographers will try to make sense of the diabolic in Romanian folk tradition. A Romanian critic will pounce upon the work of the poet Alan Brownjohn, who set one of his novels in Romania and called its hero Tim Harker Johnes. There will be an overview of the "New York city vampire youth subculture". There will be a bid to match the two Draculas, fictional and historical. A professor from Spain threatens to address "neo-romantic vampirism and bloodletting existentialism in elitist black metal music". There will be a lecture on "Dracula, hunting and imperialism".

Vasseur's box of dirt at a gallery in Knightsbridge is intended to play upon all the primal fears.

"It is a substance which on the one hand is utterly banal and has no meaning, but you only have to say 'Transylvania' and all the associations kick off. All of a sudden this very banal substance means everything. The associations are so strong that people can't help themselves."

The display is not cluttered by anything other than the documentation. There will be no stake or mallet, no garlic or crucifixes. And there will only be one box, one metre cubed (in the novel, Dracula shipped 24 of them). It's a discussion about meaning itself. "That's the reason for doing it: to ask people where does meaning reside if you can conjure up associations that easily or that quickly, by the substance and by the journey from Transylvania to London having such potency attached to it?" he says. "The thing is to avoid all kinds of lyrical elements and to keep it as inexpressive as possible, so it implodes through its associations."

Lesser mortals might have been tempted to have the soil carted away by gypsies with horses, as in the book. He decided to keep it practical, and use the shipping services Dracula might have chosen if he were stalking the land today. Not that the vampire ever existed, especially in Transylvania, now part of Romania.

Bram Stoker was an Irishman who originally intended to reside his vampire in Austria, who knew of Transylvania only from a Baedeker guidebook and who commandeered the name of a cruel Romanian prince quite late in the writing of the novel. Most Romanians had never heard of the literary Dracula, let alone seen a Christopher Lee movie, until a decade ago.

In Romania, Vlad Dracula, also known as Vlad the Impaler, is a bit of a hero. In Britain and America, paradoxically, the literary vampire has become a relatively sympathetic figure. Count Dracula has spawned a literary genre, and he and his seed have colonised all other media as well.

There are now university courses focusing on vampire fiction in particular and the gothic novel in general. There are scholars who see Dracula as part of the 19th-century Romantic tradition. And there really is a Castle Dracula in the Borgo Pass. It was built, quite recently, as a tourist hotel. All these nuances can only add to the complexity of the questions raised by a box of earth.

"The earth is just what Hitchcock calls a McGuffin; it's the thing that propels the plot along in a way, and the work is the kind of rumour in the air," Vasseur says. "It's a process which bears some similarities to a process which is written about in a book called Dracula, so it is down to the audience to draw those parallels themselves."

 Roman Vasseur's box of earth is on display at the Austrian Cultural Institute from June 12.

webTitle: Activists should reclaim higher moral ground

fields.headline: Activists should reclaim higher moral ground
fields.standfirst: The peaceful message sent out by most Reclaim the Streets demonstrators yesterday was marred by the violence of just a few and organisers have not helped the cause by their complicit silence, says Guardian environment editor John Vidal
fields.trailText: The peaceful message sent out by most Reclaim the Streets demonstrators yesterday was marred by the violence of just a few and organisers have not helped the cause by their complicit silence, says Guardian environment editor John Vidal.
fields.body:
Had Tony Blair sat down and devised a plan to discredit the environment movement with which he has little sympathy, he could not have been more successful. The Mayday Reclaim the Streets event in central London was, as ever, hijacked by a few thugs with no interest whatever in the broader ecological and social justice aims that almost all those in Parliament Square shared yesterday.

The media, predictably, highlighted the violence and not the almost visionary transformation of the square into an allotment, the turf carefully transplanted on to the Tarmac. The result is that people with a genuine point to make about the nature of life in the cities or the global environment crisis are now linked with thuggery and extremism, a point which will not be lost later this summer when new laws will have been passed, making it effectively a terrorist offence to damage property in pursuit of a cause.

But Reclaim the Streets must share the blame. The alliance of groups and individuals who devised the day have at no point tried to disassociate themselves from the violence they knew was going to occur.

By refusing to condone it or to condemn it, they have played only into the hands of the thugs. By offering no voice of explanation or excuse to the media, they have lost the chance to pass on their message. Yet very many people who have attended RTS meetings over the past year are peaceful and would not take violent action themselves.

They have allowed the agenda of the few to dominate the perception of the many. fields.bodyText: Had Tony Blair sat down and devised a plan to discredit the environment movement with which he has little sympathy, he could not have been more successful. The Mayday Reclaim the Streets event in central London was, as ever, hijacked by a few thugs with no interest whatever in the broader ecological and social justice aims that almost all those in Parliament Square shared yesterday. The media, predictably, highlighted the violence and not the almost visionary transformation of the square into an allotment, the turf carefully transplanted on to the Tarmac. The result is that people with a genuine point to make about the nature of life in the cities or the global environment crisis are now linked with thuggery and extremism, a point which will not be lost later this summer when new laws will have been passed, making it effectively a terrorist offence to damage property in pursuit of a cause. But Reclaim the Streets must share the blame. The alliance of groups and individuals who devised the day have at no point tried to disassociate themselves from the violence they knew was going to occur. By refusing to condone it or to condemn it, they have played only into the hands of the thugs. By offering no voice of explanation or excuse to the media, they have lost the chance to pass on their message. fields.body:
Ahead of them, the sun had risen above the car's roof, leaving the windscreen filled with a harsh unpunctuated whiteness that threatened to become painful. The forest on the driver's side thinned out and was replaced by a steep embankment infested with creepers and bluebells. Signs printed in several languages unknown to Isserley reminded foreigners not to drive on the wrong side of the road.

The temperature inside the car was approaching stifling, even for Isserley, who could tolerate extremes without particularly caring. Her glasses were starting to fog up, but she couldn't take them off now: he mustn't see her eyes without them. A slow, subtle trickle of perspiration ran down her neck onto her breastbone, hesitating on the brink of her cleavage. Her hitcher seemed not to notice. His hands were drumming desultorily on his inner thighs to some tune she couldn't hear; as soon as he realized she was watching, he stopped abruptly and folded his hands limply over his crotch.

What on earth had happened to him? What had brought on this dismal metamorphosis? Just as she'd grown to appreciate how attractive a prospect he was, he seemed to be shrinking before her eyes; he wasn't the same male she'd taken into her car twenty minutes ago. Was he one of those inadequate lugs whose sexual self-confidence depended on not being reminded of any real females? Or was it her fault?

'You can open a window if you're too hot,' she offered.

He nodded, didn't even speak.

Isserley pressed her foot gingerly down on the accelerator, hoping this would please him. But he just sighed and settled further back in his seat, as if what he considered to be an insignificant increase in speed only reminded him how slowly they were getting nowhere.

Maybe she shouldn't have said she was a lawyer. Maybe a shop assistant or an infant teacher would have brought him out more. It was just that she'd taken him to be a rough, robust kind of character; she'd thought he might have a criminal history he'd start to talk about, as a way of teasing her, testing her out. Maybe the only truly safe thing she could have been was a housewife.

'Your wife,' she rejoined, striving for a reassuring, companionable, male sort of tone, a tone he might expect from a drinking buddy. 'Did she get the house?'

'Yeah . . . well . . . no . . .' He drew a deep breath. 'I had to sell it, and give her half. She went to live in Bradford. I stayed on here.'

'Where's here?' she asked, nodding her head at the open road, hoping to remind him how far she had taken him already.

'Milnafua.' He sniggered, as if self-conscious about the name.

To Isserley, Milnafua sounded perfectly normal; more normal in fact than London or Dundee, which she had some trouble getting her tongue round. She appreciated, however, that to him it represented some outlandish extreme.

'There's no work anywhere up there, is there,' she suggested, hoping she was striking a matter-of-fact, masculine note of sympathy.

'Don't I know it,' he mumbled. Then, with a startling boost of volume and pitch: 'Still, got to keep trying, eh?'

Looking at him in disbelief, she confirmed what he was playing at: a pathetic gesture towards optimism, missing the mark by miles. He was even smiling, his face sheened with sweat, as if he'd suddenly become convinced it was dangerous to admit to too much sloth, as if there could be serious consequences for admitting to her that his life was spent on the dole. Was it all her fault for telling him she was a lawyer? Had she made him afraid that she'd get him in trouble? Or that one day she might turn out to have some official power over him? Could she apologize, laughing, for her deception and start all over again? Tell him she sold computer software or clothes for the larger lady?

A big green sign at the side of the road announced how many miles remained before Dingwall and Inverness: not very many. The land had fallen away on the left side, revealing the gleaming shore of the Cromarty Firth. The tide was low, all the rocks and sands exposed. A solitary seal languished on one of those rocks, as if stranded.

Isserley bit her lip, slowly adjusting to her mistake. Lawyer, saleswoman, housewife: it wouldn't have made any difference. He was wrong for her, that's all. She had picked up the wrong type. Again.

Yes, it was obvious now what this big, touchy bruiser was up to. He was going to Bradford to visit his wife, or at least his children.

This made him a bad risk, from her point of view. Things could get very complicated when there were children involved. Much as she wanted him - it was sinking in now how much she'd already invested in the idea of having him - she didn't want complications. She would have to give him up. She would have to put him back.

They both sat in silence for the rest of the journey, as if conscious of having let each other down.

Traffic had accumulated all around them; they were caught up in an orderly queue of vehicles crossing the multi-laned tightrope of Kessock Bridge. Isserley glanced at her hitcher, felt a pang of loss at finding him turned away from her, staring down at the industrial estates of the Inverness shore far below. He was appraising a dismal toy-town of prefab ugliness as intently as he had admired her breasts not so long ago. Tiny trucks disappearing into factory mouths: that was what made sense to him now.

Isserley kept to the left, drove faster than she'd done all day. It wasn't just the pace demanded by the traffic around her; she wanted to get this over with as soon as possible. The tiredness had returned with a vengeance; she longed to find a shady bower off the road, lean her head against the seat and sleep a while.

On the far side, where the bridge rejoined the mainland, she negotiated the roundabout with pained and earnest concentration, to avoid being caught up in the town-bound traffic and herded to Inverness. She didn't even bother to disguise her grimace of anxiety as she did this: she had already lost him, after all.

However, to fill the silence of their last few moments together, she offered him a small parting consolation.

'I'll drive you just a bit further, get you past the Aberdeen turn-off. Then at least you'll know all the cars passing you are going south.'

'Great, yeah,' he said passionlessly.

'Who knows?' she jollied him. 'You might get to Bradford by tonight.'

'Bradford?' he frowned, turning to challenge her. 'Who says I'm going to Bradford?'

'To see your kids?' she reminded him.

There was an awkward pause, then:

'I never see my kids,' he stated flatly. 'I don't even know where they live, exactly. Somewhere in Bradford, that's as much as I know. Janine - my ex-wife - doesn't want anything to do with me. I don't exist anymore as far as she's concerned.' He peered straight ahead, as if roughly calculating all the thousands of places that lay south, and comparing that number to what he himself amounted to.

'Bradford was years ago, anyway,' he said. 'She could've moved to fuckin' Mars by now, for all I know.'

'So . . .' enquired Isserley, changing gear with such clumsiness that the gearbox made a hideous grinding noise, 'where are you hoping to get to today?'

Her hitcher shrugged. 'Glasgow will do me,' he told her. 'There's some good pubs there.'

Noticing her looking past him at the signs announcing imminent parking areas, it registered with him that she was about to discharge him from the car. Abruptly he mustered a last incongruous burst of conversational energy, fuelled by bitterness.

'It beats sitting in the Commercial Hotel in Alness with a bunch of old boilers listening to some idiot singin' fuckin' ''Copacabana''.'

'But where will you sleep?'

'I know a couple of guys in Glasgow,' he told her, faltering again, as if that last squirt of fuel had already sputtered into the atmosphere. 'It's just a matter of running into them, that's all. They'll be there somewhere. It's a small world, eh?'

Isserley was staring ahead at the snow-capped mountains. It looked like a pretty big world to her.

'Mm,' she said, unable to share his vision of how Glasgow might greet him. Sensing this, he made a small mournful gesture, an opening out of his beefy hands to show there was nothing in them.

'Although people can always let you down, eh?' he said. 'That's why you always got to have a plan B.'

And he swallowed hard, his Adam's apple bulging like a real one stuck in his neck.

Isserley nodded approvingly, trying not to let her feelings show. She was covered in sweat now, cold chills running down her back like electric currents. Her heart hammered so hard her breasts shook; she disciplined herself to take just one deep breath instead of many shallow ones. Keeping her right hand clamped securely to the steering wheel she checked the rear-view mirror, the other lane, her speed, the hitcher.

Everything was ideal, everything pointed to this moment.

Noticing her excitement, he grinned at her uncertainly, removing his hands from his lap with an awkward jerk, as if waking up, dazed, to something that might yet be expected of him. She grinned back in reassurance, nodding almost imperceptibly as if to say 'Yes'.

Then the middle finger of her left hand flipped a little toggle on the steering wheel.

It might have been for the headlights or the indicators, or for the windscreen wipers. It was neither. It was the icpathua toggle, the trigger for the needles inside the passenger seat, to make them spring up silently from their little sheath-like burrows in the upholstery.

The hitcher flinched as they stung him through the fabric of his jeans, one needle in each buttock. His eyes, by chance, were facing the rear-view mirror, but no-one but Isserley witnessed the expression in them; the nearest vehicle was a giant lorry labelled FARMFOODS which was far away still, its driver an insect head behind tinted glass. In any case, the hitcher's look of surprise was momentary; the dose of icpathua was adequate for body sizes considerably larger than his. He lost consciousness and his head lolled back into the padded hollow of the headrest.

Isserley flipped another toggle, her fingers trembling ever so slightly. The gentle tick of the indicator lights set the rhythm of her breathing as she allowed the car to drift off the road and smoothly enter the lay-by. The speedometer wobbled to zero; the car stopped moving; the engine stalled, or maybe she turned off the ignition. It was over.

As always at this moment, she saw herself as if from a height; an aerial view of her little red Toyota parked in its little asphalt parenthesis. The FARMFOODS lorry roared past on the straight.

Then, as always, Isserley fell from her vantage point, a dizzying drop, and plunged back into her body. Her head slammed against the headrest, quite a lot harder than his had done, and she inhaled shudderingly. Gasping, she clung to the steering wheel, as if it might stop her falling further down, into the bowels of the earth.

Finding her way back to ground level always took a little while. She counted her breaths, slowly getting them down to six a minute. Then she unclenched her hands from the steering wheel, laid them over her stomach. That was always oddly comforting.

When at last the adrenaline had ebbed and she was feeling calmer, she re-applied herself to the job in hand. Vehicles were humming past from both directions, but she could only hear them, not see them. The glass of all the car's windows had turned dark amber, at the touch of a button on the dashboard. She was never aware of having touched that button; it must happen during the adrenaline rush. She only remembered that always, by the time she was at this point, the windows were already dark.

Something massive drove past, vibrating the ground, sweeping a black shadow across the car. She waited till it was gone.

Then she opened the glove box and fetched out the wig. It was a wig for males, but blond and curly. She turned to the hitcher, who was still frozen in position, and placed the wig carefully on his head. She smoothed some wayward locks over his ears, pecked at the fringe with her sharp fingernails to help it settle over the forehead. She leaned back and evaluated the total effect, made some more adjustments. Already he looked much like all the others she had picked up; later, when his clothes were off, he would look more or less identical.

Next she scooped a handful of different spectacles from the glove box and selected an appropriate pair. She slid them into position over the hitcher's nose and ears.

Finally she retrieved the anorak from the back seat, allowing the hitcher's own coat to slip onto the floor. The anorak was actually only the front half of the garment; the back had been cut away and discarded. She arranged the fur-lined facade over the hitcher's upper torso, tucking the edges of the sleeves round his arms, draping the bisected hood over his shoulders.

He was ready to go.

She pressed a button and the amber faded from the windows like dispersion in reverse. The world outside was still chilly and bright. There was a lull in the traffic. She had about two hours' grace before the icpathua wore off, yet she was only fifty minutes' drive from home. And it was only 9:35. She was doing well after all.

She turned the key in the ignition. As the engine started up, the rattling noise that had worried her earlier on made itself heard again.

She would have to look into that when she got back to the farm.

fields.headline: End of the affair
fields.standfirst: Diverging ambitions and attitudes in Germany and France have damaged their traditional leadership roles in the European Union
fields.trailText: Not long ago France and Germany were the motor driving the European Union, the joint force that kept the show on the road. But now the engine is sputtering dangerously and may even grind to a halt.
fields.body:
Not long ago France and Germany were the motor driving the European Union, the joint force that kept the show on the road. But now the engine is sputtering dangerously and may even grind to a halt.

Look back over the past half-century: Europe without these old enemies at its heart is impossible to imagine. Since the first attempts at integration with the formation of the European Coal and Steel Community in 1951, the desperate need for reconciliation between France and Germany pulled others in their wake. From Konrad Adenauer and Charles de Gaulle, Helmut Schmidt and Giscard D'Estaing, through to Helmut Kohl and François Mitterrand, the partnership allowed the countries on either side of the Rhine to transcend their traditional and destructive fixation on each other in a task which "embedded the bilateral issue in a project larger than both".

It also allowed France to play a role to which it could no longer aspire on its own - of being arbiter of Europe and and first among equals. Links were institutionalised by the Elysée Treaty in 1963. Two decades later, with the former French minister Jacques Delors running the European Commission, the decision to launch the euro put the two countries' joint commitment to integration above their own national interest - at least in the short term.

Under President Jacques Chirac and Chancellor Gerhard Schröder it has been a different story. The engine's reduced pulling power is in creasingly apparent. Romano Prodi, president of the commission, has publicly urged both to rev up. This was the response from the Quai d'Orsay last month: "From our point of view, the French-German motor is necessary but it is not sufficient to make Europe progress". Paris, not so coyly, is playing hard to get.

In a fundamental way, the Franco-German relationship is the victim of its own success. Peace is simply taken for granted. And so much so that ordinary Frenchmen were far ahead of their government in supporting German unification. Basics changed when the Berlin Wall came down. Germany, though still seriously hobbled by its past, suddenly became the more powerful of the two allies. Divergences over the collapse of Yugoslavia were one symptom of this.

In both countries too, old-style national interest has reasserted itself increasingly over the last decade. The trade-off between French agri culture and German industry now barely exists. Chirac's nuclear testing in the Pacific caused outrage on the other side of the Rhine in 1995. Last year Schröder, never keen on swapping the deutschmark for the euro, balked openly at having to pay more for the EU budget under Agenda 2000.

Since the launch of the single currency, there has been no big project to unite Paris and Berlin. Enlargement, the most ambitious item on the EU agenda, is a source of division. Germany, though worried about Polish farmers and Hungarian pollution, is deeply committed to expanding the number of members. France, by contrast, is still more interested in the southern Mediterranean and the Maghreb.

Personalities matter too. Kohl's departure was the loss of a man of European vision. France's socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, is less enthusiastic about Europe than his predecessors. President Chirac, his partner (and rival) in cohabitation, operates in mainstream Gaullist tradition and is bored at EU summits. No surprise then that France's turn at the EU's rotating presidency, which begins this July, is awaited elsewhere in Europe with some trepidation.

fields.headline: Natural powerhouse
fields.standfirst:
Yesterday, the Daily Telegraph linked Darren Johnson to the 'anarchist hooligans' who protest against free trade. In fact the Green candidate widely tipped to be London's first deputy mayor is more concerned with cycling than global capitalism. He talks to Jim White
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Yesterday, the Daily Telegraph linked Darren Johnson to the 'anarchist hooligans' who protest against free trade. In fact the Green candidate widely tipped to be London's first deputy mayor is more concerned with cycling than global capitalism. He talks to  Jim White
fields.body:
Darren Johnson, the Green Party candidate for the mayor of London election, must be sick of hearing media representatives apologising for arriving by car at his campaign photo opportunities. One day last week, when Johnson attended an event organised by the campaign to ban cars from Richmond Park, the half- dozen photographers, reporters and radio journalists who were there all turned up, shame-faced, by motor.

"Sorry about coming by car," said the snapper from the local paper, who compounded her crime by leaving her Fiat alongside a sign reading: "Strictly no parking: emergency access only." "The thing is," she added, "I'm well sympathetic to what you're trying to do, but I can't do my job without that thing."

"Never mind," smiled Johnson, using a line you sense he has employed several times a day this past month. "I'm prepared to make a policy exception for media coverage."

Not that there were many there to witness the potential embarrassment of a Green-backed campaign to ban cars apparently encouraging illegal parking. As mass grass-roots protests go, this one was not up there with Seattle. Nevertheless, undeterred, Richard Evans and John Wrepsch of the Friends of Richmond Park had gathered on their bikes at Sheen Gate, with their banner saying "cyclists before motorists", keen to use the moment to draw attention to the growing pollution problem in the park's glorious acres.

"Looking at the traffic today, you probably think I'm pulling your leg," John Wrepsch said as little more than a couple of cars a minute ambled through the gate. "But you should see this place on a nice sunny Saturday, absolutely nose to tail."

The two protesters explained they had alerted Darren Johnson to the cause when they happened upon him out on the streets canvassing.

"I saw Steve Norris in the local paper saying cars must be allowed to carry on going through the park, so I thought it would be good to get one of his rivals on our side," said Richard Evans. "It could just as easily have been Ken or Susan Kramer or Dobson, but Darren was the only one I've come across."

It may have been chance, but Johnson seemed the appropriate choice. He arrived at Sheen Gate travelling across the park aboard his version of David Steel's old electoral battle bus: a bike with a flag saying Vote Green fluttering out of a pannier. He was conducting an interview by mobile phone as he cycled, offering a new twist on mobile etiquette: "Sorry, didn't quite hear that," he was saying, "I'm on my bike right now."

Pedalling alongside him were three members of the Johnson team, including his fund raiser, Dean Walton, who also happens to be his partner. Darren and Dean have been hard at it since last May, campaigning since the day the Greens became the first party to announce a candidate for the London race. Here's how long they've been campaigning: when they first started, Darren shared a debate platform with Jeffrey Archer.

"It's been brilliant," beamed Dean. "We're having the time of our lives. Things are just getting better."

Which is undoubtedly true. As the race has developed, one unexpected side-product has become clear: although opinion polls suggest he can muster only about 7% of the vote, Darren Johnson is likely to emerge on May 5 as the most powerful Green in British political history. Not only is he almost certain, under the proportional representation system, to gain one of the 24 seats in the Greater London Assembly for which he is also standing; not only has Ken Livingstone - should he win - promised him the chair of the environment committee; but informed gossip has it that he will be named as Livingstone's deputy.

No wonder Darren Johnson can't stop smiling: at the politically tender age of 33, he is poised on the lip of what might be the Greens' big break through.

"I had a journalist on the phone two hours after Ken declared," Johnson grinned, "asking me if it was true I was going to be deputy."

Well? Is it?

"Ken's actually said he would like the other four main candidates to rotate as deputy, one a year. But it's not at all clear whether the others would buy that. We would, though."

But surely there has been some discussion about the possibility, some behind-the-scenes negotiation with the favourite himself?

"No, honestly, there hasn't."

Deal or no deputy deal, Darren Johnson does acknowledge that the Livingstone candidacy has been the best thing to happen to the Greens since the 1989 Euro elections, when the party accrued 2.5m votes. And it is not simply that Livingstone has recommended his supporters should vote Green in the assembly elections running concurrently with the mayoral race.

"Ken standing has completely broken down traditional party barriers," Johnson said. "You only have to look at the way Steve Norris has been desperately trying to dissociate himself from the Tories to see that party perceptions are very unhelpful in this election. London just seems to be engaged in a completely different politics. I look at the papers reflecting the middle England-New Labour agenda of farmers shooting intruders and jailing asylum seekers and I sometimes think I'm reading about another country."

The Daily Telegraph seems to regard him not so much as an inhabitant of another country as a threat from another planet. In an interview in the paper yesterday, Johnson was depicted as a revolutionary seeking to ban everything from the World Trade Organisation to the monarchy.

"The journalist kept asking me what I believed on all sorts of things," Johnson explained. "I was happy to tell him even though I kept spelling out that the GLA really won't have any responsibility for areas like the monarchy."

On the subject of the Telegraph's fear of revolutionary activity, was Johnson planning to be outside Westminster yesterday, digging up the pavement and planting rhubarb in the name of "guerrilla gardening"?

"No, I'll be at Alexandra Palace at the last mayoral hustings," he said. "Actually, I took the whole Telegraph thing as a compliment. I think it shows that we are a far bigger threat to the forces of conservatism than Blairite values are. It also adds to what I was saying about the way London is growing apart politically from the rest of the country."

Johnson has a point here. There has been a sense, at the myriad public meetings where they sit together on the platform, first- naming each other promiscuously, that the mayoral candidates have formed a little party of their own, colleagues rather than rivals. And Darren Johnson is keen for it to be known he is right in there.

"Oh God, we know each other backwards," he said. "We know each other's speeches, each other's jokes. In fact, at one meeting, I didn't hear a question from the floor. I was sitting next to Steve [Norris], so I asked him what the question was. He not only told me, he gave me the Green Party policy on the issue."

But what really excites Johnson about this election is that since the mayor's limited powers will coalesce around the Green agenda - public transport, rubbish recycling, cycle routes - he may well be in a position, once the votes have been counted, to deliver important party promises.

"When I first started canvassing for the Greens back in 1987, you could tell people thought of us as a bit abstract, you know, campaigning to save the whales. Now people are worried about traffic jams and children's asthma, and the environment is not seen as some good cause but a major part of the quality of life. So my 10-second doorstep spiel is: if you want to improve everyday life, my name's on the right-hand side of the yellow ballot paper."

As Johnson spoke, behind him in Richmond Park the practicalities of modern protest were coming into play. John Repsch had decided it might make a picture if all six cyclists, in a strategic piece of direct action, blocked the traffic at Richmond Gate. Johnson agreed, a risky strategy, you couldn't help feeling, jeopardising a few dozen votes at least in any ensuing jam. And so - the Green contingent by bike, the media by motor ("I would walk," the Guardian's photographer explained, "but I've got all this stuff") - everyone decamped across the park.

Here things did not quite turn out as planned. Despite Repsch's assurance that "no bugger in a car ever stops for a cyclist", the first driver we met at Richmond Gate halted and cheerily waved the protesters across the road. In the face of such politeness, nobody really had the stomach for mass protest. And so instead it was decided to repair to the pub.

"The one thing I've been really pleased about during this campaign is that we've managed to raise the profile of the Greens," said Johnson. "Yesterday, a woman came up to me and said she recognised me off the telly. That's never happened in Green politics before."

webTitle: The King and I and me

fields.headline: The King and I and me
fields.standfirst: Brian Thomson, designer of mega-musicals, talks to  Brian Logan
fields.trailText: Brian Thomson, designer of mega-musicals, talks to Brian Logan
fields.body:
I have just seen The King and I at the London Palladium. The impression is still seared into my retinas of glittering golden palaces flanked by enormous elephant sentries and burnished Buddhas in revolving pink throne-rooms, when the production designer says to me, "Actually, I'm a minimalist'.'

Brian Thomson is nothing if not a man of contradictions. His work on the original production of Jesus Christ Superstar helped create the mega-musical, a phenomenon he now laments. This summer he will orchestrate the closing ceremony of the Sydney Olympics while simultaneously designing a Tennessee Williams play for a modest Australian theatre. Then there is his work on The King and I, which Thomson wrestles to persuade himself is consistent with having co-created the once transgressive Rocky Horror Show.

The King and I, as immortalised on screen by Yul Brynner and Deborah Kerr, is the one in which a British schoolteacher civilises 19th-century Thailand according to the flawless value system of God and Queen Victoria. For all that, Thomson argues that the current production, which stars Elaine Paige and US film actor Jason Scott Lee, need offend neither political nor aesthetic principles. Not that most punters care. The production has taken £8m in advance ticket sales.

Padding around his Soho flat in a King and I sweatshirt, the personable 54-year-old uber-designer recalls his response to being summoned for the production. "I said I didn't really think it was my cup of tea." So what changed his mind? "I had been working in Thailand on a couple of films, and I really loved the place. And I feel that Australians - much as we try to be a western enclave - are part of Asia. I think in 10, 20 years' time it'll be an Asian country. It's extraordinary to be Australian, living with hundreds of millions of people whose beliefs are so different to ours. I think that is somehow dealt with in The King and I."

His job enabled Thomson to redress some of the glaring problems of the earlier incarnations. "To be fair to the world when it was first done, Thailand was a long way away. Asia was anywhere from Turkey to Japan, and the original productions would take anything from any of those places. What I've done is taken elements from Thai architecture and Siamese ideas and theatricalised them." The results won Thomson a Tony Award for the show's Broadway production. But he is eager to point out that his designs are not there to draw attention to themselves. The designer's job is "to provide a world in which the story can be told".

So dedicated is Thomson to stories, he even tried to locate them in the oeuvre of Kylie Minogue, whose Intimate & Live tour he designed. "You're still dealing with ideas: how Kylie might do Better the Devil You Know is as tough an assignment as how you stage Getting to Know You in The King and I."

He shakes his head sadly when confronted with the irony that it was his "Brechtian, stripped-back" 1971 production of Jesus Christ Superstar that helped launch the design-heavy macro- musical. "I think Superstar is a much better show than the others. I'm not in the same position as a lot of other people who rely on Lloyd Webber for their future. I couldn't care less. I think Andrew has been so, so, so lucky to have truly wonderful productions done of very wispy little thin shows." Well, wonderful with a few exceptions: "Sunset Boulevard - what was all that about? Who wants a big house that goes up and down? It's just stupid. I think your spine should be tingling from the storytelling, and I think you can do that on a bare stage." It's no wonder that Thomson decries the fashion for identikit theatrical blockbusters. His own Superstar and Rocky Horror designs predated "the McDonald's, Les Mis, Cats thing", as Thomson calls it. "I might be richer had that been the case, but I hate to see cloned versions of Rent or Cats. It's so insulting."

Clearly Thomson, who maintains a balance between industrial-sized and intimate projects, is ill at ease with the Frankenstein his 70s work spawned. He transparently wants to believe that The King and I can rise above its undistinguished genre. "Look," he says, "it could be a fluffy musical that coachloads would come and enjoy. But Elaine and Jason are working hard to give it more than just that fluff. You can always do better than that."

 At the London Palladium (020-7494 5020) till June 24.

Election countdown: Torbay could be test for Hague fortunes
Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Torquay's red and yellow tulips are in full bloom, to the relief of the genteel residents who are still recovering after they were deprived of their flowers last summer.
fields.body:
Torquay's red and yellow tulips are in full bloom, to the relief of the genteel residents who are still recovering after they were deprived of their flowers last summer.

Memories are still sore at the cheek of the Liberal Democrat council, which abandoned Torquay's flowerbeds last year as a cost-cutting measure.

By the standards of the resort, the sight of unplanted flower beds was a blunder which could cost the Lib Dems dear in Thursday's elections.

Eileen Salloway, who is standing as a Tory, thundered: "It was appalling. As a tourist resort they are our shop window. The council has replanted the flowers, but that's only because it's election year."

For the Tories, who have high hopes of regaining Torbay district council which takes in Torquay, Paignton and Brixham, the Lib Dems' behaviour over the beloved tulips is a powerful illustration of why such upstarts are unfit to run the "English Riviera" along the Devon coast. Torbay was once solidly true blue, thanks to affluent retired residents who make up nearly half the population.

The unthinkable happened in 1991 when the Lib Dems wrested control of the council. The final humiliation came at the general election when the Lib Dems won by 12 votes, making Torbay the most marginal constituency in the country.

Since then, the Lib Dems have slowly lost their grip over the council and they are now forced to govern with the mayor's casting vote.

This has meant that on Thursday, when all seats are being contested for the first time since 1997, Torbay is top of the Conservatives' target list. William Hague has made two trips in recent months because he is painfully aware that the Tories' performance in Torbay will test his standing nationally.

If the Tories win back Torbay where they are six seats short of controlling the 36-seat council they will be able to claim that their fortunes are reviving. If not, they are on course for another humiliation.

Richard Cumming, the leader of the Tory group, admitted that he is facing a key test. He said: "For the first year after the election we had to look back. Now we are looking forward, so if we do not achieve a result on May 4 we will not have moved far enough forward."

On the doorsteps of Torbay, there are tentative signs of a recovery. Doors are no longer slammed in the faces of Tory canvassers.

Diehard supporters from the 1980s, who stayed at home in 1997 in disgust at the Tories' divisions, are indicating they will turn out for their old party again. Even a few dissidents, who voted Lib Dem or Labour in 1997, are saying they may return to the fold because they are seeing no improvement in public services.

Gillian Higham, a grandmother who lives in the port of Brixham , said she would be voting Tory on Thursday after abandoning the party at the local and general elections in 1997. "I voted for Tony Blair because the Tories didn't seem to do anything during the recession when my husband's businesses went bust. But I'm very uneasy now, particularly about the NHS.

"Nothing seems to be improving. I recently had an operation postponed twice and when I eventually got to hospital the nurses didn't seem to have time. They were constantly rushing about."

Mrs Higham was canvassed in the St Peter's with St Mary's ward by Sally Jowett, who is standing as a Conservative for the first time. As a single parent, Ms Jowett is the sort of new-look Tory the party leadership is trying to attract.

"Tories are not as stuffy as you would think, or maybe they haven't realised what they've let themselves in for with me," she laughed.

Ms Jowett's decision to join the Tories should provide something of a wake up call for the Lib Dems and Labour. After voting Labour in the 1997 general election, Ms Jowett said she is now attracted to the Tories because the Lib Dem council had failed to provide any recreational facilities for her sons and because the government's New Deal programme for the unemployed was failing the teenagers she knows.

"I voted Labour in 1997 because I was fed up with the Tories and now I feel short changed," Ms Jowett said.

However, for every voice praising the Tories, there are three which say the party is still a long way from recovery. Across the street from Mrs Higham, one pensioner was scathing about Mr Hague.

Roger Gunning, 84, who used to vote Tory, said: "I would never vote for William Hague because he doesn't seem to have any ideas and just seems to jump on to the latest bandwagon."

His opposition is unlikely to translate into support for the Lib Dems on Thursday, however, because the council has turned down an application for a playground.

There is irritation after council tax bills were hiked up by nearly 20% last year and a feeling that the Lib Dems deserve a spell in opposition after nearly a decade in power.

As he was canvassed by his Lib Dem councillors, John Penny 60, said: "The council has not been a great success, but at least the councillors have turned up. Our council tax has gone up, but don't all bills go up every year?"

Mr Penny voted for John Major in 1997, but he wouldn't dream of supporting the Tories as long as Mr Hague remains leader. "William Hague has no experience and about as much charisma as a bag of cold chips."

webTitle: Dobson lays into Green extremism as Livingstone seeks to placate City

fields.headline: Dobson lays into Green extremism as Livingstone seeks to placate City
fields.standfirst:
Frank Dobson
Ken Livingstone
Mayor for London
fields.trailText: The last-minute scramble for votes in the fight to become elected mayor of London yesterday saw Labour's Frank Dobson flay the "extremist" policies of Ken Livingstone's Green ally, Darren Johnson, while the once-Red Ken himself wooed the City of London.
fields.body:
The last-minute scramble for votes in the fight to become elected mayor of London yesterday saw Labour's Frank Dobson flay the "extremist" policies of Ken Livingstone's Green ally, Darren Johnson, while the once-Red Ken himself wooed the City of London.

Desperate to avoid being pushed into third or even fourth place in Thursday's voting, Mr Dobson said that Mr Johnson's plans to introduce a £3,000 a year charge for company car parking space exposes the "marriage of extremism" between the Greens and the independent Livingstone campaign.

Mr Johnson is running for mayor on the Green ticket. But he could be appointed Mr Livingstone's deputy if the front-runner clinches his expected victory after a second round play-off against the Tory candidate, Steve Norris, whom Mr Dobson also lambasted yesterday.

Mr Livingstone's past remarks in support of anti-capitalist demonstrations which ended in violence in both Seattle and the City gave him a tactical headache as fresh protests occurred in London.

He resolved the dilemma by lying low, and issuing the text of a pro-City speech he plans to make at a City award ceremony tonight.

In his bid to soothe the fears of the financial markets if he wins, Mr Livingstone promised the City to campaign for British membership of the eurozone and to use its expertise to develop London's global role.

Predicting that a "major crisis may greet the mayor at Dagenham," Mr Livingstone said the car industry's crisis was not the fault of London business or of Ford but of the high pound.

In a signal of clashes to come, Mr Livingstone's text confirmed: "I don't agree with the government's attitude on the euro." He promised to campaign for entry as mayor.

Mr Livingstone said the aboliton of the Greater London Council by Margaret Thatcher had hit the City as well as London as a whole.

Mr Dobson staged a press conference with families of victims of the 1990 Marchioness riverboat disaster to highlight Mr Norris's failure to order an inquiry into the sinking during his time as transport minister. Mr Norris is running second in the polls.

"Our experience of dealing with Mr Norris means that we know he is not fit to be mayor," said Barbara Davies, mother of one victim.

Labour granted an inquiry into the incident, the results of which were accepted this year. Yesterday Mr Norris promised an urgent assessment of riverbank safety equipment.

In a separate development Peter Tatchell, who is running for the Greater London authority, announced that he has written to President Mugabe of Zimbabwe, whom he tried to have arrested in London for his homophobic comments.

Mr Tatchell wrote: "Although my citizen's arrest of you last October failed, the next attempt will succeed.

"If you ever return to Britain, you will be liable to arrest on charges of torture - not by me, but by the Metropolitan police."

Mr Tatchell believes such an arrest would have the support of the GLA police authority on which he hopes to sit.
